title: Audit of House Post Office Finds Inadequate Controls Over Money
description: An audit of the post office at the House of Representatives found that controls over cash were still inadequate last week, nearly a year after an employee absconded to Puerto Rico with several thousand dollars of post office money, Congressional aides said today.

title: Informality Reigns, And Good Manners Get a Bad Name
description: THE pleasure of your company is requested in a new age of informality. Do not bother to R.S.V.P. Do not get done up in black tie. The mood just now is one of casualness in dress, in manners, on all fronts.

title: Brown Trounces Clinton in Caucuses in Vermont
description: Former Gov. Edmund G. Brown Jr. of California finished an easy first today in Vermont's Democratic Presidential caucuses, his anti-establishment message drowning out the more conventional voice of Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Today Is the Day Truckers Face Tougher Rules
description: Starting today, the nation's 4.5 million truck and bus drivers must have a new license to stay on the road in all 50 states, a move aimed at keeping track of violations and weeding out the unsafe drivers.

title: L&N Housing reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dime Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included federal income tax charge of $ 1.6 million relating to net operating loss carryforward.

title: Oscar Won by Documentary Gives G.E. Boycotters a Lift
description: Organizers of an effort to boycott products of the General Electric Company because of its involvment in the nuclear weapons business said yesterday that they had received a big lift on Monday night when "Deadly Deception," a film about the subject, won an Oscar for best documentary short subject.

title: Oilgear Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
After 16 Years as President of Tufts, Scientist Counts His Achievements
description: When Jean Mayer became president of Tufts University in 1976 it had never had a capital fund-raising campaign, and university administrators counseled him to limit a drive he was planning to $14 million. "Nonsense," Dr. Mayer said. "Let's make it $140 million."

title: Sequa Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 15.5 million in the quarter and $ 21,609,000 in the year.c-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 40,057,000 in the quarter and $ 26,702,000 in the year.d-Net incomeYear-ago periods' results were restated for discontinued operations.

title: The Debate On Insurance Rages On In Trenton
description: Tapping into the public's anger over high car-insurance rates, Jim Florio made auto insurance reform one of the major themes of his successful campaign for governor in 1989.

title: Can Ninja Turtle Owner Rescue Orion Pictures?
description: Billy Crystal, the host of the Academy Awards, summed up the financial plight of Orion Pictures on Monday evening when he joked that the company, whose bankruptcy has coincided with a string of Oscars, "can't afford another hit."

title: Gosta Oldenburg; Retired Diplomat, 98
description: Gosta Oldenburg, the Swedish Consul General and Dean of the Consular Corps in Chicago until his retirement in 1959, died last Tuesday at New York Hospital. He was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan in recent years.

title: Gotti Judge in Control From Start
description: Even before the trial of John Gotti began, the rulings of Judge I. Leo Glasser have had a significant impact on the case. He disqualified Mr. Gotti's longtime lawyer, Bruce Cutler, last July, because the lawyer participated in taped conversations that were part of the prosecution's evidence.

title: Sanctions on Libya Likely To Fuel Qaddafi's Chaos
description: The United Nations sanctions imposed on Libya today appear likely to worsen the indecision and disorganization that are already hallmarks of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi's 23-year rule.

title: Quarterly Loss at HomeFed
description: The HomeFed Corporation said today that it had lost $35.6 million in the fourth quarter of 1991 and that it had not met a deadline set by Federal regulators to strengthen its financial condition.

title: Same Old Dinner, Same Old Lunch: Most People Like It That Way
description: ROBIN SIMONS figures that there are nearly 100 restaurants within walking distance of her office in downtown Seattle. But every weekday, she goes to the same restaurant and orders an oat bran muffin and a cup of coffee for breakfast. On weekends, she feels bereft without her regular muffin. "If I have an excuse to be out and about," she said, "I'll go to that restaurant and get one."

title: High Salaries for Public Health
description: New York City lacks a president for its beleaguered public hospital system and New York State lacks a health commissioner. One big reason is reluctance to pay the high salaries needed to attract top candidates. That's dangerously penny-wise and pound-foolish.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Borg Struggles Before Defeating Svensson Bjorn Borg, resuming a comeback he started a year ago, struggled before beating a fellow Swede, Peter Svensson, 6-2, 6-7 (3-7), 6-3, yesterday in a first-round match of the River Oaks International tournament in Houston. "I was satisfied with the match," said the 35-year-old Borg, who won 11 Grand Slam events, including five consecutive Wimbledon titles, before retiring in 1981. "Maybe he doesn't hit as hard as he used to but I think he'll improve as he plays more," Svensson said. Borg reached the finals of the River Oaks tournament in 1974 as a 17-year-old, losing in the title match to Rod Laver. (AP) Fernandez Is Upset: After torrential rains washed out most of the first-day matches, the sun broke through at the Family Circle Cup in Hilton Head Island, S.C., yesterday and seven of the nine seeded players advanced. But Gigi Fernandez, seeded ninth, was upset by unseeded Silke Frankl of Germany, ranked 115th in the world. Fernandez saved two set points in the first set. But she won only three games the rest of the way in losing by 6-7 (7-9), 6-2, 6-1. Conchita Martinez of Spain, seeded fifth, defeated Mary Lou Daniels, 6-0, 6-2. Gabriela Sabatini, seeded first, and Martina Navratilova, seeded second, in the $550,000 tournament, begin play today. (AP) Lendl Advances: Top-seeded Ivan Lendl advanced yesterday to the second round of the Estoril Open in Lisbon, when Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands retired in the second set. The rain-interrupted match was about to start again after Lendl won the first set, 7-5. But Koevermans stopped playing after hearing the news of his grandmother's death. (AP) BOXING Ioka Defeats Tunacao and Retains Title Hiroki Ioka of Japan outpointed the Filipino challenger, Noel Tunacao, in a unanimous decision yesterday to retain his World Boxing Association junior flyweight title. There were no knockdowns in the 12-round bout at Kitakyushu Municipal Sogo Gym in Japan. Ioka improved his record to 20-2-1 with nine knockouts. Tunacao is 18-1-1 with eight knockouts. (AP) N.H.L. Jennings Leads Penguins Past Flyers Grant Jennings matched his season output by scoring two goals last night as the Pittsburgh Penguins, playing at home, facing a possible strike that could keep them from defending their Stanley Cup title, defeated the Philadelphia Flyers, 6-5. Jennings's second goal with 5:39 remaining broke a 5-5 tie and gave the Penguins 85 points, pulling the Penguins into a third-place tie with the Devils. Mario Lemieux added a goal and assisted on three others, raising his league-leading point total to 132. He scored unassisted on a power play at 7:33 of the third period to break a 4-4 tie, extending his point-scoring streak to 13 games. (AP) Red Wings 3, Blackhawks 3: Shawn Burr's goal with 2:35 remaining in regulation time capped a 93-second scoring spree and gave Detroit a tie with the visiting Blackhawks. Burr tipped Sergei Fedorov's slap shot over Ed Belfour's shoulder for his 19th goal and the third in a 1:33 span. Fedorov had given the Wings a 2-1 lead midway through the third, but Chicago went ahead on goals one minute apart by Mike Peluso and Steve Larmer. (AP) Bruins 5, Nordiques 4: Adam Oates scored two goals and assisted on the winner by Brent Hughes with 36 seconds left in overtime as Boston beat visiting Quebec. The goal was the first of the season for Hughes, obtained by Boston from the Washington Capitals on Feb. 24. Defenseman Curtis Leschyshyn had two goals for the Nordiques. (AP) North Stars 5, Sabres 3: Minnesota's Ulf Dahlen and Mike Craig each squeezed two goals into a game filled with fights as Minnesota and Buffalo combined for 360 penalty minutes at Bloomington, Minn. Craig broke a 3-3 tie at 16:42 of the third period, then added an insurance goal in the final minute as the Stars recovered after losing a 3-1 lead to end a five-game losing streak. (AP)

title: Seville Puts Acts For Expo At 55,000
description: More than 55,000 performances and events, including a new opera by Laurie Anderson and appearances by the Metropolitan Opera, the Berlin Philharmonic, the Martha Graham Dance Company, Dizzy Gillespie and Ryuichi Sakamoto, a Japanese pop composer, will be presented at Expo '92, the Seville World's Fair. Officially called the 1992 Seville Universal Exposition, it opens on April 20 and runs through Oct. 12.

title: Port Authority Forecasts a Loss of 200,000 Jobs
description: In their annual economic forecast released yesterday, officials at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey said they expected the region to lose another 200,000 jobs in 1992 before a mild recovery settled in in 1993. That bleak forecast comes on top of the 495,000 jobs that have already been lost in the region over the last two years.

title: Resolution on Libya Embargo: Barring Takeoff and Landing 'to Any Aircraft'
description: Following is the text of the Security Council resolution adopted today imposing air and arms embargoes against Libya and reducing the size of Libyan missions abroad. The vote was 10 in favor, none opposed and five abstentions from China, Cape Verde, India, Morocco and Zimbabwe.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY A CHANGING OF THE GUARD

title: House S.& L. Proposal Has No New Financing
description: Unable to persuade a majority of the House to support a bill authorizing another $25 billion for the sale of savings and loan institutions taken over by the Government, the top Democrat and Republican on the Banking Committee introduced a much more modest bill this afternoon.

title: Issues in N.H.L. Labor Face-Off
description: Free Agency

title: Market Place; Seeking a Cure For Ailing Shares
description: REGENERON PHARMACEUTICALS began its life as a public company on a very sour note. Almost alone among biotechnology stocks, its share price collapsed soon after the initial public offering last April.

title: Figuring Out the Russian Consumer
description: Though Russia resembles a consumer society about as much as Moscow resembles Muskogee, Western marketers are focusing on demographics, seeking to penetrate the psyche of a country that Winston Churchill called a riddle wrapped in a mystery inside an enigma.

title: Episcopal Bishop Criticizes Catholic Church
description: The Episcopal Bishop of Newark yesterday attacked the policies of the Roman Catholic Church with regard to women and homosexuals, calling the church repressive, patriarchical, prejudiced, hypocritical and "in danger of losing its soul."

title: Indicators Up Again, By 0.8%
description: The Government's chief forecasting gauge advanced eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, a second straight rise that left little doubt that economic recovery, although probably not robust, was taking hold.

title: Heinz May Shut More Factories
description: The H. J. Heinz Company said it might close as many as six more plants in the year beginning May 1 in a plan to trim costs by $100 million. Plants connected to the company's branded food divisions are the least likely to be affected, said a company spokeswoman, Debora Foster, who declined to be more specific. Heinz, based in Pittsburgh, recently closed five plants.

title: Harriet Mandelbaum, Children's Lobbyist, 79
description: Harriet Mandelbaum, who spent decades of her life working in behalf of autistic and other mentally impaired children, died on Thursday at Caledonian Hospital in Brooklyn. She was 79 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Stocks Rise, Then Fall As the Dow Closes Flat
description: Stocks closed yesterday pretty much as they ended the first quarter of this year, weakening at the end after a very promising start. The Dow Jones industrial average closed at 3,235.47, up 0.23 point on the day, and 66.64 points, or 2.1 percent, for the quarter.

title: Koo Koo Roo Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said fiscal 1990 results are for the 10 months ended Dec. 31.The company also said equivalent amounts for the three months ended Dec. 31, 1990 are not available due to a change in fiscal year-end in 1990 from Feb. 28 to Dec. 31.

The Pop Life
description: The two long-awaited new albums by Bruce Springsteen, "Human Touch" and "Lucky Town" (Columbia), officially went on sale across the country at 12:01 A.M. yesterday, and record stores that stayed open for the event reported scenes ranging from midnight madness to something akin to tales from the crypt.

title: Behind the Counter; Learning Hard Lessons at the Mall
description: Janice V. Matte does not complain, except to mention that if her husband still had his management job, she would probably be at home tending her garden on their two acres in Redding.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Greiner Engineering, Irving, Tex., agreed to form a partnership with an affiliate of the Perot Group, Dallas, to plan, finance, build and operate transportation projects. * Kansas Power and Light Co., Topeka, Kan., and Kansas Gas and Electric Co., Wichita, Kan., completed their merger. Kansas Gas is now a wholly owned subsidiary of Kansas Power.

title: Youth Sought In 5 Slayings Is Arrested
description: The search for the suspect in the killings of five people in Queens ended yesterday 300 miles away in Rochester where a teen-ager was arrested in the slayings of three more people in a local crack house, the police said.

title: Penny-Pinching Submarine Warfare to Death; Recipe for Victory
description: To the Editor:

title: Sears Plans To Cut 2,000 More Jobs
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said yesterday that it would eliminate 2,000 more jobs by early next year. The retailer said the move would save $30 million this year and $80 million annually thereafter.

title: Review/Television; A Very Different Oscars Broadcast
description: "Young, beautiful and talented -- a winning combination in any league: Daryl Hannah!" exclaimed the off-camera announcer at Monday night's 64th annual Academy Awards presentation. "Everybody's definition of class: Academy Award winner Audrey Hepburn!" "Three of Hollywood's most respected citizens: Steven Spielberg, George Lucas and Geena Davis!" Apparently nobody had notified the announcer, who provided virtually the only touches of old-style Hollywood hokum, that the game would be played a little differently this time.

title: In Surprise, Race Issue Is Raised in Beating Trial
description: A prosecutor today unexpectedly introduced the issue of race at the Rodney G. King beating trial, accusing one of four white Los Angeles police officers charged with assaulting Mr. King with referring to black people as gorillas.

title: It Was Libya, U.S. Insists. Syria? Iran? Probably Not.
description: United States investigators insist that the evidence in the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 points so far to Libya, and only Libya.

title: Jud Stern Wed To Yifat Cohen
description: Yifat Cohen, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rachamin Cohen of Tel Aviv, was married yesterday to Dr. Jud Marshal Stern, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Stern of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Eliezer Weiss officiated at the Great Synagogue in Jerusalem.

title: New Coach at Oregon
description: JERRY GREEN, assistant coach at Kansas for the last four seasons, was named head basketball coach at Oregon yesterday. Green, 49 years old, was previously head coach at North Carolina-Asheville, where he was 150-108 in nine seasons. He was the No. 1 assistant to ROY WILLIAMS at Kansas and was among the Jayhawks' chief recruiters. Green succeeds DON MONSON, 58, dismissed March 18 after Oregon finished the season 6-21, the Ducks' worst record in 21 years. (AP)

Moss; sets by James E. Morgan; costumes, Michael Bottari and Ronald Case; lighting, Stuart Duke; technical director, John Miller; production stage manager, Alan Fox; musical director, Leo P. Carusone; choreographer, Barbara Siman. Presented by the York Theater Company, Janet Hayes Walker, producing director; Molly Pickering Grose, managing director, in association with One World Arts Foundation. title: Cellular Communications reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results not comparable to 1991 results.The company said on Aug. 1, 1991 it formed a joint venture equally owned by Cellular Communications' and Pactel, comprised of Cellular Communications' cellular telephone interests in Ohio and Pactel's cellular telephone interests in Michigan and Ohio.The company incurred $ 8,360,000 of special legal, accounting, financial advisory, printing and registration fees relative to the merger agreement during 1991.During 1991, Cellular Communications recognized an extraordinary loss of $ 2,405,000 from the write-off of deferred financing costs due to the early extinguishment of its old loan agreement.

title: With Song in His Heart, Noah Quits Davis Cup
description: When YANNICK NOAH announced yesterday that he was resigning as the nonplaying captain of the French Davis Cup team, it wasn't because -- as it might appear -- of France's stunning quarterfinal loss to lowly Switzerland over the weekend. He retired because tennis is simply no longer his primary interest.

title: A Family's Odyssey Brings a Taste of Cambodia to Boston
description: COMBINE "Miss Saigon" with "The Killing Fields" and you have a sense of the lives led by Longteine De Monteiro, her husband, Kenthao, their daughter Nadsa and her husband, Bob Perry. It took Nadsa and Bob seven years to find each other, and her parents 15 to make it from Cambodia to America and open a restaurant.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about Bill Clinton's record as governor of Arkansas misstated his salary. It is $35,000 a year. A proposal to increase it to $60,000, and to raise the salaries of other state officials has been approved by the state Legislature and the Governor. It will be put to the voters on a ballot in November.

title: Record Prices at Christie's For Japanese Swords
description: Buyers -- most of them Japanese -- paid record prices yesterday at Christie's in New York for swords and fittings collected by an Indiana physician and businessman. The first day's sale of the Japanese sword collection of Dr. Walter Ames Compton, described by the auction house as the most important ever held in the West, totaled $8 million, a record figure for a sale of Japanese works and within the auction house's expectations of $7 million to $10 million.

Offshore Threat -- Cruise Missiles
description: President Bush has requested more than $5 billion for "Star Wars" ballistic missile defenses for the 1993 fiscal year. The U.S. will spend $4.1 billion for such defenses in the current fiscal year. The military preparedness this money is supposed to buy does not address the most probable and serious threat we face -- highly accurate cruise missiles that cannot be stopped and can be guided to targets by technology that is available to anyone. Such a terrorists' target could be the joint session of Congress during the President's State of the Union Address.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration yesterday in Science Times showing the Earth's interior misstated the depth of the liquid core lying between the solid core and the mantle. It is 1,400 miles, not 4,580 miles; thus the Earth's diameter is about 7,920 miles.

description: President Boris N. Yeltsin traversed an important stage toward political stability in the vast Russian Federation today when 18 of its 20 main subdivisions signed a federal treaty that forms the basis of a new post-Soviet state.

title: House Rejects a Proposal to Shift Military Money to Social Programs
description: The House today decisively rejected a Democratic budget plan that would have shifted more than $6 billion in military savings to social programs next year by breaking the 1990 budget agreement between Congress and the White House.

title: Topics of The Times; Silent Night, Oscar Night
description: On Oscar night the phones are stilled, the streets are quiet and the sound of America is the sound of Billy Crystal against the sounds of popcorn disappearing, refrigerator doors opening and of incessant commentary. "Check that dress!" and "Check that hairdo!" and "Check that chest!" And, yes, the occasional snore.

description: Avon Products Inc. yesterday named Walker Lewis president of its domestic direct selling business and executive vice president of the company.

description: Advertising these days is replete with images of people who have abandoned the carefree materialism associated with the 1980's and have ostensibly adopted practical, "back-to-basics" values. But one retail advertiser is longing for an 80's revival.

title: Supreme Court Upholds Method Used in Apportionment of House
description: In a decision that dashed Montana's hope of retaining two seats in the House of Representatives, the Supreme Court today upheld the constitutionality of the method Congress has used for 50 years to apportion seats among the states.

title: Betty Ourisman; Philanthropist, 66
description: Betty Lou Haydnet Ourisman, a former board member of the Arena Stage and Ford's Theater in Washington, who was long active in philanthrophic and cultural organizations in the capital area, died yesterday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. She was 66 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: CHRONICLE
description: KITTY CARLISLE HART was appearing in her first Broadway show, "Champagne Sec," when the orchestra's pianist announced to her, "Someday I will write the best musical on Broadway."

title: Chrysler Opens Plant, Makes a Point
description: The Chrysler Corporation officially opened its Jefferson Avenue North plant today in the heart of this depressed city, bucking the conventional wisdom of the auto industry.

title: Freeing the Innocent From Behind Bars Is Centurions' Mission
description: James McCloskey gets hundreds of letters from prisoners who insist they are innocent, so he tries to get an early sense from each one of its possible merit. The letter from Clarence Chance, who wrote from California that he had been in jail at the time of the murder for which he was given a life sentence, got Mr. McCloskey's attention.

title: Topics of The Times; Coeducation, Then and Now
description: In the wake of Women's History Month, the feminist movement has a bicentennial to celebrate. Two hundred years ago, in 1792, "Vindication of the Rights of Woman" was published. It was written by Mary Wollstonecraft, a British product of the free-thinking 18th century that culminated in the American and French Revolutions.

title: Sprint Offers Liability Limit For Corporate Phone Fraud
description: The Sprint Communications Company, the nation's third-largest long-distance carrier, said today that it would limit the liability of large corporate customers for the huge bills rung up by phone-service thieves who manipulate a company's telephone switching equipment and voice-mail systems.

title: New Sign of Recovery
description: The latest statistics indicate that the economic recovery in the United States is taking hold. The Government's chief forecasting gauge rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in February, its second straight rise.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The benefit on April 9 for the East Harlem Tutorial Program is formally billed as "an evening of readings and song," but CALVIN TRILLIN prefers to think of it as the "First Real Poets' Read-Off."

title: Review/Television; The Last Days of 'Edge' on PBS
description: If you haven't yet caught "Edge," public television's monthly pop-culture magazine, try doing it tonight at 9 on Channel 13. There's not much time left. A co-production of WNET and the BBC, "Edge" will have only one more show to go, on May 13, and then it's electronic-graveyard time. Life on public television, never easy, seems to be getting almost impossible these days.

title: International Talks on Steel Trade Break Down
description: Negotiations broke down today at talks on a 36-nation agreement to limit government subsidies to steel companies, but the Bush Administration said it would allow 10-year-old United States restrictions on steel imports to expire tonight anyway.

title: Literally Entranced by Television, Children Metabolize More Slowly
description: WHY are children who watch a lot of television fatter on average than those whose viewing habits are more limited? Is it because television watching substitutes for exercise, or because television advertisements entice children to eat high-calorie foods, or because children snack more when in front of the set? Or is it simply that children who are fat would rather watch television than, say, play rough-and-tumble games with their friends?

title: Court Victory Hailed in District That Won Desegregation Case
description: For many black and white residents of DeKalb County, the Supreme Court decision today on the school system's progress in eliminating racial discrimination and inequities brought a sense of relief that they need not anticipate extensive busing programs or transfers of their children in the next school year.

title: Fate Gets Ready to Play Another Trick on the Rangers
description: If a strike does not ruin these Stanley Cup playoffs for the Rangers, then it will be something else. Something outrageous, and cruel.

title: Pittway May Sell BRK, First Alert
description: The Pittway Corporation said it had retained Morgan Stanley & Company to advise it on options concerning its First Alert and BRK Electronics divisions, including a possible sale of both units to an outside buyer.

title: J.& J. Planning A Stock Buyback
description: Johnson & Johnson said it planned to buy back up to $500 million worth of its common stock. The health-care company will buy the stock in the open market over the next few months. The transactions will be made through Salomon Brothers.

title: Bridge
description: When a major knockout team event is played at a national championship, The Daily Bulletin invariably carries predictions by "The Hog." This famous pundit was confounded at the Vanderbilt Knockout in Pasadena, Calif., last week by a string of surprising results that eliminated six of the top eight seeded teams before the semifinal stage.

title: Where Adventure Shapes the Menu
description: LET the faint of stomach get their food kicks from the season's first shad roe or soft-shelled crabs. Let them chart vicarious adventure by tasting blackened alligator tail or sea urchin mousse at the very best restaurants. To members of the Explorers Club, this is lite adventure.

title: If Budget Won't Bend, Perhaps Calendar Will
description: For months, lawmakers looked toward April 1 with Cinderella-like dread, fearing that if they missed the state budget deadline at midnight tonight, their careers would turn into the political equivalent of pumpkins.

title: U.S. GAINS PLEDGE ON EX-SOVIET ARMS
description: The former Soviet republics with battlefield nuclear weapons told the United States today that all of the weapons would be transferred to Russia by July 1, senior Defense Department officials said.

A Fast Learner From California
description: Standing in his stall, his brown coat tucked neat and smooth like a chiseled athlete, A.P. Indy looked like a million dollars.

title: Review/Art; Eakins Artifacts Give Context To Works in Philadelphia Show
description: When the American painter Thomas Eakins resigned from his teaching position at the Pennsylvania Academy of the Fine Arts on Feb. 9, 1886, he did so under duress. His students accused him of moral impropriety. The crisis was precipitated when he removed the loincloth from a male model in a class of female students, but the scandal was only the climax of longstanding disapproval of Eakins's insistence on rendering the nude human form from life.

title: Nuggets Lose Mutombo
description: Rookie DIKEMBE MUTOMBO will miss the Nuggets' 10 remaining games because of a left thumb injury, the Denver Nuggets said yesterday. Mutombo, who has a torn ligament in his left thumb that he incurred against Phoenix last Saturday, was placed on the injured list. The Nuggets activated STEVE SCHEFFLER to take the center's place. (AP)

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Clinton's Roots Trip Him in New York
description: History is riddled with the stories of Southerners who fled their native region and found glory in New York City. They were writers and actors, musicians and journalists, people from every walk of life -- except, perhaps, Presidential contenders. For them, the rite of passage has been hard in recent years.

title: Noj Journal; Just Smashing Communism (Got Carried Away)
description: The farmhouses of this dirt-poor village near the bottom of one of the deep gorges that cut through the mountains north of Tirana, the capital, encircle shattered buildings, piles of rubble, exposed cement floors that serve no purpose anymore and neat stacks of building blocks and roof tiles.

title: Iran-Contra Prosecutors Question General Powell
description: Iran-contra prosecutors have interviewed senior Pentagon officials from the Reagan Administration in recent weeks, examining for the first time the role of the military in the affair, Government officials with knowledge of the meetings said today.

title: 48 Charged in Garment District Arson Ring
description: Forty-eight people, including several independent insurance brokers, claims adjustors and businessmen in the Garment District in Manhattan, were arrested yesterday and charged with running what the District Attorney called one of the nation's largest full-service, arson-for-profit rings.

description: The Senate voted overwhelmingly today to allow Federal financing of tissue transplants using cells from aborted fetuses.

title: Economic Scene; The Great Search: A Perfect Tax
description: ARE Americans ready for another sweeping overhaul of taxes -- something, perhaps, like Jerry Brown's flat tax? The answer may not matter much to candidate Brown, who needs recognition as a champion of change far more than he needs a practical plan for cutting the Gordian tax knot. Indeed, Mr. Brown's campaign staff has conceded as much: "The nuts and bolts" of the flat tax, said a Brown campaign spokesman, "are still to be determined."

Chung impassively enters a similar, if almost empty, courtroom two floors below. To prosecutors and criminologists, this is like the changing of the underworld guard.

title: Insurance Futures Backed
description: Federal regulators today approved plans for trading futures contracts tied to health-care and homeowner insurance risks.

title: Review/Music; Medieval Interactions Of Christians and Jews In Melody and Text
description: The politics of cultural interaction have become so heated in recent years, the demands for cultural recognition so confrontational, that the portrayal of cultural influence and imitation in Sunday night's concert by the Boston Camerata at Merkin Concert Hall seemed almost pastoral. The program, titled "The Sacred Bridge," explored the connections between medieval Judaism and Christianity, the ways in which melodies and text emigrated from one religious world to the other. Arab culture was also included in the confluences of artistry and belief, in selections from medieval Spain. The interactions seemed to have the natural ease of streams running together; they provided uncanny glimpses of the evolution of religious culture in the West.

description: For decades, becoming a partner in a law or accounting firm was almost better than getting tenure at a university. The promotion guaranteed job security, prestige and a large, steady income.

title: Computer Tests Pump More Miles Into Tires
description: Tire makers have devoted considerable research over the years toward producing a tire that would last longer than what had been the industry standard of about 50,000 miles. In what may become the new standard, Groupe Michelin S.A. of France, at its research center in Greenville, S.C., recently introduced a tire backed by an 80,000-mile warranty.

title: Judge Rejects Parents' Plan to Take Over School
description: A New York State Supreme Court judge today rejected a proposal by a group of parents, alumni and teachers who sought to take over control of an exclusive century-old parochial school that the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island closed last year.

title: Simms to Return to Giants After Bucs Sign DeBerg
description: Phil Simms's last hope for a trade disappeared last night when the Tampa Bay Buccaneers signed 38-year-old Steve DeBerg, starting his 16th season as a National Football League quarterback. It means that Simms, who will turn 37 this season, will return to the Giants as the backup quarterback behind Jeff Hostetler, who was his backup until last year.

title: Blood Taken From One Met
description: Lieut. Dwight Hart of the Port St. Lucie Police Department said tonight that a blood sample had been obtained on Monday evening from one of the three Mets accused of rape by a New York woman. The officer also said that the woman, who says she was raped here in March 1991, had been interviewed for more than five hours today in an effort "to clarify certain facts that had been discovered by detectives during the course of the investigation."

title: Rumors Hit Alexander's
description: Shares of Alexander's Inc., the embattled New York retailer, tumbled yesterday as rumors that the company was preparing to file for bankruptcy protection traveled around the garment industry. Roanne Kulakoff, a spokeswoman for Alexander's, said the company would not comment on speculation.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Record; Despite Improvements, the Schools In Arkansas Are Still Among Worst

title: Action Seen By Manville
description: The Manville Corporation is likely to announce a public offering of shares in the Riverwood International Corporation, its packaging subsidiary, within the next few weeks.

title: Leaders in Albany Settle Disputes In Rush to Meet Budget Deadline
description: Using a time-honored method for closing a budget deal, state leaders on Tuesday produced more money for schools and for New York City with an array of last-minute fiscal maneuvers that all but guaranteed the swift conclusion of marathon budget negotiations.

title: Call Him Sgt. Tomba
description: If ALBERTO TOMBA continues to ski with such masterly results, it may not be long before Italy crowns him the commander of the country's military elite. For the second time in two Olympiads, the 25-year-old Tomba has been awarded a promotion in rank in the Carabinieri, the Italian paramilitary police. You may call him Sergeant Tomba now.

title: Serb and Croat Asking to Confer With Bush
description: President Slobodan Milosevic of Serbia and President Franjo Tudjman of Croatia, the principal antagonists in the Yugoslav civil war, are separately seeking meetings with President Bush, Administration officials said today.

title: Manville Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time, after-tax charge of $ 173,398,000 from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for post-retirement benefits other than pensions, in the quarter and year; the year also included income from discontinued operations of $ 4,290,000, or 4 cents a share, a gain of $ 13,512,000, or 11 cents a share, on disposal of discontinued operations, and an after-tax gain of $ 220,795,000, or $ 1.83 a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.c-Net incomed-After income from discontinued operations of $ 4,607,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 15,983,000, or 13 cents a share, in the year, and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $ 6,437,000, or 5 cents a share, in the both periods.The latest periods included losses from restructuring of operations of $ 28,005,000 in the quarter and $ 64,148,000 in the year, compared with $ 37,681,000 and $ 26,731,000 in the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE annual migration of shad to rivers in the East is reaching its peak, which means that one of spring's delicacies, shad roe, is abundant.

title: Socanav Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Net incomec-After losses from discontinued operations of $ 200,000 in the quarter and $ 4.2 million in the 6 months.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Telemundo Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time charge of $ 238,484,000 from a writeoff of goodwill in the quarter and year; the year also included a gain of $ 1,045,000, or 3 cents a share, for the retirement of debt.c-Net incomed-Included extraordinary gains of $ 22,220,000, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 25,871,000, or 76 cents a share, in the year, both related to the early redemption of long-term indebtedness.

title: Excerpts From Court Ruling to Lift Curbs on Formerly Segregated Schools
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today in Freeman v. Pitts, providing standards for the termination of Federal Court control of formerly segregated school districts. The vote was 8 to 0. Justice Anthony M. Kennedy wrote the majority opinion, which was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Byron R. White, Antonin Scalia and David H. Souter. Justices Scalia and Souter also wrote concurring opinions. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote an opinion concurring in the judgment, which Justices Sandra Day O'Connor and John Paul Stevens joined. Justices Clarence Thomas did not vote in the case, which was argued before he joined the Court. JUSTICE KENNEDY For the Court.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 I.M.F. BACKS RUSSIAN AID PLAN

title: WINE TALK
description: "IT'S out here somewhere," the driver said, peering through the rain at the muddy dirt road. All we could see, except for the downs undulating off into the early spring mist, were fat Herefords gazing impassively at the sight of a taxi pretending to be a Land Rover.

title: First City Trustco reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 160,700,000 for the latest year and $ 43,000,000 for the 1990 year.The company said the losses from discontinued operations included operating losses by First City Trust Co. and a provision for loss on the expected disposition of the company's interest in First City Trust Co.Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Urban Problems; Democratic Foes Harmonize On Need to Give Aid to Cities
description: Facing mayors for a dialogue on urban problems, and then each other in a debate on the same topic in the Bronx, the Democratic Presidential contenders expressed broad agreement yesterday that cities needed more help from Washington, which, each said, he would deliver as President.

title: Integrated Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included a nonrecurring merger-related noncash charge of $ 11,840,000. Without this charge, net income for fiscal 1992 would have been $ 4,416,000.c-Net incomeLatest figures included the results of Software Components Group Inc., acquired in August 1991.

title: New Campaigns
description: * O. J. Simpson, longtime spokesman for Hertz, has returned in new advertising by Wells Rich Greene BDDP,New York, for Hertz's frequent-renter program, the No. 1 Gold Club. To demonstrate its advantages, he strolls, rather than rushes, through an airport, urging renters to "beat the rush hour." Mr. Simpson, who has been under contract to Hertz since 1975, last appeared in the company's ads in 1989.

title: Mylex Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Bias Attack Is Reported in Crown Heights
description: A Hasidic man was attacked last night by a group of black youths on a street in Crown Heights, Brooklyn, and the police have classified the attack as bias related.

title: Elsinore Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary tax benefit of $ 807,000, or 7 cents a share.

title: Ambiguity Remains After Decision
description: In its ruling yesterday on a major school desegregation case, the Supreme Court could have set broad new guidelines or sharply curtailed existing remedies. Instead, the Court left many of those crucial judgments up to lower courts, and left legal experts guessing about what the impact of its latest ruling will be.

title: Furr's/Bishop's Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 28
description: b-Included a charge of $ 12.9 million for the write-down of assets related to certain restaurants and charges related to debt restructuring, organizational restructuring and certain potential tax and other liabilities.c-Included $ 15.2 million in special charges related to asset write-downs and other costs.Year-ago figures are restated to reflect the results of operations of Furr's/Bishop's Cafeterias L.P. and its operating units as combined entities.

title: Turks Got Tanks, and German Minister Must Quit
description: The German Defense Minister and his top aide resigned today after a scandal over arms shipments to Turkey.

title: Charter Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of $ 5,171,000 related to the closing of the company's Perth, Ontario, production facility and the consolidation of its operations into its six remaining facilitites.c-Net income

title: Acquisition by Digital Reinforces Role of PC
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it had acquired 800 Software Inc., a personal- computer software distributor in Berkeley, Calif. The acquisition is another indication of Digital's commitment to becoming a large player in the direct-mail personal computer business.

title: Hall Financial Group Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the loss in the latest year was largely due to taking an additional $ 35.7 million reserve against partnership receivables and $ 4.5 million reserve on investments in limited partnerships, compared with a $ 10.4 million reserve taken during 1990.

title: Japan Lowers Its Discount Rate to 3.75%
description: The Bank of Japan today lowered an important lending rate by three-quarters of a point, a day after the Government announced a package of measures to stimulate the sagging economy.

title: In Fight Over Privileges, Spotlight's Now on Bush
description: Jockeying for advantage over a volatile issue that threatens both parties, the White House and Congressional Democrats battled today over the perquisites and privileges of the capital's political elite, especially subsidized travel.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; Cuomo's Freudian Slips: Desire, or Just Fatigue?
description: Mario Cuomo's Freudian slip has been showing again.

title: Ralph E. Shikes Is Dead at 79; Publisher, Editor and Art Writer
description: Ralph E. Shikes, a publisher, an editor and the author of several books on art, died on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 79 years old and had homes in Manhattan and Lakeville, Conn.

title: Amstar Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 20,182,000 for the latest year and $ 3,032,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Double Trouble for the Kurds
description: When Iraq's powerful, modern army wages high-tech war against overmatched Kurdish guerrillas, killing and uprooting innocent civilian populations, Americans know what to call it. Ugly repression, verging perhaps on genocide.

title: Comcoa Inc. reports earnings for Year to Jan 26
description: b-Included a gain of $ 305,697 on a tax credit.

title: Deliberations Set to Start In Gotti's Rackets Trial
description: The jury in John Gotti's racketeering-murder trial is to begin deliberations this morning, after the judge excused one juror from the case yesterday and then gave the remaining panel members their final instructions.

title: Justices Ease Court Controls In School Desegregation Case
description: Ruling in a major school desegregation case, the Supreme Court today gave hundreds of formerly segregated school districts a potential new legal tool for returning to local control after decades of operating under Federal court supervision.

title: General Nutrition Inc. reports earnings for Year to Feb 1
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 55,000 for the latest year and $ 1,640,000 for the year-earlier period, and an extraordinary credit of $ 182,000 and $ 6,375,000 for the latest year and year-earlier period, respectively.The company is wholly owned subsidiary of General Nutrition Cos.

title: Knicks Once Again No Obstacle for Bulls
description: The Chicago Bulls remain an imposing obstacle the Knicks cannot conquer.

title:
Real Estate;
New Offices, Lower Rents Near Boston
description: A 450,000-square-foot building called the Framingham Corporate Center is giving companies in this western suburb of Boston an opportunity to move into newer office space at lower rents.

title: Pinelands Stock Falls 10.1% on Disney Deal
description: Stock in Pinelands Inc. fell 10.1 percent yesterday, as investors reacted unfavorably to the deal the company, which owns WWOR-TV Channel 9 in the New York area, made with the Walt Disney Company on Monday. Pinelands said it would buy KCAL-TV in Los Angeles from Disney, which, in turn, would get 45 percent of Pinelands.

title: Extra! Extra! British Editors Infuse Views Into the News!
description: When the Labor Party recently announced its economic game plan for Britain, should it win the general election on April 9, the entire front page of The Daily Mirror, a London tabloid, was given over to the story.

title: I.M.F. ENDORSES RUSSIAN PLAN FOR ECONOMY, CLEARING WAY FOR AID AND FOR MEMBERSHIP
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that it had endorsed Russia's economic reform plan, paving the way for Moscow to receive up to $4 billion in I.M.F. aid over the next year.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Poll; Clinton Dogged By Voter Doubt, Poll of U.S. Says
description: With only one Democratic opponent remaining on the field, Gov. Bill Clinton has gained the support of a bare majority of Democrats nationwide and his campaign continues to confront a cloud of doubts and reservations, according to the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll.

title: Food Notes
description: Brooklyn Tea Party

title: With These Words, Spain Banished Jews
description: Five hundred years ago today, King Ferdinand and Queen Isabella signed an edict expelling the Jews from Spain. They sought to justify the action by arguing that Jews continued to proselytize among former Jews who had converted to Christianity. Here are excerpts from the edict, as translated by The New York Times from the Spanish.

title: Prices of Treasury Issues Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading and interest rates were little changed yesterday, as most market participants waited for the start of the second quarter to take new positions.

title: Big Texas Bank Seeks a Buyer
description: The financially troubled First City Bancorporation of Texas said today that it hoped to find a buyer for the Houston-based banking company without requiring immediate aid from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Analysts were uncertain such a deal could work.

title: Therapy in Suicide Case Defended by Psychiatrist
description: A Harvard Medical School psychiatrist accused of seducing a patient and causing his suicide said today that her treatment of him was "somewhat unconventional." And she insisted that dozens of pages of her handwritten sexual fantasies that were found in his apartment had been obtained illegally when he broke into her office.

title: Move Against 47th St. Photo
description: A major creditor of 47th Street Photo Inc., the TransAmerica Commercial Finance Corporation, yesterday filed a motion to have the New York discount photo and electronics chain's Chapter 11 bankruptcy converted to a Chapter 7, which would liquidate the company.

title: Jones Intercable Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Honors
description: * New York Women in Communications will present awards to seven women at the 22d annual Matrix Awards ceremony in New York next Wednesday. Among them are Helayne Spivak, executive vice president and executive creative director of Young & Rubicam New York; Elizabeth P. Valk, publisher of Time magazine, and Lou Rena Hammond, president of Lou Hammond & Associates.

title: Ulster Catholic Hopes Vote Advances Peace
description: John Hume, viewed as the most effective Roman Catholic political leader in Northern Ireland, wants the British election campaign to be a referendum on the violence that has killed some 3,000 people in Ulster since 1969.

title: French Paradox
description: To The Living Section:

title: Envirosource Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 828,000 and $ 15,743,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary tax credit of $ 134,000 for the quarter and $ 873,000 for the year.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 4,478,000 for the quarter and year, which both included provision of $ 1.3 million for operating losses during phase-out period.c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 405,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Consumers Gain Back Some Confidence
description: Consumers turned markedly more optimistic in March. The Conference Board said yesterday that its consumer confidence index jumped to 54, from 47.3 in February, its biggest gain in a year.

title: 'Free' Macedonia Faces Hostile World
description: In the tumult that has destroyed Yugoslavia, Macedonia has defied its bitter history of conflict by remaining at peace.

title: Goals for Racial Inclusion Elude Latest Crop of Young Doctors
description: THE nation's new crop of physicians, 14,030 men and women, gathered last Wednesday at 137 medical schools for the anxious moment that would decide much of their future and also give an indication of the future character of American medicine.

title: Conner's 4th in a Row Gives Him Overall Lead
description: Dennis Conner, who last month looked as if he had lost his habit of winning America's Cup races, has rediscovered his old ways. Today, in the trials for prospective cup defenders, Conner's Stars & Stripes beat America3, one of Bill Koch's two contenders, by 45 seconds.

title: Prosecution Starts Closing Arguments in 7-Month-Old Noriega Trial
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was "nothing more than a corrupt, crooked and rotten cop" who eagerly "sold his uniform, his army and his protection to a murderous criminal gang called the Medellin cocaine cartel," a Federal prosecutor said today as closing arguments began in the seven-month trial of the deposed Panamanian leader.

title: Reading & Bates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 411,000 in the quarter and $ 2,156,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year; the year also included an extraordinary credit of $ 3,725,000, or 2 cents a share, from settlement of claim against Iranian National Oil Co., and an extraordinary charge of $ 18,860,000 from an adjustment in accounting.c-Net lossd-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,349,000, or 4 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 518,000, or 1 cent a share, in the year; the year also included an extraordinary credit of $ 2,899,000, or 8 cents a share, on early retirement of debt.

title: Hotel Investors reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said the table shows combined results of Hotel Investors Trust and Hotel Investors Corp. Their shares are paired and trade together on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Extended Pact for Craig
description: The San Francisco Giants yesterday gave Manager ROGER CRAIG a one-year contract extension through the 1993 season. Salary terms were not disclosed. Craig, 62 years old, has managed the Giants since September 1985, guiding the club to two National League West titles and a National League pennant in that time. Craig holds the San Francisco club marks for games managed (988) and victories (513). (AP)

title: Lilly Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
New Nissan Car Is Named Altima
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation said it would name its midsize sedan Altima when it is introduced this fall. The model will replace the Nissan Stanza, which was first introduced in 1981.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters; Many in the Bronx Say Candidates Aren't in Touch
description: The Democratic Presidential candidates took their campaign roadshow to the Bronx this week, for a debate on the problems of urban America. But for many who live in the heartland of urban America, it was as if the candidates had never been there at all.

title: Daily Telegraph Stock Offering
description: Hollinger Inc., owned by the Canadian financier Conrad Black, said today that it planned a public offering of shares in its Daily Telegraph unit, a major British newspaper.

title: Essay; Bush-Clinton Debate
description: President Bush and his likely Democratic challenger went back-to-back on CNN yesterday, and Gov. Bill Clinton came out standing a little taller.

title: E-Z Serve Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The results for 1990 were not previously reported, as the company was a wholly owned subsidiary of Harken Energy Corp. prior to May 1991.The shares outstanding in the 1990 periods were restated to give effect to a December 1990 recapitalization.

title: At Home Abroad; A Captive Press
description: The Sunday Times of London topped the front page some weeks ago with a banner headline: "Soviet files reveal Labor's private dialogue with Kremlin." Below it was a large picture of the Labor Party leader, Neil Kinnock, his head shown against a red background.

title: Football; N.F.L. Will Give Rebate to Networks
description: The National Football League owners found a compromise here today for their television brethren who say they are struggling to sell advertising in a soft marketplace: Each team will give back $1 million of the $41 million it will receive from the networks in 1993, and the 1992 N.F.L. regular season will be played over 17 weeks instead of the 18 weeks previously scheduled.

title: Itel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 5 million in the quarter and $ 46 million in the year, and an extraordinary charge of $ 100,000 and an extraordinary credit of $ 8.8 million, or 26 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $ 127.4 million, or $ 2.91 a share, in the quarter and $ 157.2 million, or $ 2.03 a share, in the year.The latest periods' losses from continuing operations included a $ 30 million loss on the sale of the company's stock position in Santa Fe Pacific Corp. and a $ 33 million loss from the revaluation of the company's remaining marketplace securities.

title: Times Bags to Be Recycled
description: Starting on Sunday, New York Times subscribers will be able to recycle the blue plastic bags in which their papers are delivered at all Grand Union supermarkets in the New York metropolitan area. Home-delivery customers can drop the bags, which are used to protect newspapers from water and dirt, in special bins at all Grand Union stores in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut. The bags will be combined with other plastics recycled at the stores, then sent to Webster Industries, a manufacturer of lawn and leaf bags.

title: INSIDE
description: French Premier Resigns

title: Interpharm Laboratories reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Texaco Ends a Sponsorship
description: The Texaco Company has decided to end its corporate underwriting of the public television series "Great Performances" at the end of this season, a spokeswoman for the oil company said yesterday.

title: Galvest Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net incomeThe company said the loss for the year is attributable to expenses associated with a merger that did not take place.

title: As the New York Vote Nears
description: Even as Gov. Bill Clinton has found himself forced to go head to head against Edmund G. Brown Jr. in daily debates, New Yorkers and the nation are pondering Mr. Brown's surprisingly strong Presidential bid and asking, who is this unconventional politician?

description: b-Net income

title: Bush Signs a $14.2 Billion Foreign Aid Bill
description: President Bush tonight signed a bill that extends foreign aid for six months. Earlier theSenate, resisting popular sentiment against such aid, approved the $14.2 billion measure but pared an Administration request for money for United Nations peacekeeping.

title: Baseball; Kamieniecki Leaves The Yankees Guessing
description: The uncertainty over the Yankee pitching staff continued today as Scott Kamieniecki did little to hurt, or truly help, his struggle with Greg Cadaret for the final berth in the starting rotation.

description: Kenny Drew Jr. The Blue Note

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Acton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its 1991 operating loss resulted primarily from $ 4,245,774 of writedowns to the carrying value of its real estate held for development and sale necessitated by the continuing decline in real estate markets, combined with writedowns of $ 10,863,884 of certain securities in its investment portfolio to reflect what Acton believed to be other than temporary declines in their value.The company also said losses for the latest quarter were primarily due to writedowns to the company's real estate held for development and sale, and writedowns of certain securities in its investment portfolio as described above.

title: Marlton Technologies reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossc-Included $ 1,718,321, or 51 cents a share, of cumulative non-operating gains on Marlton's sale of Audio Information Sciences Inc. stock.The company said that the fourth quarter of 1990 included several non-recurring transactions which significantly affected earnings, including severance arrangements with two former officers.

title: Ghost Houses Reflect Fading of Farm Life
description: It sits, fragile as a bird's nest, down a country road with no name. The old clapboard house has been abandoned for nearly 30 years, but some of the Svarc family spirit remains. Patches of red honeysuckle wallpaper cling to the walls, and the entrance to the old root cellar where the family stored milk and eggs in the days before refrigeration still stands in the backyard.

title: Where the English Country Look Is Still Man's Best Friend
description: WHILE many decorators have abandoned the English country-house look that once engulfed Fifth Avenue libraries, East Side studio apartments, Connecticut bedrooms -- even pool houses in the Hamptons -- in favor of a virtuous new minimalism, Josef V. Pricci has stuck to his idea of what the proper gentleman's home should look like.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Foreign Policy; Turning His Sights Overseas, Clinton Sees a Problem at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue
description: Gov. Bill Clinton accused President Bush yesterday of failing to articulate clear goals for American foreign policy after the cold war and outlined his own program for assisting Russia's transition to democracy.

title: Osborn Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $ 625,462, or 9 cents a share, on extinguishment of debt, net of tax.

title: Wendell Mayes, 72, Film and TV Writer
description: Wendell Mayes, who wrote the screenplays for "Anatomy of a Murder" and "Advise and Consent," died on Saturday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 72 years old and lived in Bel Air, Calif.

title: Port Agency Says Hoboken Owes Refund
description: A day after Hoboken voters, for the second time in two years, defeated a plan to redevelop the city's crumbling waterfront with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey as a partner, the bistate agency says it wants a refund of at least part of the $30 million it has spent on the project over the last decade.

title: Reliance Insurance Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $ 20,818,000 in the quarter and $ 29,913,000 in the year, and after extraordinary credits of $ 224,000 and $ 894,000 in the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $ 1,459,000 and after extraordinary credit of $ 6,408,000.d-Net income and included loss of $ 73,000 from discontinued operations and after extraordinary credit of $ 7,461,000.The company, which is the largest unit of Reliance Group Holdings Inc., said it has adopted the equity method of accounting for certain significant investments. Accordingly, th results from continuing operations in 1991 and 1990 included the company's equity in the results of Zenith National Insurance Corp., as well as Telemundo Group Inc., which has been written off.In addition, the company has consolidated the results of Frank B. Hall & Co. and, reflecting its decision to sell its stake in Hall, has classified it as a discontinued operation.

title: Buying Time for Yeltsin
description: The $24 billion in aid that President Bush and other leaders have promised Russia is not going to turn it into a prosperous nation overnight. But it does give President Boris N. Yeltsin something Mikhail S. Gorbachev never received: a major vote of confidence on his economic reforms.

title: 13 Companies Admit Guilt in False Coal Dust Tests
description: A three-year investigation of coal companies' tampering with equipment and falsifying tests to understate the amount of disease-causing coal dust in mine air has led to guilty pleas by 13 coal companies.

title: Lancer Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

description: b-After extraordinary credits of $ 8,835,000, or 15 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 114,256,000, or $ 2.40 a share, in the year, both from refinancing of long-term debt. The periods also included income from discontinued operations of $ 76,456,000, or $ 1.35 a share, and $ 44,367,000, or 93 cents a share, in the quarter and year, respectively.c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $ 7,607,000 in the quarter and $ 20.8 million in the year; the year also was after an extraordinary credit of $ 38,794,000, or $ 1.11 a share, from refinancing of long-term debt.The latest periods' results also included gain of $ 37 million in the quarter from the sale of the company's investment in Black Entertainment Television. The year's results included the gain on the sale of the Black Entertainment Television stake and a $ 45 million gain on the sale of the company's remaining investment in Chiquita Brands International.Great American sold its entertainment in December 1991. title: Duracell Promotes Official to President
description: Duracell International Inc., the world's largest producer of batteries for the consumer market, has appointed Charles R. Perrin to the newly created position of president and chief operating officer.

title: James H. Bell, 48, Political Chief For Auto Workers Local, Is Dead
description: James H. Bell, a vice president of District 65 of the United Auto Workers who was active in New York City's union affairs and political campaigns, died yesterday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 48 years old and lived in Mt. Vernon, N.Y.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: California; Who Is Jerry Brown? Voices From Past Show Why the Man Is an Enigma
description: As New Yorkers and the nation ponder the surprisingly strong Presidential bid of Edmund G. Brown Jr., they ask who is this unconventional politician? In the California Democratic political soil from which he sprang, there are many answers.

title: Most Trout Choose to Ignore the Casting Call
description: Never have so many cast so much for so little. As a fly fisherman, this has always been, and continues to be, my experience of the annual rite of mortification known as opening day, also well named April Fool's Day. But this year I had high hopes, very high hopes.

description: The number of companies raising dividends turned up sharply in the first quarter of the year, providing another signal that the economy may be recovering, figures released yesterday by the Standard & Poor's Corporation showed.

Manuel Antonio Noriega today derided the drug-trafficking, money-laundering and racketeering charges against the deposed Panamanian leader as a crude political vendetta built on the dubious testimony of "admitted liars and convicted felons."

title: Wallace Fund Quietly Grows Into Nation's Top Arts Donor
description: Rural Alaskans may not know it yet, but they will be getting a truckload of theater over the next five years. Earlier this month the Perseverance Theater in Douglas was one of nine community theaters across the United States to receive grants totaling $3.4 million from the Lila Wallace-Reader's Digest Fund.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Advanced Interventional Systems Inc., Irvine, Calif., signed a letter to acquire Polymicro Technologies Inc., which supplies fiber-optic products. * American Telephone and Telegraph Co., New York, bought 51 percent of Informatica y Telecomunicaciones S.A., Mexico's telecommunications distributor. No terms were disclosed.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co.  reports earnings for 12mos Feb 29
description: Year-ago period's revenue was restated to include revenues from interchange deliveries previously classified as a credit to expense.

title: Valenti Calls 'J.F.K.' 'Hoax' and 'Smear'
description: In a highly unusual and angry statement, Jack Valenti, the president and chief executive of the Motion Picture Association of America and a former top aide to President Lyndon B. Johnson, denounced the film "J. F. K." today as a "hoax," a "smear" and "pure fiction" that rivaled the Nazi propaganda films of Leni Reifenstahl.

title: A Rising Tide of Rhetoric Over Warnings on Alcohol
description: AS Senate hearings get under way this morning on a bill that would require health warnings in advertising for alcoholic beverages, people on both sides of the issue are intensifying their already fierce efforts to sway public opinion.

title: U.P.S. Buys Europe Carrier
description: United Parcel Service of America Inc. said today that it had bought the Austrian package carrier Star Air Parcel Service, its gateway agent for most shipments to Eastern Europe. No terms were disclosed.

title: Justices Hear Case on Right Of U.S. to Kidnap Foreigners
description: The Bush Administration argued before the Supreme Court today for the right of the Federal Government to kidnap foreigners and prosecute them in the United States for crimes committed abroad.

title: Rexhall Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Pregnancy-Discrimination Award Upheld
description: A state appellate court has reversed itself and upheld a decision of the state Division of Human Rights awarding $450,000 to an employee of the New York City Transit Authority who accused the agency of discriminating against her during two pregnancies.

title: New Hope Is Seen for Trade Pact
description: After several years of tortuous negotiations, the leading trade negotiators of the European Community and the United States are saying, for the first time, that a global agreement on liberalizing trade may be possible soon.

title: Welfare and Medicaid Bills Likely to Keep Soaring
description: Although the new state budget will wring unprecedented savings from New York's Medicaid and welfare programs, even the budget's architects do not believe it will arrest the explosive growth in spending on social services in the near future.

title: United Stationers reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
A Plan to Burn PCB's Frightens Neighbors
description: Twelve years after heavy concentrations of PCB's were discovered in the oily waters of a Metro-North Commuter Railroad yard lagoon here, environmental officials have announced a $9.1 million plan to burn the chemicals in a mobile incinerator and bury the residue in the yard.

title: Abatix Environmental reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

description: b-Net loss

title: Busch Plans Theme Park in Spain
description: The Anheuser-Busch Companies said yesterday that it planned to open a theme park and resort near Barcelona in 1995.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE 11-year-old boy needed to build a small wooden car as part of a father-and-son project. His father was very enthusiastic, but the boy said he preferred to work on the model with his stepfather instead.

title: Dinkins Authorizes Bond Issue To Improve Grand Central Area
description: Giving official approval to an effort by private businesses to enhance nearby public areas, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday authorized a bond issue of up to $35 million to finance improvements in the area surrounding Grand Central Terminal.

title: Industrial Expansion Continues
description: The nation's manufacturing economy, pushed by a surge in new orders, continued to expand in March, according to a report by the nation's purchasing managers. Economists said that the figures presented the freshest evidence available that the nation's economy had moved out of recession.

title: Douglas Roby, 94, A Former President Of Olympic Group
description: Doug Roby of Ypsilanti, Mich., a high-ranking American amateur sports official for 50 years and a member of the International Olympic Committee for 32 years, died Tuesday in a nursing home in Ann Arbor, Mich.

title: Market Place; Cash Is Trash? Not This Time
description: "Cash," went the Wall Street refrain as 1991 ended, "is trash." So low were the prevailing interest rates on savings accounts, money market funds and Treasury bills that investors would have to turn to the stock and bond markets to find decent returns, the conventional wisdom held.

title: Intercontinental Life Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
ON THE ROAD WITH: Jacques Barzaghi; What's That Glimmering Behind Jerry Brown?
description: DON QUIXOTE had Sancho Panza and Richard Nixon had Bebe Rebozo. Jerry Brown, who on any given day of his campaign can seem idealistic or just plain tricky, has Jacques Barzaghi.

title: Emerson Moves To Revamp Debt
description: The Emerson Radio Corporation said it would not proceed with plans for an equity infusion from Semi-Tech (Global) Ltd. The consumer electronics maker said it instead began talks with its lenders to restructure its debt. Emerson said had it signed a distribution agreement with Semi-Tech to sell Emerson televisions, radios, tape players and other products.

title: Prine's New Lease on Performing Life
description: Like any great songwriter, John Prine frames the world in a way that gives things a slightly different luster, a new sheen.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Campaign Trail; Aides Seek Right Song For Clinton
description: Having dealt with sex and drugs, the Clinton campaign must now overcome the most impossible hurdle of all: rock and roll.

title: Foster Wheeler Job
description: The Foster Wheeler Corporation said today that it had received a $143 million contract to design and build an asparatame artificial sweetener plant for Euro-Asparatame, a joint venture of the Ajinomoto Company of Japan and the Monsanto Company's Nutrasweet Company. The plant will be in Gravelines, France.

title: Grubb & Ellis Realty Income Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net lossThe company said financial results for 1991 include provisions for losses of $ 1,003,000 on the sale of three of the company's investments which were completed during the year. Also, the REIT's 1991 fourth quarter operating expenses reflect a $ 639,000 reversal of prior year advisory fees and interest on deferred advisory fees. Under limitations of the advisory agreement, its is unlikely that the liability for advisory fees and interest on the fees will be paid.

title: Imaging ManagementAssociates reports earnings for Year to Dec 31

description: HOLD on to your antimacassars. Jean-Paul Gaultier, the fashion designer who made skirts for men and ballistic brassieres for Madonna, has turned his attention to furniture.

description: Patrick J. Buchanan, the Republican candidate who often speaks of leading a "middle-American revolution," has income and assets that place him far above the average American, according to a financial disclosure form made public today.

Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in some editions yesterday about a vote in the Senate, to allow Federal financing of tissue transplants using cells from aborted fetuses, misstated the tally. It was 77 to 23, not 72 to 23.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Japanese Stock Slide Continues
description: The deep pessimism here over the course of the economy and the stock market worsened on Wednesday as stock prices plummeted despite announcments of a steep cut in the official interest rate and an emergency Government stimulus program.

title: Slaying Suspect Adrift in World of Violence
description: At a storefront church in Rochester, a few miles from a drug house where three people were found shot dead the morning before, Etheridge Pierce Jr. sought sanctuary on Monday. His life had changed, he said. He had nowhere to go. And for most of the day, the 18-year-old from New York City sat quietly in a pew, praying and reading from a Bible.

title: Reserve Industries Corp. reports earnings for Year to Nov 30
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $ 1 million for anticipated expenes related to the Decmeber suspension of operations of its L-Bar Products Inc. unit.c-After an extraordinary credit of $ 528,142, or 39 cents a share, from partial extinguishment of debt and tax-loss carryforward.The year-ago loss from continiuing operations of $ 1,040,796 included a pretax loss of $ 560,413 from the reduction of capitalized equipment, exploration, acquisition and carrying costs, and a pretax gain of $ 277,010 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Intel-Digital Software Pact
description: The Intel Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation, two of the biggest high-technology powerhouses, said they would collaborate on new software vital to the future of the world's fastest computers. They said the effort would cover projects that include advanced supercomputer software for operating systems and networking. Supercomputers, the world's most powerful, can complete billions of calculations a second, making them a vital tool for scientific and mathematical research in areas as diverse as aerospace, chemical analysis and meteorology.

title: Rehearsal Week For Nicklaus
description: A trimmer, muscular Jack Nicklaus will compete in the Tradition this weekend. His devotion to a new fitness regimen, however, has little to do with his quest for a third straight tournament title.

title: 4 Palestinians Die in Major Gaza Clash
description: At least four Palestinians were killed and dozens wounded in the southernmost part of the Gaza Strip today in one of the most serious clashes between Israeli troops and Palestinians since the killings at Al Aksa mosque in Jerusalem 18 months ago.

title: The S.& L. Victims' Avenging Angel
description: When one of the nation's largest law firms and one of the largest accounting firms said this week that they would pay $87 million to settle charges that they had helped Charles H. Keating Jr. dupe investors, it was another big victory for Joseph W. Cotchett.

title: Harrowston Corp.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
