description: WHEN I think of the car that I have most wanted in my life, it is a model that was neither particularly exotic nor very rare. But it is still there in my fantasy, a new 1960 Cadillac coupe standing on the showroom floor at Mayo Motors in Trexlertown, Pa., glittering in its coat of dark turquoise paint.

title: Dollar Is Down Against Pound
Movie Fan's Productions Get as Far as the Lobby
description: PERHAPS it took a film addict like Erwin Koti, who watched "The Spy Who Loved Me" more than 50 times, to discover a need in the movie business that even the industry's giants didn't recognize. Mr. Koti, a 31-year-old native of Norwalk, quietly developed that niche in the early 1980's, and his work is seen every year by millions of movie buffs nationwide.

title:
Commercial Property: Sick Buildings;
Seeking Remedies for Indoor-Air-Pollution Problems
description: WHEN workers move into the State of Washington's new Natural Resources Building in downtown Olympia this July, they will encounter a work environment that officials hope will be as free of contaminants and other adverse conditions as technology, know-how and plain common sense can make it.

title: Rome
description: As Europe's capitals go, Romans acknowledge with a mix of pride and regret that theirs best exemplifies the old adage that time is money: in other words, in this city, it is virtually impossible to spend time without spending money in substantial dollops. So the question arises: Is it still worth it now that youth's lost memories of dollar-a-bowl pasta are gone, and the famed three coins in the Trevi Fountain won't even buy a cappuccino?

title: Outpouring of Sympathy For Dog, but Not Master
description: When a taxi jumped a curb in midtown Manhattan on Monday, two bystanders were struck and seriously injured. Since then, one victim has received four get-well cards and a handful of visitors. The second has received hundreds of cards; 300 to 400 people have called each day to ask about him, and well-wishers have contributed hundreds of dollars to insure that he receives good care.

title: Feminism and the Wild Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Rickin Marries
description: Roseanne Ricklin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Ricklin of Denver, was married last evening to Andrew D. Tenenbaum, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Tenenbaum of Bel Air, Calif., and New Rochelle, N.Y. Rabbi Gerald Serotta officiated at the Park Hyatt Hotel in Washington. Mrs. Tenenbaum, 27 years old, is an administrator at the Cardio Diagnostic Center in Chevy Chase, Md. Mr. Tenenbaum, 29, is a lawyer with the Washington firm of Cohen & White.

title: Mets' Silence Was Blessing
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Manhattanville College And Russian Enterprise
description: Regarding the article on the joint effort of the Volunteer Development Council for United Nations Delegations and the Manhattanville College Entrepreneurial Center [ "Lighting Russia's Entrepreneurial Spirit," March 29 ] :

title: UConn Gives Athletes Coaches for Classwork
description: THE basketball players were more than 1,000 miles from home. On the following day they would be playing their biggest game of the season. But on this Friday afternoon eight members of the University of Connecticut men's team were gathered in a conference room at a hotel in Cincinnati to review material from their psychology course with Doug Melody, a former UConn basketball star.

title: Free-Market Capitalism, Applied to the Stage
description: Whatever else people say about him and they say a lot -- nearly everyone agrees that Wiktor Kubiak has chutzpah.

title:
MUSIC;
When a Child Prodigy Comes of Age
description: MATT HAIMOVITZ, a cellist who was well known as a professional musician in his teens, has had to make the difficult transition from a career as a child prodigy to the life of an adult musician. Now 21 years old, and having completed two years at Princeton University while maintaining his concert schedule, Mr. Haimovitz has taken this year off from school to play a season of 50 concerts.

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: THE RUN OF THE COUNTRY By Shane Connaughton. St. Martin's, $17.95.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;
The Portals Gets a Tenant
description: THE Federal Aviation Administration has signed a $17 million, 10-year contract for a 51,000-square-foot floor of the eight-story, 460,000

title: Life's Tragic, but Julie Hagerty's Funny
description: Here's one way to look at it: Julie Hagerty is finished in Hollywood -- at least in sitcoms, at least for now. Gone -- under circumstances both mysterious and ridiculous -- is her starring role in the CBS comedy "Princesses." Gone, too, for that matter, is "Princesses." Just a fond memory is her Universal Studios dressing room; ancient history is her shiny red rented sports car; available for occupancy is her former West Coast base of operations -- an, er, interesting house in the Hollywood Hills.

title: Talking: Remodeling; An Ideal Time to Do the Job
description: THIS is an ideal time for a homeowner to embark upon a major remodeling job. For one thing, the prolonged recession has weeded out many of the fly-by-night operators who flourished when getting anyone to do the work was a minor miracle.

title: Carolyn Balch To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. James P. Balch of Sheffield, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Carolyn Knowles Balch to Michael Wells Streett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald H. Streett of St. Louis. A June wedding is planned.

title: The Parking Lot of Memory
description: GOING TO PATCHOGUE By Thomas McGonigle.Illustrated. 213 pp. Elmwood Park, Ill.:Dalkey Archive Press. $19.95.

title: Linda Wrigley Marries Nicholas Rizopoulos
description: Linda Wrigley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John F. Wrigley of Egg Harbor, N.J., was married in New York yesterday to Nicholas Xenophon Rizopoulos, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Xenophon Rizopoulos of Athens, Greece. Jacqueline Silbermann, an administrative judge of the New York City Civil Court, officiated at the home of Sherwin M. Goldman.

title: Arthur Nelson, Art Professor, 79
description: Arthur Nelson, a retired art professor, died April 4 at his home in Spring Valley, N.Y. He was 79 years old.

title: Feminism and the Wild Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Grabbing for Royalties in the Digital Age
description: If i were a member of Congress in this election year, I would have grave doubts about voting for a bill that imposes a new tax, constrains a common form of home entertainment and yields revenue not to the government but, primarily, to multinational corporations -- two in Japan and one each in Germany, the Netherlands, Great Britain and the United States. Amazingly enough, the proposed Audio Home Recording Act has a good chance of slipping through Congress this spring.

title: Even After Overtime, Strike Ends in Tie
description: After six months of saber-rattling and a 10-day strike, what exactly did the hockey players' union gain in a settlement with team owners that was announced at midnight Friday in the Plaza Hotel?

title: Feminism and the Wild Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Cleanup Project Can Be Inspiration
description: Mike Booth's splendid cleanup project in Long Branch by the unemployed, described in "How One Idea Solved Two Problems, Lifting a City's Spirits" (March 22), should inspire other communities to start similar ventures.

title: A. T. Gardner to Marry Ms. Harris
description: Mr. and Mrs. T. R. Harris of Kimberley, Ontario, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Kimberley Patricia Harris, to Andrew Tobias Gardner, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan D. Gardner of Chappaqua, N.Y. A December wedding is planned.

title: World Markets; Is Japan Ready to Bottom Out?
description: Fiona Biggs, portfolio manager for the Dreyfus Strategic World Investing Fund, has been bearish on the Japanese stock market, and she looked very smart last week. The Nikkei index of 225 shares fell 10.6 percent through Thursday, to its lowest level since October 1986. The market was down 27.8 percent for the year and 57.4 percent since its all-time high at the end of 1989.

title: The Rituals of El Tajin
description: ON the sun-baked dirt path that is the entrance to El Tajin, an archeological site in northern Veracruz state, five men clad in red velvet pants, embroidered sashes and helmets decorated with multicolored feathers climb to a platform atop a 100-foot pole. While four attach thick ropes to their waists, the fifth man begins to play a flute and sound a small drum attached to the end of the instrument.

title: Amy G. Schmitt Married in West
description: Amy Gillette Schmitt, the daughter of Paul F. Schmitt of Novato, Calif., and Anne G. Briggin of Menlo Park, Calif., was married yesterday to Andrew Waldron Faulkner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Winthrop W. Faulkner of Washington. The Rev. Joan Hull, a Unitarian minister, officiated at Beaulieu Gardens in Rutherford, Calif.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE COUNTY PARKS DEPARTMENT;
Golf Courses and Playland in the Age of Computerization
description: DON'T go looking for robots just yet, but the County Department of Parks, Recreation and Conservation is swinging into automated gear.

title: POSTINGS: Rebirth for Bradhurst; A Start for Sass Plaza
description: One sign that the long awaited rebirth of Bradhurst, one of Harlem's most impoverished sections, is finally under way is the completion of the first phase of Sass Plaza, a complex that will provide permanent housing for the homeless.

title: Slump Vs. Wetlands in Trenton Bill to Revive Construction Permits
description: In a battle pitting builders against citizens groups and environmentalists, the New Jersey Assembly is to vote on Monday on a bill that would automatically extend through 1994 all building permits that have expired in the last three years.

title: Afterlife of a War
description: M.I.A. Or Mythmaking in America. By H. Bruce Franklin. 225 pp. Brooklyn: Lawrence Hill Books. $17.95.

title: A Last Call for Fathers, Sons and Barflies
description: I have no statistics to back this up. But it's my guess that the two most common manifestations of the American drama are the bar play and the father-son play.

title: Miss Popularity Bites the Dust
description: THE WAY MEN ACT By Elinor Lipman. 305 pp. New York: Pocket Books. $20.

title: Education Effort Fights AIDS in Zimbabwe
description: In a country where talk about AIDS was virtually taboo, Zimbabweans can hardly pass a day now without hearing about the virus in the office, on the farm, in the pub or in the classroom.

title: Wall Street; Before the Bombs, London Toasted the Tories
description: The terrorist bombs that hit London's financial district Friday night were a grim finale to what had already been a turbulent spring in the British markets, as the Conservative Government fought off a Labor challenge, first in the opinion polls and then at the ballot box.

title: If You're Talking $1 Million for a Major Leaguer, You're Talking Peanuts
description: The average salary in major league baseball has soared so high this season that 15 players who have salaries of $1 million or more are earning less than the average.

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: GAMES WE USED TO PLAY A Lover's Quarrel With the World of Sport. By Roger Kahn. Ticknor & Fields, $21.95.

title: Magazine Publisher, 17, Turns to Laser Printing
description: WASTING TIME magazine is going high tech. The magazine's president, publisher and editor in chief -- a 17-year-old Scarsdale High School student, Derek A. Milman -- has just acquired a new laser printing system for his personal computer.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: JOHN BROWN

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: AWARD FOR ALI

title: Plans for Easing Traffic Raise Ire in New Haven
description: AT a time when cities like Hartford, Boston, San Francisco and New York are restoring pedestrian access to their waterfronts, the Connecticut Department of Transportation has unveiled costly plans to ease rush-hour traffic in New Haven that would effectively separate the city from its historic port. The plan, which is still tentative and contains a wide range of options, would help drivers on Interstate 95 near the harbor by widening the Quinnipiac River Bridge and its highway approaches.

title: Sharon Ann Wolpoff: Designer of Beaded Handbags
description: There was no thought of creating a new art form or fashion item, and certainly not of building a new business, when Sharon Ann Wolpoff of Kensington, Md., began working with beads just about a year ago. An artist who had always been fascinated with the interplay of light and color, she initially thought of her foray into beads as just another way of expanding her knowledge and experience of color.

title: Conner, Caught in a Crucial Spot, Clings to Hope of Turning the Tide
description: America's Cup trial racing took on a life of its own this week as Dennis Conner struggled to hang on to an era he created in yachting nearly two decades ago. And as the pressure mounted to win, so did his dread of loss.

title: Miss Hawkins Plans Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin Hawkins of Verona, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Cynthia Karen Hawkins, to Daniel Edward Stryker Jr., a son of Mr. Stryker of Spokane, Wash., and Rosemarie Stryker of Everett, Wash. A December wedding is planned.

title: U.N. Warns That Time Is Running Out on Cyprus
description: In a new effort to settle the decades-old Cyprus dispute, the Security Council has told the island's Greek and Turkish leaders to start settling their differences by July or risk the collapse of the United Nations force that is helping keep the peace on the island.

title: Sally Srok Marries
description: Sally Jean Srok, a daughter of John Srok of Milwaukee and Joyce Goulet of Denver, was married yesterday evening in Milwaukee to Michael Andrew Friedes, a son of Bernice Friedes of New York and the late Harry E. Friedes. Judge John DiMotto of Milwaukee County Circuit Court performed the civil ceremony at the Wisconsin Club. Mrs. Friedes, 27 years old, is a manager of retail events at Go Silk, a sportswear manufacturer, in New York. Mr. Friedes, 28, is a sales representative at the Giorgio Armani Fashion Corporation in New York.

title: Bus Carrying L.I. Students Crashes; At Least 2 Die
description: A chartered bus carrying students from a Long Island middle school slid off Interstate 87 in the Adirondacks yesterday and tumbled over a steep embankment, killing at least two people and injuring 29, the police and emergency rescue officials said.

title:
OUTDOORS;
Valve Is Good for Fish and for City
description: City dwellers are not the only ones who have grown accustomed to living in an almost perpetual state of shock. The condition also applies to many of our neighbors in the otherwise idyllic Catskills, including the trout and mayflies who inhabit the upper Delaware watershed.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;
Philip Huncik, Ironworker
description: Of late, one of the more attractive corners of Bloomingdale's is its Future Watch boutique, where clothing hangs on racks adorned with swirls of wrought iron that look like abstract clocks. Philip Huncik, a specialist in decorative ironwork, made the whimsical display fixtures, but he hardly fits their trendy image.

title:
FORUM;
Japan's Restricted Mutual-Funds
description: Last week, the Japanese Government called for efforts to bolster the country's troubled stock market, including measures to encourage more mutual funds investing in Japanese stocks. However, the Japanese Government did not put forward one obvious proposal -- to abolish the regulatory barriers that prevent American firms like mine from offering mutual funds to Japanese investors.

title: Israeli Troops Destroy 7 Houses in Lebanon
description: Israeli troops have demolished seven houses in southern Lebanon belonging to Shiite Muslim families whose members were suspected of aiding Muslim guerrillas, security officials said here today.

title: Sam Kinison, 38, Comedian, Dies; Wife Injured in Head-On Collision
description: Sam Kinison, a former tent preacher who gained fame as a shrieking and often insulting stand-up comedian, was killed Friday night in a head-on automobile crash on a desert highway near Needles, Calif.

title: A Reverential 'Oklahoma!' Revival
description: CARRYING the weight of history and nostalgia, "Oklahoma!" represents hallowed musical comedy territory. One feels obliged to welcome it with good will and cheer. No critical carping. That would be unthinkable, if not subversive.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Call Is Out to Iran's Rich: Cut Excess
description: They are the revolutionary rich, a cast of thousands who have monopolized foreign trade, manipulated the exchange rates and made fortunes on the 13-year reign of the ayatollahs.

title: Review/Theater; Brother vs. Brother in a Dangerous Game
description: "Blood Knot," the 1961 two-character drama that established the reputation of the playwright Athol Fugard, is not an easy play. A rambling, two-and-a-half-hour dialogue between Morris and Zachariah, two South African brothers of mixed racial background, it is as austere and claustrophobic as one of Samuel Beckett's metaphysical meditations. Rituals of daily life -- the symbolic ringing of Morris's alarm clock; Zachariah's soaking of his tired feet in bath salts at the end of each workday -- are repeated and drawn out with a solemnity that borders on tedium. Not until well into the second act of "Blood Knot" do its carefully set up emotional fireworks begin to detonate.

title: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.
description: In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.

title: THE BALLAD OF NO-SHOW JONES
description: As a veteran session musician who has worked with George Jones dozens of times, I agree with Randy Travis that Jones is "one of the greatest when it comes to phrasing" ("The Ballad of No-Show Jones" by James Hunter, March 15).

title: In and Out in Villanova
description: Judging by the flurry of prospects flocking to Villanova you'd think that Athletic Director TED ACETO is trying to recruit an entire team, not a single coach to replace ROLLIE MASSIMINO.

title: Star-Struck
description: HOW THE SHAMAN STOLE THE MOON In Search of Ancient Prophet-Scientists From Stonehenge to the Grand Canyon.By William H. Calvin.Illustrated. 223 pp. New York:Bantam Books.

title: 40's-Style Melodrama Takes Giddy Turns
description: IN his six and a half years as artistic head of the Boston Post Road Stage Company, Douglas Moser has fancied the non-mainstream play with an off-center point of view. But none has been wilder and crazier than "The Lady in Question."

title: For the Garage Door, An Automatic Opener
description: RECALLING winter weather or a sore back may be evidence enough that it is time to invest in an automatic garage-door opener. They can be installed on virtually any overhead door that operates smoothly.

title: There Must Be Better Ways
description: HORACE'S SCHOOL Redesigning the American High School.By Theodore R. Sizer.238 pp. Boston:Houghton Mifflin Company. $19.95. S.O.S. Sustain Our Schools.By Patricia Albjerg Graham.195 pp. New York:Hill & Wang. $22.95.

title: TALES FROM THE BABY FACTORY
description: As a couple who've experienced infertility for more than seven years, we have come to know another insidious side of the quest to conceive. Although the stress caused by financial burdens, medications, schedules and perhaps failure is real, it is also somewhat short-term. With termination of infertility therapy, much of this stress disappears. What remains is the conditioning of scheduled lovemaking, and decisions based on maximizing fertility. What is lost is romance and spontaneity. It is here that the truly devastating tales of the baby factory lie. JIM AND MARY ELLEN SLADE Manalapan, N.J.

title: THE ORACLE OF CROWN HEIGHTS
description: The article on Rabbi Schneerson seems to suggest that the Rebbe is engaging in political influence peddling in Israel. This, of course, is his right, but it begs the question of why the Lubavitchers then do not have to account adequately for the supposed hundreds of millions flowing into their organization. It seems to me that what people do, not what they call themselves, is what allows for the privilege of religious exemption. We deserve the right to know how extremist religious institutions here are influencing the political process in Israel, and exactly how much tax-free money is being spent on it. COLLIN PERRY New York, N.Y.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: ROY HINSON;
An Injured Star Hopes to Shine Again
description: THE New Jersey Nets' Roy Hinson has been underestimated at almost every turn of his career. As a gangly freshman at Franklin Township High School, he failed to make the basketball team. By the time he was a 6-foot-9-inch senior, he was seriously recruited by only four colleges.

title:
BACKTALK;
Tennis's Conspiracy of Compassion for Arthur Ashe
description: It was when Arthur Ashe started talking about his family -- wife Jeanne Moutoussamy, an accomplished photographer, and their 5-year-old daughter, Camera -- that the tears welled in his eyes. The deceptively dispassionate voice that has given eloquent expression to issues of political and social consequence was overcome with emotion. For a painful, poignant minute, the gentleman who has been the conscience of tennis was silent, unable to speak, which explained better than words how it was kept quiet for three and a half years that he has AIDS.

title: Lesley Bischoff To Wed in June
description: Richard Bischoff of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Nancy Kane Bischoff of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Lesley Clare Bischoff and William Alexander King, a son of William H. King of Higganum, Conn., and Sondra King of Middletown, Conn.

title: A Fistful of Rubles
description: WHAT IS TO BE DONE? Proposals for the Soviet Transition to the Market.Edited by Merton J. Peck andThomas J. Richardson. 220 pp. New Haven:Yale University Press.Cloth, $28. Paper, $12.

title: You Can't Tell a Restaurant by Its Name
description: THE Long Island Seafood Dumpling House in Stamford has a few anomalies in its name. Immediately putting aside that it's in Connecticut, not Long Island, the word dumpling suggests dim sum, yet there are very few dim sum (appetizer-like tidbits), on the menu. And while seafood represents about half the menu choices, most of these dishes are either shrimp or scallops.

title: Complaints on Center Shouldn't Be a Surprise
description: Your reporter wrote a fair article on the Wayside Home [ "Proposal to Expand Girls' Home Fought," March 15 ] . But Mr. Juliani and Mr. Gutheil created some misleading impressions concerning being "surprised" at our "complaints."

title: Ukraine, Awaiting Fleet Decision, Builds a Navy
description: The Ukrainian Government is quietly taking steps to build its own naval force as Ukrainians and Russians await a political decision on the future of the Black Sea fleet, which has been a major point of contention between them.

title: Laura Wessner to Wed Lawrence Policastro Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ernest R. Wessner of Kutztown, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Laura Mary Wessner to Lawrence Joseph Policastro Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Policastro Sr. of Freehold, N.J. A June wedding is planned.

title: Ito Wants to Retire
description: Let's see. She has won a world championship. She was the first woman to perform the forbidding three-and-a-half-revolution triple axel in competition and at the Olympics. And although a fall kept her from winning, she did bring home a silver medal from the 1992 Winter Olympics.

title: Jill Nagusky and M. R. Epstein Wed
description: Jill Ellen Nagusky, a graduate student in human service management at Brandeis University, was married last evening to Dr. Michael Richard Epstein, a pediatric resident at Children's Hospital in Boston. Rabbi William Dreskin officiated at Chanterelle, a catering establishment in Mayfield Heights, Ohio.

title: Sunday Menu; A Heady Linguine Sauce That Evokes 2 Regions
description: Combine elements of a New England dinner of fresh salmon and peas -- a tradition dating from the time when salmon was still abundant in the region's rivers and streams -- with a slightly altered version of New York's Lower East Side lox and cream cheese, and you have a heady sauce for a potful of linguine.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There is almost nothing that men and women won't talk about publicly these days. There is little or no hesitation in owning up to alcoholism, drug abuse, extramarital affairs, abuse as a child, compulsive gambling, shopping addiction, face lifts, fat thighs, overeating, undereating -- name it.

title: Making a Difference; For Nathan's, Caldor Dogs
description: Look out, McDonald's. Here comes Nathan's Famous.

title: Ashley Kiesel, Lawyer, to Wed
description: Dr. and Mrs. John L. Kiesel of Lexington, Ky., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Ashley Kiesel, to Richard Elliott Rochman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Barton C. Rochman of Peoria, Ill. A September wedding is planned.

title: Ex-Soviets to Get a $12 Billion Loan
description: The World Bank plans to lend $12 billion to $15 billion to the former Soviet republics by 1995 to bankroll food and oil-production projects and pay for critical imports like spare parts, according to the international lending institution's president.

title: Charles Busch Spoof of the Movies
description: IN his six and a half years as artistic head of the Boston Post Road Stage Company, Douglas Moser has fancied the non-mainstream play with an off-center point of view. But none has been wilder and crazier than "The Lady in Question."

title: Hudson Bass Running, but Off Limits to Fishermen
description: In an annual rite of spring, shad and striped bass are returning to the Hudson River to spawn.

title: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.
description: In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.

title: This Week's Numbers
Killings of Palestinian Suspects Raise Questions About Israeli Army Agents
description: As a fruit-stand owner in the outdoor market remembers it, the men were leaning against a wall drinking juice when they suddenly called out to Bassam Fadi Shaban, who was standing yards away in the dusty street.

title: State Vexed By Its Rank As a Leader In Car Thefts
description: THOMAS SEBAS said he had a bad feeling when he left his car at the New Haven train station early one morning last December. Mr. Sebas, an Ansonia resident, said his 1983 Celica GT -- with more than 100,000 miles -- was parked across the street from the city's police headquarters. But that did not comfort him, he said, because his father's car had recently been stolen right out of his driveway in Stratford.

title: Return of Refugees to Cambodia to Take Longer Than Planned
description: The return of 375,000 refugees to Cambodia from border camps in Thailand will take far longer than foreseen, Cambodian, United Nations and relief officials say.

title: J. K. Albaugh, 66, Retired Psychiatrist and Administrator
description: Dr. Judson K. Albaugh, a retired psychiatrist and mental health administrator, died on Friday when he collapsed and fell into Cayuga Lake in New York while fishing on the shore.

title:
DINING OUT;
Unexpected Delights in Chinese Food
description: CHINESE restaurants in New Jersey have become increasingly adventurous. Many now accept that local diners don't have to be Chinese to order jellyfish or vegetable duck in lieu of egg roll and barbecued spareribs. But China 17, a brightly lighted restaurant opposite the Malcolm Konner Chevrolet dealer on Route 17 in Paramus, has expanded its menu in yet another direction.

title: Deliverer's Union Nears Pact With The Times
description: The New York Times and a major independent newspaper delivery company reached separate tentative agreements with the drivers union yesterday that could insure labor peace in the wholesale distribution of New York's newspapers until the year 2000 and speed the opening of The Times's new printing plant in Edison, N.J.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Behind the Scenes; To President's Campaign Manager, It's Been a Season of Smooth Sailing
description: Public approval of George Bush's Presidency has been scraping along at historic lows for two months. A third of all Republican voters have consistently rejected the President through the spring's primaries. A drumbeat of news reports is depicting the White House as adrift and bereft of bright ideas. And the prevailing view of Mr. Bush's campaign performance is that it has been, ah, uneven.

title: Top Athletes Are Being Wooed to Fill Some Big Shoes
description: Forget the burning question about how the United States basketball team will fare at the Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain, with Patrick Ewing, Charles Barkley and the other pros taking on the world.

title: Nancy Gardner, Lawyer, Weds
description: Nancy Christine Gardner, an associate at the law firm of Weil, Gotshal & Manges, and Edward Joseph Garofolo, a vice president at Reliance National, an insurance concern, both in New York, were married yesterday. Msgr. Anthony J. Barretta officiated at St. Paul the Apostle Roman Catholic Church in Brookville, L.I.

title: Clinton, Among Others, Prevails With the Help of Grudging Voters
description: Given what he had gone through in the preceding two weeks, quadruple victory was especially sweet for Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas on Tuesday. He won the big one, the New York Presidential primary, by a good margin, added Wisconsin and Kansas to his string and even prevailed in the non-binding Minnesota "beauty contest." He fairly glowed with bonhomie.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Voters; These Voters Want Change, But Don't Have a Candidate
description: Like most everyone at the Northeast Bronx Senior Citizens Center, Anita Sollino did not bother to vote in New York's Presidential primary on Tuesday, even though she has been a Democrat for more than 50 years.

title: Coins
description: The Mint's Mistakes

title: 116-Year-Old Company Thrives on Innovation
description: DESPITE 30 years of decline among Connecticut manufacturers, optimism reigns at Stanadyne Inc. in Windsor. To understand why, it helps to consider the company's history.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday on the Making a Difference page about steel trade issues misidentified Carla A. Hills. She is the United States trade representative.

title: Treating Alcoholics In Russia
description: The article "Russians Learn About Helping Alcoholics" (March 8) was informative and inspiring in many ways, but it presented some inaccurate facts about what is actually progressing in the former Soviet Union with regard to alcoholism treatment and recovery. Your readers deserve to know the history and the facts about what is currently transpiring in the Commonwealth of Independent States.

title: Editorial Notebook; The Horror Files
description: People throughout Eastern Europe struggle with the question of how to deal with the contents of Big Brother's files. Is there a middle ground between total amnesty and wholesale purges in post-dictatorial societies?

title: Lynn Sanborne Weds M. F. Jimenez
description: Lynn Marie Sanborne, a graduate student in clinical social work at Bryn Mawr College, and Michael Francis Jimenez, an assistant professor of history at Princeton University, were married yesterday. The Rev. Patrick Connor, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at Princeton University Chapel in Princeton, N.J.

title: Gregory Peck Enters The 'Tribute Stage'
description: IN THE 1950's, WHILE DRIVING INTO THE mountains of what was then Ceylon, Gregory Peck spotted a sign in a tiny village. It read: "Gregory Peck. Fine Gentleman's Tailoring."

title: School Chief Bridges Gap Between City and Suburb
description: ATTENDING college was not a family tradition when Vincent L. Ferrandino was growing up in the poorest section of Norwalk in the 1950's and 1960's. The son of an immigrant who worked as a factory shipping clerk, he was raised in a home where the primary language was Italian. Encouraged by several Norwalk teachers, the young man discovered the rewards of studying, which included admission to Amherst College in Massachusetts. He later went on to earn a doctorate from the University of Bridgeport and was appointed Superintendent of Schools in Weston in 1989.

title: Legislators Try to Limit Powers of Health Plan
description: PRODDED by angry protests from the public and the medical community, Republican legislators are trying to drastically weaken the sweeping State Health Plan sought by the Florio administration. The Assembly is scheduled to vote tomorrow on a bill that would prevent the plan's proposals from becoming binding regulations, making them only advisory, and a similar measure is expected shortly in the Senate.

title: Ms. Hamburg, A Lawyer, Wed
description: Jeanne Melissa Hamburg, an associate in the New York law firm of Coudert Brothers, and Dr. Jay Alan Schechtman, a resident in rehabilitation medicine at the Mount Sinai Medical Center in New York, were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I. Rabbi Arnold B. Marans officiated.

title: Mattingly and Leary Lift Yanks to 4-0
description: The Yankees will not proclaim their excitement out loud because Manager Buck Showalter has preached to them about being cautious, but their play is passing the message for them. Their actions are screaming, "Take us seriously."

title: Sunday Outing; Shad's on Hudson Valley Menu for Next 2 Months
description: As much as the bloom of forsythia, the return of shad to the Hudson River is a sure sign of spring in the Hudson Valley. Between now and the end of May, those who relish the taste of the fish and its roe can find all they can eat at fish markets, restaurants and festivals along the river front.

title: Adrienne Marshall Plans Wedding
description: Dr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Marshall of Falls Church, Va., have announced the engagement of their daughter Adrienne Jo Marshall to Thomas Phillip Boschwitz, a son of Ellen and Rudy Boschwitz of Minneapolis and Washington. A September wedding is planned.

title: Feminism and the Wild Man
description: To the Editor:

title: Nothing Magical
description: To the Editor:

title: Forster's Sisters
description: To the Editor:

title: Forrest Sawyer, Gathering the Spoils of War
description: Forrest Sawyer, who ricochets across the globe as a correspondent for ABC's "Nightline," with time out to serve as substitute inquisitor for Ted Koppel and anchor of the network's "World News Sunday," describes himself as a "utility infielder."

title: IN SHORT: NONFICTION
description: TOMBSTONES A Lawyer's Tales From the Takeover Decades.By Lawrence Lederman.Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $24.

title: Why 'Republic of Macedonia' Incenses Greeks; For Neighborliness
description: To the Editor:

title: Exhibit On Pioneers Of Oregon Trail
description: Next year will mark 150 years since the start of the great migration of Americans along the Oregon Trail, and there will be a series of events commemorating the early pioneers.

title: Silencing of Editor Considered Reason For Fatal Shooting
description: One month after the slaying of the editor Manuel de Dios Unanue, his companion of seven years said yesterday that she believed he was killed to stop his investigations into drug trafficking.

title: PHYSICIANS REFUSE MEDICARE PATIENTS
description: Many doctors in Manhattan, Miami and other places where medical care is expensive say they are curtailing services for the elderly because of sharp reductions in the payments they receive from Medicare.

title: An Irresistible Force Moves a Few Objects in Moscow
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia, under some pressure last week from unreconstructed conservatives in his testy legislature, said he might step down from his concurrent post as Prime Minister in three months' time, at least if his economic reform program is going well. If he does, will it matter? Almost assuredly not. This is still Russia, where a lot of sensible people talk of the need for government by an "iron hand," and there is little indication that Mr. Yeltsin's hammy fists are losing their calluses.

title: Honored in the Breach, as It Should Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Russian Legislature Votes To Curtail Yeltsin's Powers
description: After heated and tangled debate, the Russian Congress of People's Deputies passed a resolution this evening that could curtail some of the powers of President Boris N. Yeltsin.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
Government Adding Space
description: WITH office leasing and construction in the doldrums here, the Federal Government is in the midst of a long-term program that will spend more than $235 million in the next five years to accommodate its growing need for space.

title: Cruise to Focus On the Palate
description: A voyage with a French chef and a wine expert that will lead passengers to vineyards and kitchens in France, Spain and Portugal is scheduled aboard the 80-passenger Aurora II. The chef, Jacques Pepin, author of "The Short Cut Cook," will give two cooking demonstrations at sea and lecture on the legacy of nouvelle cuisine. David Rosengarten, a wine writer, will discuss matching wine with food. The trip, from Aug. 30 to Sept. 12, starts with two nights in Bordeaux, France. From nearby Pauillac the ship sails for Bilbao, Spain, and then calls at Oporto and Lisbon in Portugal, and, in Spain, Cadiz and Motril (there is an optional excursion to Granada) and Barcelona.

title:
ART;
Out of the 1920's, A Growing Appetite For Americana
description: Today most Americans take for granted the appeal of their own decorative and folk art -- they see evidence in booming sales, new museums, popular traveling exhibits -- but for a long time it was simply ignored. When Electra Havemeyer Webb, heiress to a sugar fortune, began to collect rural and folk Americana in the 1920's, she had to endure the chiding of her haughty mother, Louisine Havemeyer: "How can you, Electra, you who have been brought up with Rembrandts and Manets, live with such American trash?"

title: How a Prescient Pentagon Contractor Entered Civilian Life
description: When the Pentagon suddenly canceled the Navy's A-12 attack fighter a year ago, Electromagnetic Sciences Inc. was stuck with millions of dollars worth of antenna positioning devices that it had manufactured for the aircraft. "It was incredibly traumatic," said John E. Pippin, the company's 64-year-old chairman and chief executive. He had to lay off 100 employees, an eighth of his work force.

title: Why 'Republic of Macedonia' Incenses Greeks
description: To the Editor:

title: Other Views On Animal Rights
description: In response to the animal activist article: These people are not representative of our population and are merely a small, noisy one-dimensional group.

title: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.
description: In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.

title: The Wrong Time to Be a Mongologist
description: OWEN LATTIMORE AND THE "LOSS" OF CHINA By Robert P. Newman.Illustrated. 669 pp. Berkeley:University of California Press.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: WESTPORT;
Town Can't Stop a Battling Businessman, but the Economy . . .
description: ARNOLD KAYE stubbed out a cigarette, stared at the security screens in the office of his restaurant in Westport and quickly lit up again. Business was slow, even for a weeknight. Only a few tables were filled at the International Deli on the Post Road East.

title: Jewish, Irish, Cuban: It's Music to His Ears
description: Andy Statman lives in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn, in a modest house filled with children and musical instruments. It is a home resonant with delightful sounds.

title: A Vintage Monteux Concert Surfaces
description: Here's to the mysterious ways of the record world. On May 31, 1963, Pierre Monteux conducted the London Symphony Orchestra and the pianist John Ogdon in an all-Tchaikovsky concert at the Vienna Festival, comprising "Romeo and Juliet," the First Piano Concerto and the Fifth Symphony. For reasons no one has been able to reconstruct, the American Vanguard label recorded the performance but then filed away the tapes.

title: Booth Speech Reveals a Killer's Mind
description: In 1860, more than four years before John Wilkes Booth assassinated Abraham Lincoln in Ford's Theater, the actor wrote a 21-page manuscript that showed his fanatical state of mind, his sympathies for the Southern secessionists and his association with the historical characters he portrayed in Shakespeare's plays.

title: Deborah Platt To Wed in June
description: Sidney Platt of Glen Cove, L.I., has announced the engagement of his daughter Dr. Deborah Platt to Dr. Jeffrey Weiss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jesse Weiss of Fairfield, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Kathy Weilbaecher, Student, Weds
description: Katherine Nelson Weilbaecher and Michael Hirsch Tomasson, students at the Stanford University Medical School, were married yesterday at the Woodside (Calif.) Village Church. The Rev. Albert A. Grosskoff, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony.

title: STANDOFF AT U.N. WITH A PROTESTER
description: A woman in a van held the police at bay throughout the afternoon and evening yesterday after she drove onto the grounds of the United Nations headquarters on First Avenue, then threatened to set herself on fire and detonate explosives she said were in the back of the vehicle, the police said.

title: Laura Hobson Is Married in Natchez
description: Laura Thorn Hobson, a landscape architect in Charlottesville, Va., was married yesterday to Daniel L. Larson Jr., the president of Larsdale Inc., a Boston industrial products manufacturing company. The Rev. John Jenkins, an Episcopal priest, officiated at Montaigne, in Natchez, Miss., the home of Mrs. Hunter Goodrich, the bride's maternal grandmother.

title: Ms. Goldstein, Student, to Wed
description: Marianne Goldstein, a daughter of Jeremy and Barbara Goldstein of Elkins Park, Pa., and Richard Alan Feifer, a son of Dr. Irwin and Betty Feifer of Wantagh, L.I., are planning a June wedding.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: I REMEMBER BALANCHINE: Recollections of the Ballet Master by Those Who Knew Him, by Francis Mason. (Anchor/Doubleday, $15.) The author interviewed more than 85 of the choreographer's colleagues and friends, ranging from Rudolf Nureyev to a men's wardrobe supervisor at the New York City Ballet. "This book is less than a biography, yet it catches more of the man than any of the Balanchine biographies to date," Alastair Macaulay said here last year.

title: In Case of Illness or Death: Airlines' Fare Policies
description: FEW letters to this department register more pain and frustration than those concerning flights to a funeral or deathbed of a family member when the fare seemed outlandish. The same distress is expressed when travelers have to cancel their plans because of illness or death and discover that even then a nonrefundable ticket cannot be cashed in.

title: TALES FROM THE BABY FACTORY
description: As is the case with all developing fields, advanced reproductive technology has its share of unanswered questions, and some practitioners and clinics are more skilled than others. What women need are facts so that they can make informed choices. They need to ask specific questions:

title: How G.M.'s Altered Personality Saved Opel
description: When the 1980's dawned, Adam Opel A.G. seemed to be speeding along the Autobahn to oblivion. Germany's second-largest auto maker was producing boring, boxy cars that were badly designed and carelessly assembled. Sales were slumping, losses were rising and jokes were prevalent -- for instance, "Pick up Opel's brochure and you can hear the rattle."

title: Some Land-Use History Highlights
description: 1871: The first Tenement Law is enacted, setting a minimum for the amount of light and air reaching tenement dwellers. An amendment in 1901 increasing those standards results in the so-called "new law" tenements.

title: 'Faust' in West Hartford
description: AT 2:30 this afternoon Gounod's "Faust" will be presented by the Hartt Opera and Music Theater in the Millard Auditorium in West Hartford. The production is staged by Adelaide Bishop and conducted by Sidney Harth. (For information call 243-4228.)

title: Little Laughter in "Heidi Chronicles"
description: "THE HEIDI CHRONICLES," the play by Wendy Wasserstein that won both the 1989 Pulitzer Prize and Broadway's Tony Award, is at the Studio Theater in Lindenhurst through May 2.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Football World League FRANKFURT GALAXY -- Activated Billy Poe, guard. OHIO GLORY -- Activated Karl Coles, guard. Hockey National Hockey League ST. LOUIS BLUES -- Recalled Guy Hebert, goalie, from Peoria of the International Hockey League. College NAVY -- Named Don DeVoe men's basketball coach.

title: Peru's Basic Problems Won't Be Ordered Away
description: Outside the ornate presidential palace here, there is a figure of a man on a horse, Pizarro the conquistador. It recalls more of Peru's history than just the subjugation of the Incas. When things get bad, this country always seems to look for a hero on horseback to save it.

title: 'Ritual Journey' of Assemblages at the University of Hartford
description: BETYE SAAR is the latest artist to transform the Joseloff Gallery at the University of Hartford, and she has done it with an installation and about 40 assemblages, large and small. Semi-darkness reigns, except where works are picked out by spotlights or are illuminated from within, and the only thing missing is organ music.

title: Joshua Lerman and Christina Frank to Marry
description: June wedding plans have been announced for Christina Bess Frank, an associate editor at The New York Times Syndication Sales Corporation and a freelance writer, and Joshua Carl Lerman, an associate editor at Skiing magazine, both in New York. Ms. Frank, 28 years old, is the daughter of Mrs. John A. Frank of New York and the late Dr. Frank. Mr. Lerman, 29, is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Lerman of Teaneck, N.J.

title: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.
description: In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.

title: Cuttings; And Mrs. Haupt, Seeing the Garden, Pronounced It Good
description: Enid Annenberg Haupt was having a good time refusing to sit on the rustic garden bench for the photographer. The former editor of Seventeen magazine, now an octogenarian, complained that her elegant green suit did not make her look thin enough.

title:
SPECTACLE;
The Mysteries of Mongolia, Revealed at the Circus
description: Never before have so many Mongols come to the United States. But this is not a band of naifs from the remote aimaks, or counties, moving in one great leap from life in yurts, the conical felt huts of Mongolia, into the glitter of New York. Most of these stars of the 122d edition of Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey Circus have trained for years in the circus schools of Mongolia and the former Soviet Union. They have toured Eastern and Western Europe and some of the countries of Asia. And they are, in a word, professionals -- as at home in the center ring of Madison Square Garden as any of their peers.

title:
DANCE;
Rutgers to Revive 15 Multimedia Works
description: MODERN dance, once coolly received elsewhere, has almost always found a warm welcome in university settings, and few welcomes have been warmer than the one accorded by Rutgers University to the Nikolais and Murray Louis Dance Company.

title: Living in a Landmark, From Temple to Tower
description: OUR first sight of Shute Gatehouse came in late afternoon. We eased around the corner of a narrow Devon lane to find the 16th-century building sprawled in emerald lawns, turreted and crenelated like a small castle. Creamy stone rose before dark trees, bathed by slanting sunlight like a stage set. Our home for a week.

title: Anne Gillette Plans to Marry
description: Scotty and E. Peter Gillette Jr. of Minneapolis have announced the engagement of their daughter Anne MacGregor Gillette to George Douglas Frederick Cleveland, a son of Kathleen and George D. Cleveland of Wayzata, Minn. A September wedding is planned.

title: Technology; A Celebration of Isaac Asimov
description: I reached the point where I could not bear to read another science fiction novel one spring day during my freshman year of college. It was the height of the Vietnam War and science fiction suddenly seemed irrelevant. I remember that moment now because I had just reread Isaac Asimov's "Foundation" trilogy for the third time. In fact, in the preceding eight years, I had read little else besides science fiction.

title: Business Diary/April 5-10
description: INTERNATIONAL Worry Around the World as Japan's Stock Market Wobbles

title: Paths of Patient and His Therapist Cross on Dark Journey Leading to Death
description: He was a brilliant child who taught himself to read by the time he was 4 years old and was so strong-willed that as a pre-schooler he refused to take a dose of aspirin until he read the instructions on the bottle himself.

title: Spence, Eyestone and Kampainen: the Marathon Men
description: In a race that typified the American style of running, more caution than bravado, Steve Spence, Ed Eyestone and Bob Kampainen ran far off the lead for 22 miles of the Columbus Marathon today, before moving to the front and finishing within 11 seconds of each other to qualify for the 1992 United States Olympic team.

title: Miss Rusling Has Wedding
description: Eleanor Merrill Rusling, a daughter of Thomas G. Rusling and Dr. Ellen G. Rusling of Pittsford, N.Y., was married yesterday to William Adolph Lampeter, the son of Albina Poje Lampeter and the late Adolph Lampeter of Annandale-on-Hudson, N.Y. The Rev. Winifred Collin officiated at St. Paul's Episcopal Church in Rochester, assisted by the Rev. James Callan, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: An Elusive Butterfly
description: To the Editor:

title: Isn't That Spatial?
description: POSTMODERNISM Or, The Cultural Logic of Late Capitalism.By Fredric Jameson.Illustrated. 438 pp. Durham, N.C.:Duke University Press.Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $19.95.

title: Election-Year Gridlock Fouls Washington Mood
description: So far this year, Congress and President Bush have made one important law, enacting a second extension of unemployment benefits. The rest of the time they have been exchanging partisan insults and political declarations, sometimes in the form of bills and veto messages.

title: Six Different Maggies
description: NOT THE END OF THE WORLD By Rebecca Stowe.151 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $18.

title: State and Federal Efforts Aim to Protect Sturgeon
description: MILLIONS of sturgeon once lived in the Connecticut River, but the river's Atlantic and shortnose sturgeons were slaughtered during the 19th century for their valuable roe, which was used for caviar. Only about 1,000 of the fish remain. And while Federal law protects the Connecticut River sturgeon from fishermen, biologists say the species continues to decline in the river, due to dredging, road and bridge construction, pollution and development along the banks.

title: Sarah Deffeyes Has Wedding
description: Sarah Stover Deffeyes, the daughter of Prof. and Mrs. Kenneth S. Deffeyes of Princeton, N.J., and Robert Joseph Gralewski Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gralewski of Wilmington, Del., were married yesterday in Princeton. The Rev. Vincent E. Keane, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Princeton University Chapel.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Cornell; Opposition Blocks Plan to Improve Dorm Racial Mix
description: Faced with persistent student and faculty opposition, Cornell University has dropped a proposal to improve the racial mix in student housing for this fall's entering class.

title: Faking Hospital Records: A Case of Double Jeopardy
description: To people not involved in health care, the issue can appear arcane. Even some doctors and nurses have a hard time believing it is important. But with increasing intensity, Federal investigators and industry regulators are concentrating on a series of little-known meetings so confidential that New York and most other states protect their records from disclosure even by subpoena in malpractice cases.

title:
CLASSICAL MUSIC;
How a 'Serious' Violinist Went Punk
description: His recent recording sold over a million copies and spent more than a year on the pop charts. His every move is chronicled, with banner headlines, in the tabloid press. His outdoor concerts, complete with arena-style lighting and sound engineering, have attracted more than 20,000 fans.

title: Carolyn S. Bondurant Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Clarence R. Bondurant of Martinsville, Va., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Carolyn Stone Bondurant and Timothy Hicks McCoy, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard P. McCoy of Boston. Miss Bondurant, 27 years old, is an administrative assistant at Beacon Management, a real-estate concern in Boston. Mr. McCoy, 29, is a field manager at Colley & McCoy, a family real-estate and restaurant investment company in Windham, N.H. Both graduated from Rollins College.

title: Political Talk
description: Long-Distance Grudge

title: In Connecticut, It's a Whole New April 15
description: Everywhere else, tax season may be routine, but not here. At Connecticut's Department of Revenue Services, the first-ever filing season for the state's first-ever tax on wages is an exercise in controlled panic.

title:
FOCUS;
In Bullhead City, the Desert Is Blossoming
description: JoAnn Allen and Robert, her husband of 40 years, moved to this desert region along the eastern edge of the Colorado River six years ago. If current projections are true, there will be many others who will follow in the next decade.

title: A June Bridal For Laura Oot
description: Mrs. Terence R. Blackwood of Centreville, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter Laura Leighton Van Oot to John Daniel Sheridan, a son of Mrs. Thomas P. Sheridan of the Bronx and the late Mr. Sheridan. Miss Oot is also a daughter of the late Albert P. Oot Jr. A June wedding is planned.

title: Shari Slotnick and Ronald Pillar Are to Wed
description: July wedding plans have been announced for Shari Lynn Slotnick, a daughter of Mrs. Howard Slotnick of New York and the late Mr. Slotnick, and Ronald Scott Pillar, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Robert M. Pillar of North Woodmere, L.I.

title:
DINING OUT;
Italian Fare at Renamed Spot in Armonk
description: IN the pretty space last known as Covington, Bambina takes over with an Italian menu designed to suit all comers. Diners can choose dishes from among six categories, mixing and matching large and small items to satisfy hunger for anything from snacks to full-course meals: spuntini (or snacks that can also serve as appetizers); generous, hearty salads; pasta in half or whole orders; small pizzas; sandwiches and burgers; entrees.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A. Sinking Lakers Can't Get Past the Jazz The Utah Jazz beat the Los Angeles Lakers, 93-90, in Inglewood, Calif., yesterday, further jeopardizing the Lakers' streak of 15 consecutive seasons in the playoffs. Los Angeles began the day a half-game behind Houston for the eighth and final Western Conference playoff spot. Utah, which won its third straight game, clinched playoff spots for Seattle and San Antonio with the victory. Karl Malone gave Utah a 91-90 lead with 43 seconds left. Eldon Campbell then missed a short jumper, and Mark Eaton scored on a dunk for a 93-90 lead with 11.5 seconds left. Malone blocked A. C. Green's 3-point attempt with 3.6 seconds left. (AP) Trail Blazers 113, Sonics 106: Portland's Terry Porter scored 14 of his 27 points in the fourth quarter of the Friday night game. Portland led by 2 with 3 minutes 33 seconds left in the game before Clyde Drexler and Porter scored all of the Trail Blazers' points in a 9-2 run that gave them a 109-100 lead with 1:27 left. (AP)

title: For Design and for Nature
description: MONDAY -- The National Museum of Fashion at the Fashion Institute of Technology previewed an exhibition of the clothes of 36 black designers. The show, called "Tribute to the Black Fashion Museum," begins with designs by Ann Lowe, who made Jacqueline Bouvier's dress for her wedding to John F. Kennedy. It ends with a group of rap-inspired clothes from Cross Colors, a California design house. The styles are from designers, clients, the Black Fashion Museum in Harlem and the Fashion Institute. The exhibition runs through May 2.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Brown; Codes and Classes On Sex Offenses Draw Praise
description: In the fall of 1990, Brown University here gained notoriety when a so-called rape list - graffiti naming alleged rapists - was found on the walls of a campus bathroom. As a result, the university adopted procedures to deal with sexual assault and harassment on campus. Those procedures are now winning praise.

title: Data Update
J. Edgar Hoover, Literary Critic
description: ALIEN INK The FBI's War on Freedom of Expression. By Natalie Robins. Illustrated. 495 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company.

title: Rough Landing
description: A private plane bearing Yasir Arafat and a dozen bodyguards crash-landed in a remote corner of Libya last week after it was caught aloft in a desert sandstorm. For half a day, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization was out of contact with the world, leaving governments concerned with the Middle East to speculate on the implications of Mr. Arafat's fate, whatever it was. When the plane was found, its three-member flight crew was dead, a half-dozen of Mr. Arafat's bodyguards had been injured, and the P.L.O. chairman had suffered some cuts and bruises. There was rejoicing among Palestinians in the Occupied Territories, but P.L.O leaders said that Mr. Arafat's accident underscored the need for designating a line of succession within the organization, at the very least. "I think Arafat has probably concluded many things from this accident, too," said Bassam Abu Sharif, a senior political adviser to Mr. Arafat. "For example -- God forbid -- if he dies, what then?"

title: Lucy Buxton Wed in South
description: Lucy Wilson Buxton, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Julian T. Buxton Jr. of Charleston, S.C., was married yesterday to Lewis Alan Lukens, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alan W. Lukens of Chevy Chase, Md. The Rev. William Skilton officiated at Grace Episcopal Church in Charleston.

title: Amy L. Gaudry and Pierre R. Dulin Married
description: Amy LaRue Gaudry, a daughter of Charles L. Gaudry of Jacksonville, Fla., and Margaret McClain of Louisville, Ky., was married yesterday to Pierre R. Dulin, the son of Santiago Rodriguez Merino and Nicole Dulin of Madrid. The Rev. William Starkey performed the ceremony at St. Thomas Episcopal Church in White Sulphur Springs, W.Va.

title: Competing for Shoppers: Coupons Proliferate
description: IF it takes longer to get through the supermarket lines these days, it is because more people are using coupons. And they have more coupons to choose from as marketers compete more than ever for customers.

title: Yvette Jacob To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans have been announced for Yvette K. Jacob, a director of folk art for Ann Jacob Galleries in New York and Atlanta, and David Andrew Schorsch, a partner in the New York antiquities firm of David A. Schorsch.

title:
FORUM;
Accelerating G.M.'s Pace of Change
description: The General Motors board of directors startled Wall Street, the automotive industry and, perhaps most of all, G.M. management last Monday when it demoted the company's president, Lloyd Reuss, and chief financial officer, Robert T. O'Connell, removed Robert Stempel as chairman of the board's executive committee and eliminated two of management's six seats on the board.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Brown Renews His Battle Against the Moonbeam
description: Is Edmund G. Brown Jr. being followed by a moonbeam shadow?

title: Deborah Sager Plans to Marry
description: Deborah J. Sager, a daughter of Jerome I. Sager of New York and the late Marilyn Sager, is engaged to Norman D. Birnbach, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maks L. Birnbach of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Africa Without Eye Cream
description: LAST year I came face to face with the "African Problem." We had saved since our wedding for a fifth anniversary trip to Kenya. I suddenly realized my greatest dream also involved my worst nightmare -- it's not that there are no bathrooms in Kenya, there are just no bathrooms on baby planes, game drives or hot air balloons.

title: When Presidential Slogans Meet the Realities of Government; And Vice Presidents?
description: To the Editor:

title: Patricia Gilligan Has Wedding
description: Patricia Elizabeth Gilligan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James R. Gilligan of Manasquan, N.J., was married yesterday to John Emmet White, a son of Mrs. John H. Keating Jr. of Rumson, N.J., and the late Dr. Richard L. White. The Rev. Robert Burke officiated at St. Catharine's Roman Catholic Church in Spring Lake, N.J.

title: The Executive Computer; Hot New Portables: Great Features, Wide Price Range
description: Several impressive portable computers have come to market in recent weeks, including the first widely available models with color displays.

title: In the Region: Connecticut and Westchester; Affordable Housing Law Brews a Storm
description: A RISING storm has begun to swirl around Connecticut legislation that was designed to shift some of the responsibility for affordable housing from overburdened cities to the suburbs. The law is aimed at towns in which fewer than 10 percent of the dwellings are classified as affordable.

title: POINT COUNTERPOINT ON I.B.M.
description: In an article on the Forum page on March 22, Webster Brown, a former engineer with International Business Machines Corporation, wrote about his 26 years with I.B.M.

title:
Your Own Account;
Which Health Care Plan Will Pay?
description: Over the last several years, the rules used to coordinate health benefits between working spouses have grown so complex that even those who design the plans say they have trouble deciding what to do about their own benefits. Unfortunately, if you do not bother to grapple with the rules, you may wind up paying for unnecessary coverage or going without coverage you thought you had.

title: Andrea Heil to Wed Robert L. Sand
description: Andrea Lauren Heil, a reporter for The Valley News in Lebanon, N.H., and Robert Leonard Sand, a state prosecutor in Windsor County, Vt., are planning a June wedding.

title: Where Parents Can Find New Horizons
description: SEATED on children's chairs in the kindergarten of the Fanny Meyer Hillers School here, 17 parents listened raptly as Maxine Soren, a speech and language specialist, talked to them about educating and communicating with their children.

title: Carter Lee Wed To Peter Maas
description: Carter Ridgely Lee, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Preston P. Lee of Chatham Township, N.J., was married yesterday to Peter Louis Maas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis I. Maas of Scotia, N.Y. The Rev. Roger Dunnavan officiated at First Presbyterian Church in Haddonfield, N.J.

title: Review/Dance; Two Major Revivals By Juilliard Ensemble
description: The Juilliard Dance Ensemble does more than provide students of the Juilliard Dance Division with theatrical experience. It contributes to the entire dance community by offering world premieres and important revivals.

title: Knights Coach Who Can Do More
description: The World League takes chances -- hiring the kinds of people the National Football League often did before it fell in love with its image on the TV screen.

description: To the Editor:

title: Small Sigh of Relief on School Aid
description: MANY local school officials and state legislators expressed relief last week that cuts in state aid to education were not as bad as they could have been and not nearly as steep as in the past.

title: Francesca Grifo Plans to Wed
description: Judge Richard D. Grifo and Leonarda T. Grifo of Easton, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter Dr. Francesca Theresa Grifo to William James Hahn, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James Hahn of St. Louis. A September wedding is planned.

description: LIKE many shopping centers of its vintage, the Galleria at White Plains has begun to show its years. The 880,000- square-foot enclosed mall in the heart of this urban downtown area is due for a face lifting, say its owners, who are planning to spend $8 million on the project.

title: THE ORACLE OF CROWN HEIGHTS
description: Specter writes that the Hasidic men and women of Crown Heights live in a setting that grafts "the 18th century onto the 21st." In fact, our lives here are high-tech, but our morals are indeed "18th-century." Counted among our problems are not unwed mothers, teen-agers on drugs, suicides, wife-swapping, AIDS and so on.

title: Campaign Tries to Find Arsonists at Early Age
description: A FIRE rages, and firefighters rush to the scene. In the shadow of a nearby tree, a child watches wide eyed. He wears a plastic fireman's hat and clutches a teddy bear. Is he an innocent onlooker, or did he start the fire?

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York

title: IN SHORT: FICTION
description: NET OF JEWELS By Ellen Gilchrist.Little, Brown, $21.95.

title: Thoroughly Modern Maestro
description: Most days in midwinter, a stocky, still-young man can be seen hurrying out of the new Symphony Hall in Birmingham, England, on his way to a late and often rapid lunch in the neighboring Hyatt Regency.

title: Face Lift for Galleria in White Plains
description: LIKE many shopping centers of its vintage, the Galleria at White Plains has begun to show its years. The 880,000- square-foot enclosed mall in the heart of the city's urban downtown area is due for a face lifting, say its owners, who are planning to spend $8 million on the project.

title: Social Events
description: Equity Fights AIDS

title: Nets Play Nearly Perfectly In Their Run for Playoffs
description: On March 28, after the Nets let the Golden State Warriors escape from Byrne Arena with a 153-148 overtime victory, Coach Bill Fitch said that if his team was going to make the playoffs for the first time since 1986, it would have to win its next 12 games, which meant a perfect run for the rest of the regular season.

title: Rodman Writes His Name All Over Backboard
description: Chuck Daly recalled the 1986 National Basketball Association draft, the one that brought Dennis Rodman and John Salley to the Detroit Pistons. Daly had already been the Pistons' coach for three years and had managed to give the franchise its first-ever consecutive winning seasons. Still, the Pistons in 13 playoff appearances before the arrival of Rodman and Salley had advanced past the first round only four times and had never won a championship.

title: Other Views On Animal Rights
description: Angi Metler's response to a question concerning animal testing reveals the scientific naivete of the animal rights activists (New Jersey Q & A, "A Leader in the Battle for Animal Rights," March 22).

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan; Committee Urges University to Open Doors for Women
description: While women constitute nearly half of the undergraduate population and three-quarters of the staff at the University of Michigan, they fill only one-fifth of all faculty positions, according to a report from the special committee created by the university's president to review the matter.

title: Camera
description: "Change, change, change," is coming at the Image Bank, a New York picture agency acquired by the Eastman Kodak Company last fall. Those are the words of Pete Turner, a longtime photographer for the agency, which specializes in stock pictures used in commercial photography.

title: Salmon Fishing Greatly Limited But Not Banned
description: After four days of often emotional testimony on the dwindling runs of Pacific salmon, a Federal panel late Friday rejected a proposal to ban all ocean salmon fishing and decided to allow a limited season this year.

title: 'You Can't Do It!' I Shouted 'Oh, Can't I?' She Shouted Back
description: THE first time I was written about I was overjoyed. I was a 10-year-old Chicago street urchin in the 1930's, and Max Siegel (no kin), a youth counselor at my local boys' club, put me and some of my gang in his novel, "Boys' Club." He gave us different names, or perhaps used our noms-de-guerre. I was called "Rocky" after a frayed, faded red-and-blue Rockets Athletic Club team sweater I wore everywhere I went, including to sleep. Our bunch of wet-nosed little toughies made a special expedition to a Michigan Avenue bookshop opposite the Art Institute where we stood staring in awe at Mr. Siegel's novel placed prominently on a window rack. Golly, this was fame. I talked about nothing else for weeks.

title: Words Spell Success for Comedian
description: "I LOVE words," Larry Miller said. "I love the glory and power of words, the shape and the texture, the rhythm and the tone of words."

title: Susan Kelley Wed in South Carolina
description: Susan Elizabeth Kelley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Austin P. Kelley of Atlanta, was married yesterday to William Mark Conger, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Kenneth Conger of Statesville, N.C. The Very Rev. James Fenhagen, the dean of the General Theological Seminary in New York and an Episcopal priest, officiated at Pawleys Island Presbyterian Church in Pawleys Island, S.C.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bay Shore
description: BAY SHORE is a hamlet of wealth alongside poverty -- of mansions on the Great South Bay waterfront a mile from low-income housing. Like many Long Island communities, its downtown was hard hit in the early 1960's by the opening of nearby shopping malls.

title: Miss O'Hearn Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Walter D. O'Hearn Jr. of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter Meghan Patrick O'Hearn to Douglas Brainard Benedict, a son of Julia Barber Benedict of St. Louis and Charles B. Benedict of New York. A September wedding is planned.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. DAVID SCHONFELD;
'Many Children Confuse AIDS With Cancer'
description: MOST children are aware of AIDS, yet few have any real understanding of what it is, who gets it and why. Dr. David Schonfeld, a behavioral pediatrician at the Yale School of Medicine, recently directed a study intended to measure the level of understanding about AIDS among elementary school children. Most, he found, knew about AIDS but had difficulty differentiating the disease from others, including colds and cancer.

title: The Quest for a New Zoning Plan
description: THERE may never be a better time to overhaul the Zoning Resolution that governs the physical evolution of New York City. But that does not mean that it will -- or can -- be changed.

title: Local United Way Trying to Provide Answers
description: "IN the light of all the excesses I've been reading about, I'd think twice now about giving to United Way," Selma Crowe of Harrison, the owner of a mail-order gift business, said recently. "I always assumed most of the money they collected went to help the needy, not to make their executives rich."

title: Abroad at Home; The British Message
description: Any Democrat who thinks it will be easy to beat George Bush because this country is in a recession should look at the British election results. Economic misery is worse in Britain and has been going on far longer. Yet the Conservatives, in power for 13 years, won again.
