description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $ 1,954,000 from a cumulative effect of change in accounting for post retirement benefits other than pensions and a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,569,000.

title: Burger King to Sell Distribution Unit
description: The Burger King Corporation has agreed to sell its in-house distribution business, Burger King Distribution Services, to the Onex Corporation, a conglomerate based in Toronto. The distribution services company distributes food and paper products to all of the Burger King-owned restaurants in the United States.

title: Boy Impaled During Game
description: An 8-year-old boy was accidentally impaled in the forehead with a curtain rod last night during a mock sword fight with a playmate on a Queens street, the police said. The boy, who was not immediately identified, underwent surgery at Mary Immaculate Hospital and was in critical condition, said Officer Andrew McInnis, a police spokesman. The accident occurred as the two boys, both 8, played with the curtain rods on a Jamaica street about 7:15 P.M., Officer McInnis said.

title: East European Bank Is Split on Its Future
description: The London-based bank established to foster private investment in Eastern Europe agreed today to study an expansion of its role there, but put off any decision on broadening its financing abilities, after sharp United States objections.

title: Gauging Threat of Recalcitrant TB Patients
description: Milton A. Ellison is considered a walking public health threat.

title: Pentair Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: D'Amato Paid 41% of Income Toward Taxes WASHINGTON, April 13
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato and his wife paid 41 percent of their income in taxes last year, according to joint returns released today. They gave 1.6 percent of their earnings to charity.

title: Dekalb Genetics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Stich Has to Work to Win Opening Match Michael Stich, the current Wimbledon champion, struggled to beat Chang Eui Jong of South Korea, 7-6 (7-4), 6-3, yesterday in the opening round of the Salem Open in Hong Kong. Stich, ranked fifth in the world and seeded second, was eliminated in the first round last year and needed all his experience to beat Chang, ranked No. 315. The South Korean pressured Stich in the first set and led by 6-5, but the German won the next game and the tie breaker. Top-ranked Jim Courier and Michael Chang, ranked sixth and seeded third, play their first matches today. (AP) Russians Eliminated: In Nice, France, two Frenchmen upset seeded Russians in the opening round of the Philips Open. Fabrice Santoro defeated third-seeded Andrei Chesnokov, 6-3, 0-6, 6-3, and Thierry Champion beat No. 4 Andrei Cherkasov, 6-4, 6-1. Today, Bjorn Borg is scheduled to play Olivier Delaitre of France. (AP) Korda Is Upset: Top-seeded Petr Korda of Czechoslovakia was beaten by 125th-ranked Claudio Mezzadri of Switzerland, 6-3, 4-6, 6-3, in the first round of the U.S.T.A. Men's Clay Courts of Tampa (Fla). Mezzadri, off the tour for a year after suffering knee injuries in 1989, used a break in the second game of the final set to take control against the 10th-ranked Korda. (Reuters)

title: Organ Donor Babies Can Turn Death Into Life; What Is Essential
description: To the Editor:

title: Ford Plans $3 Billion Outlay To Raise Production Levels
description: The Ford Motor Company announced a $3 billion investment in new machinery and plant space today, some of which will be used to build a new mini-van in late 1993. When auto sales were brisk in the 1980's, Ford was tightly constrained by too little production capacity, and today's announcement is a step to correct that problem.

title: Sports of The Times; Looie's Final Buzzer
description: LOU CARNESECCA from Queens said goodbye to basketball yesterday, and it took a considerable amount of air out of the ball around here.

title: Winnie Mandela's Rise and Fall
description: The unraveling of the old order was the undoing of one of its most passionate adversaries. In the end, unable to adjust to change, Winnie Mandela could no longer be a hopeful symbol of the future, remaining instead a painful symptom of the past.

title: New York City to Hold Gay Games in 1994
description: New York City is to hold Gay Games IV in 1994, an amateur sporting competition that is expected to draw as many as 15,000 athletes from 40 countries, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday.

title: Baseball; Amazin' Yankees (6-0) Win Battle of Unbeatens
description: Circle this date on your calendar. Circle it again. The Yankees are in first place, and they are the only undefeated team remaining in the major leagues. This is no joke. Maybe you should circle it once more.

title: Trenton Legislature Debates Plan to End Highway Tolls
description: The Republican majority in the Legislature unveiled a proposal today to eliminate tolls on both the New Jersey Turnpike and the Garden State Parkway, upstaging Gov. Jim Florio, who has suggested removing tolls only from the Garden State.

title: Westchester to Buy Land for Preservation
description: Ending 13 years of lawsuits, countersuits and negotiations, Westchester County lawmakers today tentatively agreed to acquire the Rye birthplace of John Jay, the nation's first chief justice, for up to $11.5 million.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article and a picture caption on Saturday about California's senatorial primary referred incorrectly in some copies to the Senate seats sought by Dianne Feinstein, the former Mayor of San Francisco, and Representative Barbara Boxer. Ms. Feinstein is running for the two-year term and Representative Boxer the six-year term.

title: Salem Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MANDELA DIVULGES BREAK WITH WIFE
description: In a voice reflecting tenderness and regret, Nelson Mandela, the president of the African National Congress, announced today that he and his wife of 33 years, Winnie Mandela, had agreed to separate.

title: Ameritech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest quarter earnings included a $ 28 million increase, or 10 cents a share, resulting from interest income on an Internal Revenue Service settlement.

title: E-Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings include average shares outstanding and the effect of dilutive options outstanding.

title: YELTSIN'S CABINET THREATENS TO QUIT IN CONGRESS FEUD
description: President Boris N. Yeltsin's entire Cabinet formally offered to resign today unless an unexpectedly aggressive Parliament halted efforts to scale back the Government's program of economic reform.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Health; Laryngitis Silences Clinton Another Day
description: A common occupational hazard for politicians, chronic laryngitis from speaking too much, forced Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas to cancel a major economic address he had planned to give Tuesday in Pennsylvania, his staff said tonight.

title: Hotels as Well as Amusements Use Fantasy at Euro Disneyland
description: The Walt Disney Company is known for Mickey Mouse and Magic Kingdoms. But in recent years it has also become an aggressive and, despite a reputation for fierce budgetary control, affluent patron of post-modern architecture. That policy has been pursued eagerly in the new Euro Disneyland here.

title: Grappling With the Care Of Problem TB Patients
description: Public health officials and legal experts say that dealing with problem patients is harder now than it was when tuberculosis was a leading killer of Americans earlier this century. There are, they say, two reasons: lack of adequate institutions for the long-term supervision of patients and changes in constitutional law that have placed greater importance on the rights of an individual and made confinement less acceptable.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Week; Bush and Clinton Share Win-at-All-Cost Image
description: With white eyes, black teeth and a porcupine shaft of hair, Bill Clinton stares ferally from the cover of this week's Time magazine.

title: In Liberia's Illusory Peace, Rebel Leader Rules Empire of His Own Design
description: Only the legions of edgy and heavily armed guards at checkpoints leading to this sleepy village give any hint of the grand ambitions envisioned here. For if the guerrilla leader Charles Taylor has his way, this remote outpost will become the strategic center of a vast military and administrative empire.

title: Peter H. Knapp, 75, Psychiatrist Noted in Psychosomatic Medicine
description: Dr. Peter Hobart Knapp, a Massachusetts psychiatrist noted for his research in psychosomatic medicine, died last Tuesday at his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: Organ Donor Babies Can Turn Death Into Life
description: To the Editor:

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Bankers Trust New York Corp. filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission for a shelf offering of up to $1 billion in debt securities. * Burlington Resources Inc., Seattle, filed for a shelf offering of up to $400 million in debt securities.

title: Consumer Chief Urges Rise In Fines for Business Fraud
description: Saying the New York City Department of Consumer Affairs needs a bigger stick to enforce consumer-protection laws, Commissioner Mark Green yesterday called for increases in the fines his agency levies.

title: Quake Theory Attacks Prevailing Wisdom On How Faults Slip and Slide
description: TAKING a tip from carpet layers and tire designers, a number of eminent seismologists are challenging the basic theory of how earthquake faults behave.

title: New Duties Familiar To Treasury Nominee
description: When he becomes Under Secretary of the Treasury, Jerome H. Powell will carry on much of the work he did in his previous position as Assistant Treasury Secretary for domestic finance. Mr. Powell, who was nominated on Thursday by President Bush, has been deeply involved in developing and pushing the Administration's banking bill, which has yet to receive Congressional approval. As Assistant Secretary, he also oversaw a report that called for big changes in auctions of Government securities after the scandal over improper practices by Salomon Brothers. As Under Secretary, he will oversee domestic finance, economic policy and the public debt bureaucracy.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center Alice Tully Hall

title: Bridge
description: An aspect of practical play that has received insufficient attention concerns opponents' errors. A clever player can sometimes encourage the enemy to miss the best route.

title: Chicago's Loop Is Closed Down As River's Water Floods Tunnels
description: All business halted in the heart of downtown Chicago this morning and tens of thousands of office workers were sent home after 250 million gallons of water from the Chicago River leaked into underground tunnels and, from there, flooded into basements.

title: U.S. PANEL SEEKING RESTRICTION ON USE OF DNA IN COURTS
description: A long-awaited Federal report on a powerful new genetic technique for identifying criminal suspects says it should not be allowed in court in the future unless a more scientific basis is established.

title: Stocks Gain in Japan After Monday's Big Fall
description: Japanese stock prices moved higher today after a seesaw trading session. Traders said the market remained volatile, pointing to continued low volume. The Nikkei index of 225 issues ended the day up 202.93 points, or 1.2 percent, at 17,439.58. An estimated 250 million shares were traded.

title: Review/Theater: Two Trains Running; August Wilson Reaches the 60's With Witnesses From a Distance
description: In "Two Trains Running," the latest chapter in his decade-by-decade chronicle of black American life in this century, August Wilson arrives at a destination that burns almost too brightly in memory to pass for history. "Two Trains Running" is Mr. Wilson's account of the 1960's, unfurling at that moment when racial conflict and the Vietnam War were bringing the nation to the brink of self-immolation.

title: Salomon to Sell 42% Stake In Parent of Grand Union
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. said yesterday that it had agreed to sell its 42 percent stake in the parent of the Grand Union Company, a move that would enable the owners of the supermarket chain to try to establish a more durable financial structure after its leveraged buyout in 1989.

title: A Wronged Staff Shows It Has the Right Stuff
description: Amazing. Stunning. Totally unexpected.

title: China's Octogenarian Deng Shows New Gains
description: To the Editor:

title: Patterns
description: No More Skin?

title: 'What Did You Do in the Cold War, Daddy?'
description: The German people have a penchant for introspection. Their history in the 20th century has given them lots of opportunity to practice. No sooner had the Nazi past lost its hold on the current generation, who examine the evils of the Third Reich with a detachment born of personal innocence, than a new cloud descended on the landscape. It is no longer, "What did you do in the war, Daddy?," but "What did you do in the cold war, Daddy?" What did you do during 44 years of dictatorship in East Germany?

title: Fall Collections End On a Brighter Note
description: The fall fashion shows opened in Milan, Italy, last month on a lugubrious note with mournful colors, longer skirts and a feeling that the slow economy through most of the world had deflected interest in new clothes. By the time the last designers had introduced their collections in New York on Friday, the mood and the perception had changed.

title: Talcon L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included a loss of $ 731,200 in latest first quarter from joint ventures in which it holds interests, compared to a loss in 1991 of $ 201,000, which included a writedown of $ 150,000 from investments in and advances to certain joint ventures.

title: Biologists Tally Generosity's Rewards
description: THE baseball adage that "nice guys finish last" may or may not apply to biological evolution, but either way, many theorists find it hard to explain how cooperation, altruism and even self-sacrifice arose in our dog-eat-dog world. But some mathematically inclined biologists have come to believe that clues to this apparent paradox are to be found in a computer game that seems to mimic interactions between real organisms.

title: People
description: * Richard Tompkins, corporate executive vice president of Campbell-Mithun-Esty, was named to the additional new position of chief operating officer in New York.

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Criticizes Peru's Leader But Stops Short of Sanctions

title: PROGRESS IS SLIGHT IN CONTRACT TALKS
description: Executives of Caterpillar Inc. and officials of the United Automobile Workers met here today to try to resolve a five-month-old labor dispute in which thecompany has threatened to replace 12,000 striking union members, but the two sides remained far apart, according to participants in the talks.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Brooklyn Philharmonic Brooklyn Academy of Music

title: Prime Is Cut By Chemical; Others Hold
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation cut its prime lending rate to 6 1/4 percent yesterday from 6 1/2 percent.

title: Talks Halted
description: The Scor U.S. Corporation discontinued talks with Crum & Forster Inc. for the possible purchase of the Constitution Reinsurance Corporation. Neither Scor U.S. nor Crum & Forster, a Basking Ridge, N.J.. subsidiary of Xerox Financial Services Inc., gave a reason for the ending of talks, which were announced on March 27. Scor U.S., is an insurance and reinsurance company whose majority shareholder is Scor S.A. of France. Scor shares rose 12.5 cents yesterday, to $17, on the Big Board.

title: A.T.& T. Plans for Business
description: In an step-up of the battle for small-business telephone customers, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it was adding four long-distance calling plans with 10 to 30 percent discounts for frequently called numbers.

title: All Together Now: Nets Join in Victory
description: Derrick Coleman was back after missing three games because of discomfort from a boil, but it took the Nets all four quarters tonight before they could get in step against the Magic and come away with a 110-104 victory.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "In view of the tensions that have arisen owing to differences between ourselves on a number of issues in recent months, we have mutually agreed that a separation would be best for each of us." -- NELSON MANDELA, announcing his separation from his wife, Winnie. [ A7:1. ]

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about a residential development planned in Brooklyn for the site of the Brighton Beach Baths misstated the date of a public hearing to be held at the Brooklyn Borough President's office. It is May 6, at 10 A.M.

title: Breaking Up Is Really Hard to Do; Scarcity of Judges Leads to Divorce Chaos in Passaic County
description: In Passaic County, marriages that are on the rocks are being kept together, at least in the legal sense, for two or three years after the couple files for divorce. There aren't enough judges to hear the cases.

title: The Price of Peace, Evaded
description: President Bush's vaunted New World Order is undergoing two tough tests at once: on the ramparts in bleeding Yugoslavia, and by election-year penury in Washington.

title: Growing Ranks of Homebound Patients Put Strain on Medicaid
description: To the Editor:

title: Couples Takes a Place Among Game's Elite
description: For even the most skeptical observers, Fred Couples's victory at the Masters fills a void that has existed for more than a decade in American golf. Once again, the country that produced Jones, Hogan, Palmer, Nicklaus and Watson can claim the indisputably best player in the game.

title: Office Depot Inc.  reports earnings for 13wks to March 28
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 138,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: More Turmoil at Yale: College Dean Plans to Quit
description: The dean of Yale College, Donald Kagan, a central player in the university's painful efforts to get its budget in order, announced his resignation last night and warned that "Yale's tradition and greatness" were threatened by the "frenzied denial and defensiveness" of the university's faculty.

title: College Basketball; Carnesecca Steps Down From St. John's Empire
description: Lou Carnesecca, who became a worldwide basketball ambassador at St. John's University despite never having played a varsity game, announced his retirement as the coach of the Redmen yesterday.

title: Pioneer Hi-Bred International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After tax credits of $ 3,910,000 in the quarter and $ 25,054,000 in the 6 months.c-After tax credits of $ 6,896,000 and $ 30,974,000 in the quarter and 6 months, respectively.Sales represented net sales.

title: Organ Donor Babies Can Turn Death Into Life; Humanity of Unborn
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.T.& T. Microelectronics formed a global venture to produce integrated circuit chip sets for low-power, compact digital cellular telephones with Mitsui & Co., Tokyo, and Teknekron Communications Systems Inc. * Bank of San Francisco, San Francisco, entered a definitive agreement for the sale of at least a 51 percent voting control to a private investor group for about $13 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Buckingham Palace could surely use a laugh or two: the latest word from the royal marital front comes from PRINCESS ANNE, daughter of Queen Elizabeth II. Yesterday she filed for an uncontested divorce from her husband of 18 years, MARK PHILLIPS. The couple have two children, Peter, 14 years old, and Zara, 10. They separated more than two and a half years ago.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $ 18.2 million, or 82 cents a share, from the sale of a facility for the quarter and the 9 months is after a charge of $ 165,500,000 from an accounting adjustment.c-Net income

title: Review/Television; Sheriff Ned Blessing, a Onetime Texas Boy Bandit
description: Think things are tough enough already? Try selling a new series to television these days, especially if it's not a half-hour sitcom. The hourlong dramas, we are told, aren't nearly as profitable later, in syndication. Producers have to try harder, sometimes reverting to tactics that not too long ago would have been unthinkable. Consider the case of "Ned Blessing," an 1880's Texas-Mexican border tale being presented on CBS this evening at 9 as a two-hour movie.

title: Moves to Halt Phone Abuses
description: A.T.& T. and Sprint said yesterday that they planned to move against companies that abuse the long-distance carriers' "800"-number service by surreptitiously imposing fees for a toll-free call.

title: Dance Magazine Awards
description: The ballerina Darci Kistler, the composer and choreographer Meredith Monk and the choreographer Helgi Tomasson, director of the San Francisco Ballet, are the recipients of the 1992 Dance Magazine Awards. The awards were established 35 years ago to honor lifetime achievement in dance. A silver bowl was presented to each winner yesterday afternoon in a private ceremony.

title: Charles Arthur Russell Jr., 40, Cellist, Dies
description: Charles Arthur Russell Jr., a cellist, vocalist and composer who was known for his fusion of classical and popular music, died on April 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 40 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Assembly Votes to Extend Building Permits for Years
description: Over the strong objections of environmentalists, the Assembly gave overwhelming final approval today to a bill that would automatically extend local building permits through 1994.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $ 360,000, or 6 cents a share.c-Net loss and after a loss from discontinued operations of $ 15,019,000 for the quarter and $ 16,025,000 for the 9 months.

title: Towns Fear Fallout of I-95 Weigh Station
description: The collapse of the Mianus River Bridge here in 1983 created a traffic nightmare for Greenwich and nearby Port Chester, N.Y., as traffic was detoured from Interstate 95 to local streets. Now, residents fear a reprise.

title: Celanese Canada reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.Results are in Canadian dollars.Year-ago results are restated to reflect increased interest in Edmonton, Alberta methanol operations.

title: On My Mind; Poets of the Gulag
description: In the passageway outside the punishment isolation cells, the Soviet prison commandant stopped to argue.

title: A Shake-Up At Chambers
description: The Chambers Development Company yesterday dismissed Richard A. Knight, its chief financial officer, and moved to replace its auditor in the wake of recent disclosures of unorthodox accounting practices that inflated earnings of the waste disposal company.

title: Topics of The Times; A Hug for Arthur Ashe
description: Just two days after acknowledging that he has AIDS, Arthur Ashe delivered a simple, ringing message to the American people, one well known to doctors but not, alas, to vast numbers of people who shrink in mindless panic from contact with AIDS patients. Appearing with his wife on ABC-TV's "20/20" Friday night, he said:

title: General Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: As previously reported, effective Jan. 1, 1991, the company adopted Statement of Financial Accounting Standards (SFAS) No. 106, ''Employers' Accounting for Postretirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.'' This adoption resulted in a one-time reduction of earnings of $ 1.799 billion, or $ 2.07 a share, and a reported net loss for the first quarter of 1991 of $ 800 million.

title: Books of The Times; An Emigre in Paris Willing to Start Afresh
description: The Italics Are Mine By Nina Berberova 600 pages. Translated by Philippe Radley. Alfred A. Knopf. $30.

title: METRO DIGEST
description: GAUGING THE THREAT OF TB PATIENTS

title: Seeing Genius Between the Dashes
description: FOR today's column, you'd best care about words, literary history, the imperfect process of creative writing and editing, and something as minor as commas. It would be helpful if you enjoy F. Scott Fitzgerald and "The Great Gatsby." But you needn't like italics. Fitzgerald hated -- absolutely despised -- italics for emphasis; he wasn't keen on semicolons either. And Fitzgerald was definitely not the best speler.

title: More Orders For Boeing 777
description: The Boeing Company said today that Cathay Pacific Airways would order 11 of the new 777 midsize twin-engine airliners, with options on an additional 11, for a total value of $3.4 billion. The Hong Kong-based carrier's order brings to 99 the number of 777's for which Boeing has firm commitments from a total of eight airlines; options now equal 86.

title: Just Enough of a Wind Helps Conner Advance
description: Dennis Conner, always the pragmatist until he finds himself losing, said before his sudden-death race in the America's Cup defenders' semifinals today that he was leaving his fate up to the "wind gods." Apparently, they listened.

title: Olympia Asks for More Time
description: Embattled Olympia & York Developments Ltd., declaring itself cash-poor but asset-rich, called on its bankers today to defer interest and principal payments on billions of dollars of debt over the next three months. It also chose Gerald Greenwald, a former Chrysler executive, as its new president to lead it through a huge restructuring.

title: A Weak Housing Plan for Yonkers
description: After more than a decade of litigation, Yonkers, N.Y., still struggles to desegregate its housing. A new Mayor, Terence Zaleski, promised to move the city away from bruising court battles toward reasonable progress. But he now offers a housing plan that would provide too little too late. The City Council, which is scheduled to vote on the proposal today, ought to reject it.

title: New Environment Aide
description: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, appointed Sanford Gaines to the new position of deputy assistant trade representative for the environment. Mr. Gaines has been a professor of environmental law at the University of Houston and a lawyer at the Environmental Protection Agency. Environmental organizations and foreign governments have criticized what they characterize as Washington's lackadaisical attitude toward the environment. Mrs. Hills also appointed David Weiss to the new position of deputy assistant for Canadian affairs.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 AN ULTIMATUM IN RUSSIA

title: By Design; A Comeback for Hats?
description: Will the hat really come back?

title: Ex-Ballplayer Scores by Putting Sports on Screen
description: At the age of 46, Ron Shelton still plays pickup basketball three days a week at the Hollywood Y.M.C.A., only yards away from the office where he wrote "White Men Can't Jump."

title: Tories Seen Softening Thatcherite Free-Market Orthodoxy
description: In their 13 years in power, first under Margaret Thatcher and now John Major, the Conservatives have believed that the best way to help business was to expose it to the rigors of the free market and minimize Government involvement in business affairs.

title: Smith (A.O.) Corp. (A) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Arab League Wants 2 Bombing Suspects To Be Sent to Malta
description: As the deadline approaches for Libya to turn over two suspects in the bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Scotland or face international sanctions, the Arab League has proposed that the suspects be handed over to Malta and that the sanctions be postponed, United Nations officials said today.

title: C.I.A. Chief Says Focus Will Shift to Economics
description: Robert M. Gates, the Director of Central Intelligence, said today that the Bush Administration had directed that nearly 40 percent of the new tasks of the country's intelligence agencies would involve international economics.

title: G.E. Net Rises 6%, Led by Kidder and NBC
description: The General Electric Company yesterday reported a 6 percent rise in first-quarter earnings, which was within the range expected by financial analysts but caused concern among investors.

title: Surging Paychecks on Wall St.
description: After a few years of humility, Wall Street is again seeing its paychecks rising sharply, especially at the most senior level. But now, compensation experts say Wall Street is likely to face increasing pressures to devise more objective pay-for-performance standards for its senior executives.

title: Jennifer Convertibles reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 134,841, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $ 274,348, or 7 cents a share, for the 6 months.c-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $ 11,901 for the quarter and $ 51,845, or 2 cents a share, for the 6 months.

title: Death Penalty Sought in Brooklyn Trial
description: Despite the absence of a death-penalty law in New York State, a reputed Mafia member could face execution if convicted in a Federal narcotics and murder trial that is beginning in Brooklyn.

title: 2 From Hal Riney Head a Design Firm
description: Hal Riney & Partners Inc., of San Francisco, is helping to form a graphic design firm there. The firm, Riney, Bradford & Huber, is led by two agency executives.

title: Bonn Journal; Too Many Capitals (and Knee-Deep in Blueprints)
description: A visitor to Germany these days might be forgiven for concluding that Germans are in the process of moving the seat of their Government from Berlin to Bonn, instead of the other way around.

title: Hudson County Prices Bonds
description: A $135.3 million debt refunding by the Hudson County, N.J., correction facility was tentatively priced yesterday through a group of underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds have a maximum yield of 6.65 percent for a 6.6 percent bond due in 2021

title: August Wilson Reaches the 60's With Witnesses From a Distance
description: In "Two Trains Running," the latest chapter in his decade-by-decade chronicle of black American life in this century, August Wilson arrives at a destination that burns almost too brightly in memory to pass for history. "Two Trains Running" is Mr. Wilson's account of the 1960's, unfurling at that moment when racial conflict and the Vietnam War were bringing the nation to the brink of self-immolation.

title: One Happy CBS Advertiser: Itself
description: When CBS began selling itself to viewers and advertisers as assiduously as any soap or soup is sold, critics complained that the network was demeaning itself through flashy promotions with partners like Kmart. Yet that glitz has paid off.

title: Baseball; Cold Mets Resemble Old Mets As Futility Continues at Shea
description: The comedy, if it isn't yet tragic, is at least fast approaching epic.

title: Review/Piano; Mozart, Debussy and Schubert by Richard Goode
description: In reviewing pianists, there probably should be a very strict ration on invocations of Artur Schnabel. Few musicians could survive the comparison; and even the best might not deserve it. But when a friend mentioned Schnabel's name in Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday night, no comparison seemed more just. Richard Goode played Mozart, Debussy and Schubert with such intellectual focus and grace, I could not help but think of his distinguished predecessor.

title: Aluminum Co. of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Team Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Salem Carpet Mills Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Sales represented net sales.

title: Wieden & Kennedy Gets Ad Age Award
description: After forgoing the selection of an American agency of the year for 1990, Advertising Age has named Wieden & Kennedy of Portland, Ore., as agency of the year for 1991.

title: Therapies Offer Hope For Sex Offenders
description: WHILE few revelations are as chilling for parents as the news of parish priests who have been molesting children, research reported last week suggests that many child molesters are reformable.

title: Microsoft Smooths Some Bumps
description: DEPENDING on which side of the debate you favor, Microsoft Windows is either the best thing to happen to DOS computers since the first PC was introduced or the biggest case of hysterical consumerism since the tulip bulb mania in 17th-century Holland. The truth lies somewhere in between, of course.

title: Off the Rolls -- A special report.; Cuts for New York and Connecticut
description: New York have adopted drastic cuts in its general assistance program as part of its budget this year and Connecticut seems likely to do so. But in New Jersey, which recently imposed stricter eligibility requirements for such programs, no cuts have been proposed.

title: Inmate Given Stay to Argue That Execution Would Violate Rights
description: Just two days before he was to be put to death for the 1981 murder of a South Texas police officer, Leonel T. Herrera today received a stay of execution. The delay clears the way for the Supreme Court to hear the man's claim that the execution would violate his constitutional rights simply because he is innocent.

title: Treasuries Rise in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury securities moved higher in slow trading yesterday, aided by expectations that the Federal Reserve Board would need to cut short-term rates again soon.

title: Cypress Semiconductor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
Chess
description: When a player introduces a daring gambit, the question arises whether its surprise value was uppermost or whether it was a profound concept that might withstand the test of time.

title: Experts Dismiss Flood Threat at Proposed Nuclear Dump
description: A SCIENTIFIC clash over a proposed nuclear dump in Nevada intensified yesterday with the public release of two conflicting reports.

title: Q&A
description: Cavernous Caves

title: School Copes With Shock After Crash
description: The students at Woodland Middle School left a morning assembly today without speaking much. Grade by grade, they walked to their homerooms after hearing that two classmates had died and 27 teachers and students were injured when their bus tumbled down an embankment Saturday on the way back from a class trip to Montreal.

title: Devils, With New Lines, Return to the Good Old Days
description: Coach Tom McVie had trouble recalling the last time his Devils had played as effectively as they did tonight in their 5-1 triumph over the Pittsburgh Penguins at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Black Holes
description: New observations by space telescopes have produced strong evidence that massive black holes are an extremely common phenomenon in the universe, perhaps existing as the violent vortex of nearly every galaxy, astronomers reported last week.

title: Hueytown Journal; Humming Along, and Howling Mad
description: For the last four months a loud hum that comes and goes erratically has bedeviled parts of this central Alabama city, keeping people awake and setting teeth on edge and dogs to howling.

title: Harry Burks Jr., 92, Retired Oil Executive
description: Dr. Harry G. Burks Jr., a retired executive of the old Standard Oil Company in New Jersey, died on Wednesday at the Meadow Lakes Retirement Community in Hightstown, N.J. A longtime resident of Hillside, N.J., and Madison, Conn., he was 92 years old.

title: Key Rates
description: In percent

title: Cheap and Abundant Power May Shutter Some Reactors
description: Nuclear plants that provide 10 percent of the nation's nuclear power may be closed this decade because their operating costs are too high to compete against a rising tide of cheap surplus electricity, experts say.

title: Off the Rolls -- A special report.; The Sorrows, and Surprises, After a Welfare Plan Ends
description: Body odor, ammonia and spaghetti sauce battled for control of the air at the Wheeler Warming Center this week as Anita Robinson straggled in, submitted to a search from a guard in rubber gloves and headed for a mandatory lice-fighting shower.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Who says there's no sense of humor in the environmental movement? Dr. THOMAS E. LOVEJOY, a tropical biologist who is widely credited with bringing the rain forest issue to public attention, will be the subject of a roast tonight. Those who will aim their barbs at Dr. Lovejoy, who is assistant secretary for external affairs at the Smithsonian Institution, are CHEVY CHASE, master of ceremonies for the evening; BRUCE BABBITT, former Governor of Arizona; MICHAEL FUCHS, chairman of HBO; PAUL EHRLICH, ecologist and author, and SCHUYLER CHAPIN, former dean of the Columbia University School of the Arts. Their remarks will be made at a "bow tie required -- black tie preferred" dinner at the Water Club given by the Rainforest Alliance.

title: Aetna Life Is Discussing Sale of Unit
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company is discussing the sale of its American Re-Insurance Company unit with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company in a leveraged buyout that could run as high as $1.4 billion.

title: Baseball; For Taylor, a Few Blots Amid the Blurs
description: Even before the Yankees made pitcher Brien Taylor the first pick over all in the major league draft last June, and before they signed him to a record $1.55 million contract in August, he was thought of as a future star.

title: Protesters Disrupt Brooklyn Board Meeting
description: The first meeting of a reconfigured Community Board 14 in Brooklyn was disrupted last night by a bomb threat and later, by angry shouting matches -- evidence that the racially charged protests that have wracked the board for two years show little sign of ending.

title: Pizza Hut Ends Franchise Dispute
description: Bringing a six-year legal battle to a close, Pizza Hut Inc. agreed to acquire 236 Pizza Hut restaurants from one of its second-largest franchisee, Pizza ManagementInc. Details of the transaction were not disclosed, but restaurant industry analysts said Pizza Hut, a unit of Pepsico Inc., paid $125 million for the restaurants.

title: Morgan (J.P.) & Co. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The net investment securities gains were $ 100 million in the latest first quarter, compared with a loss of $ 14 million in year-ago period.

title: Classical Music in Review
description: Waverly Consort Town Hall

title: Flood Halts Markets
description: Because of flooding in Chicago that affected trading at the Chicago Board of Trade, the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange, all Chicago futures and options tables today on pages D19 and D21 reflect only trading until it was suspended at each exchange. The Board of Trade halted trading at 9:45 A.M., central time; the Mercantile Exchange at 10:45 A.M., and the Options Exchange at 12:30 P.M. Trading in grains on the Board of Trade did not open.

title: Systems That Make Votes Count for More
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A front-page picture caption on Sunday quoting independent voters in the Bronx misidentified the woman shown with Louis Puccio. She was Teresa Cuccio, not Mr. Puccio's wife.

title: Goodyear Sees A Turnaround
description: The Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company expects to report earnings of up to $65 million in the first quarter, compared with a punishing loss a year earlier, its chairman, Stanley C. Gault, said today.

title: Observer; Monkey Business, Anyone?
description: We can have H. Ross Perot for President if we ask him. He is a businessman and a rare example of the species nowadays: hasn't even gone bankrupt, apparently.

title: Swedes in Venture With Scott Paper
description: The Scott Paper Company formed a partnership with Molnlycke A.B., a division of Svenska Cellulosa A.B. of Sweden, to manufacture and market adult incontinence and wound-care products in the United States and Canada under the name Scott Health Care.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Sanitizing Sex -- and Death
description: Recently, a Federal official decided to play it safe. He deleted a chapter of a best seller called "Taking Care of Your Child" before it was distributed to 275,000 Federal employees. The chapter dealt with contraception. The decision to delete it is yet another instance of the Bush Administration's willingness to placate a part of America that refuses to confront elementary facts of life.

title: Butterfly Farms May Be Last Hope of Rare Hunted Species
description: WITH a wingspan nearly half a foot across, banded in black and yellow with iridescent blue patches, the homerus swallowtail is one of the most spectacular butterflies on earth. But its beauty and rarity have brought the gorgeous insect to the brink of extinction as poachers and collectors prowl its last refuges in the remote mountain rain forests of Jamaica.

title: Woman Injured in 50-Foot Fall at Quarry
description: A woman was seriously injured after she fell at least 50 feet from the ledge of a quarry and landed in a rocky ravine, the police said.

title: J.P. Morgan and Wachovia Post Gains
description: J. P. Morgan & Company and the Wachovia Corporation, two banking companies renowned for avoiding loan losses, both announced strong gains in first-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Organ Donor Babies Can Turn Death Into Life; A Question of Anatomy
description: To the Editor:

title: States Sue E.P.A. Over Lack of Clean Air Rules
description: New York, New Jersey, Connecticut and six other states filed suit against the Federal Environmental Protection Agency yesterday, saying it failed to issue regulations that the states need to regulate emissions of toxic air pollutants.

title: Wachovia Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Study Faults F.C.C. Deals
description: Unwary investors stand to be bilked out of tens of millions of dollars this year by unscrupulous telemarketers selling risky investment opportunities in the wireless cable television industry, according to a report.

title: Top G.M. Executives Took Pay Cut in '91
description: Officers and top executives of the General Motors Corporation suffered a 36 percent pay cut in 1991, according to the auto maker's 1991 proxy statement, which was published today.

title: Whitaker Forfeits Lightweight Belt
description: PERNELL WHITAKER has forfeited his World Boxing Council lightweight title because of problems keeping within the 135-pound weight limit, the World Boxing Council announced yesterday in Mexico City.

title: Pro Basketball; Knicks Aren't Panicking Yet, But They Are Counting to 3
description: This week will be memorable for the Knicks in one of two ways: Either they will clinch the Atlantic Division title, or they will let it slip away.

title: U.S. Is Shunning Sanctions Against Peru
description: The Bush Administration continued today to sharply criticize President Alberto K. Fujimori of Peru for suspending democracy to bring order to his Andean nation. But Washington stopped short of calling for economic sanctions to force him to change course.

title: Herman Cherry, Artist, Is Dead; An Abstract Painter and Poet, 83
description: Herman Cherry, an abstract painter who was a contemporary and friend of the vanguard Abstract Expressionist artists, died on Friday, his 83d birthday, at his home in Manhattan.

title: Models of Miami Draw German Shop
description: As a new boom in metropolitan Miami attracts trendy businesses like nightclubs, restaurants and modeling agencies, advertising agencies were sure to follow.

title: DAZED BUT ALIVE, LONDONERS RETURN
description: London's financial district returned to work a bit dazed today, with streets still blocked off by the police and ankle-deep in debris and glass from the terrorist bombing in the ancient heart of the city on Friday night.

title: Laser-Pacific Media Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said final per share results for 1991 reflected an increased number of shares outstanding, resulting from completion of the company's initial public offering of 1,100,000 shares in August 1991 and the conversion of series A preferred stock into 638,821 shares of common stock.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House; Following 'Rose Garden Strategy,' Bush Puts Thorn in Side of Unions
description: President Bush strolled into a Technicolor Rose Garden this morning with the movie star renowned for playing Moses to sign an executive order intended to limit political spending by labor unions.

title: Dinkins Administration Rethinks Cuts in Municipal Construction
description: Under mounting pressure from construction groups, bond dealers and some fiscal monitors, the Dinkins administration has decided that it was a mistake to propose deep cuts in the city's construction spending during a recession and is trying to come up with a way to finance the spending.

title: Barkley Slams Sixers' General Manager
description: CHARLES BARKLEY of the Philadelphia 76ers said yesterday that GENE SHUE, the team's general manager, is "a clown whose only ambition is to caddie" for HAROLD KATZ, the Philadelphia owner.

title: Rematch Is Being Worked Out For Slaney and Budd-Pieterse
description: A confluence of events could bring Zola Budd-Pieterse of South Africa and Mary Decker Slaney to the track together this spring for the first time since their collision eight years ago in the 3,000-meter race of the Los Angeles Olympics.

title: Molex Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represented net revenues.

title: Blount Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-After income of $ 6,014,000, or 50 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of accounting changes.c-After an extraordinary gain of $ 1,205,000, or 10 cents a share, on repurchase of debt.

title: Campuses Find New Ways to Recruit as Fight for Good Students Gets Fierce
description: Dan Riches, a high school senior in Waukesha, Wis., is in a difficult spot. A straight-A student, he has been accepted by both the University of Pennsylvania and Georgetown University and cannot make up his mind.

title: Gundle Environmental Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: * Franklin Electronic Publishers Inc., Mount Holly, N.J., will publish the Handbook of Adverse Drug Interactions as a hand-held CD-ROM electronic book. * Hughes Aircraft Co., Los Angeles, a unit of General Motors Corp., received a $20 million contract to provide cable assemblies for the Boeing Co.'s 747-400 and 767 jets.

title: L.A. Gear reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $ 1,456,000.Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.Sales represented net sales.

title: Washington at Work; Lawmaker's Life: Not So Wonderful
description: Here in Big Sur, Representative Leon E. Panetta has long been admired as a champion of fishermen and environmentalists against the oil companies wishing to drill offshore. He is also chairman of an important Congressional committee, by all accounts a serious legislator and, at least by Washington power standards, an abstemious fellow.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Clinton; Mission: Keeping Track Of Those Keeping Track
description: In the view of the campaign of Gov. Bill Clinton, this deceptively placid riverside capital has reporters the way some dark kitchens have mice, and it has called on Betsey Wright to keep track of them.

title: No Headline
description: The durable and highly visible president of the University of Chicago, Hanna H. Gray, announced yesterday that she would retire at the end of the 1992-93 academic year and return to teaching history.

title: Lecture on a Jooss Ballet
description: Bengt Hager, the Swedish dance historian and museum director, will speak on the choreographer Kurt Jooss and his ballet "The Green Table" tomorrow at 2:30 P.M. in a free public lecture at the Bruno Walter Auditorium of the New York Public Library for the Performing Arts, Lincoln Center. Information: (212) 870-1657.

title: Agnico-Eagle Mines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included writedowns totaling $ 80 million in both the quarter and year.c-Included writedowns totaling $ 36.9 million for both the quarter and year.Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Independent; Perot Says He Had Aides Visit an Accuser of Bush
description: H. Ross Perot, the Texas billionaire who is considering a bid for the Presidency, has found himself under scrutiny for investigating the story of a Missouri inmate who claimed that President Bush was part of a 1980 plot to delay the release of American hostages in Iran.

title: AT DINNER WITH: Jane Pratt; Jane's Excellent Adventure: 'Oprah' for Teen-Age Girls
description: JANE PRATT may well be the only talk show host who has had a major fight with her producers over a pair of overalls.

title: Mr. Bush Pays His Campaign Dues
description: Bowing right and punching left, President Bush has attacked organized labor with orders aimed at separating the unions from some of their money. His principal order tells Federal contractors to notify non-union employees that they cannot be forced to contribute fees to a union's political causes. Now, unless a worker objects, some portion of fees paid in lieu of dues goes to support political campaigns or lobbying.

title: Eating Well
description: IT'S the late 20th century and Lucy Ricardo's Vitameatavegamin of the 50's has been replaced by Jay Kordich's cabbage-spinach-carrot juice. Lucy would be so jealous. Mr. Kordich was selling juicers door-to-door and sleeping in his pickup truck when "I Love Lucy" was still a gleam in Desilu's eye. Now he sells Juiceman II machines on television and drives a Mercedes. His book, "The Juiceman's Power of Juicing" (Morrow, 1992), had a first printing of 300,000 copies and will be on the New York Times best seller list on Sunday.

title: Octel Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
METRO DIGEST
description: NEW YORK CITY CUNY PLANS TUITION RISE

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to price $1.1 billion of debentures in two issues today: a $600 million 5-year issue and a $500 million 10-year issue. * Connecticut Health and Educational Facilities Authority is offering $52.6 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds for Lawrence and Memorial Hospital through underwriters led by Paine Webber Inc. Yields on the serial bonds range from 5.55 percent in 1998 to 6.35 percent in 2005, with longer bonds due in 2012 and 2022 priced to yield about 6.519 percent and 6.55 percent, respectively. All the bonds are insured by Municipal Bond Investor's Assurance Corp. and are rated triple-A by both Moody's Investors Service Inc. and Standard & Poor's Corp.

title: Why Economists Shun Deficit Spending
description: To the Editor:

title: Retail Sales Dropped 0.4% in March
description: After rising smartly during the first two months of the year, retail sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Commerce Department said today.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Dixon Coale Philips; Former Mayor, 97
description: Dixon Coale Philips, a former Mayor of Plainfield, N.J., died on Sunday at the Meadow Lakes Health Care Center, a retirement community in Hights town, N.J. He was 97 years old.

title: Picking College by the Aid
description: As a result of tuition increases and the recession, students are increasingly making decisions about where to attend school based on how much financial aid they receive.

title: Oakland Grapples With Murder Rate
description: Increasingly deadly violence that threatens to engulf some neighborhoods and stifle downtown renewal has forced this city to search its collective soul for solutions and has thrust a political hurdle before Mayor Elihu Harris.

title: 2 Wisconsin Agencies Price $124.69 Million in Bonds
description: Two Wisconsin state agency bond issues totaling $124.69 million were priced for public sale yesterday.

title: Insignia Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Tough Day for Borg

title: Boise Cascade reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Cannon Pictures In Debt Talks
description: Cannon Pictures Inc. said it was restructuring its long-term debt and might reorganize its business operations. The Beverly Hills, Calif., film producer said in its Form 8k filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it was negotiating with its primary lender, another financial institution, and other parties concerning the company's financial condition and business relationships.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $ 250,000 for the quarter and $ 1,246,000 for the 9 months.

title: Alan Bond Is Declared Bankrupt in Australia
description: Alan Bond, the executive best known for financing Australia's triumph in the 1983 America's Cup yacht race, was declared officially bankrupt today.

title: Richard Pommer, 61, a Historian Of Architecture in Social Context
description: Richard Pommer, an architectural historian whose writings linked modernist design to its social and political context, died on Friday at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Polaroid Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Polaroid eliminated preferred stock and related dividend payments in a stock buyback last year.

title: American Home Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Helmsley's Last Legal Bid to Elude Prison Fails
description: Leona M. Helmsley's final legal move to avoid prison failed yesterday when a Federal appeals court in Manhattan upheld an order for her to surrender today to the Federal Medical Center in Lexington, Ky.

title: Two Big Drug Companies Had Profits in First Quarter
description: Two large health-care companies reported double-digit earnings gains for the first quarter yesterday.

title: Olympia In Default On Eurobond
description: Olympia & York Developments defaulted yesterday on an $800 million Eurobond issue secured by one of its best New York properties, a tower in Manhattan's World Financial Center, when it failed to make a $62 million interest payment.

title: Centennial Cellular reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Myers Industries (X) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
There's Still Time to Save U.S. Shipbuilding
description: To the Editor:

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Virginia; Clinton Wins Final Caucuses; Vote Is Put at 52%
description: Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas won the second and final round of Virginia's caucuses Monday night, capturing the state's rural vote with the same ease that he took the urban vote on Saturday.

title: Arbour Shrugs at Mark and Coaches On
description: Al Arbour has always been solid and stolid, more historical than hysterical. When he coaches the Islanders in their final game of the season Wednesday night against the Devils at Nassau Coliseum, this taciturn man will set a record that will be difficult to break. But he doesn't seem too impressed with himself.

title: Personal Health
description: WHEN consulted by a patient with crippling back pain that radiates down the leg, a doctor's first thought is that a protruding disk in the lower spine may be pressing on the sciatic nerve. And very often, that is indeed the cause of the pain popularly known as sciatica.

title: Union Agrees To End Strike At Caterpillar
description: The United Automobile Workers union unexpectedly agreed tonight to end a five-month-old strike against Caterpillar Inc. that had left more than 12,000 workers walking the picket lines.

title: Motorola Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 4
description: The year-ago first quarter ended March 30.

title: Review/Theater: Guys and Dolls; Damon Runyon's New York Lives Anew
description: If you have ever searched Times Square to find that vanished Broadway of lovable gangsters, wisecracking dolls and neon-splashed dawns, you must not miss the "Guys and Dolls" that roared into the old neighborhood last night. As directed with a great eye and a big heart by Jerry Zaks and performed by a thrilling young company that even boasts, in Faith Prince, the rare sighting of a brand-new musical-comedy star, this is an enchanting rebirth of the show that defines Broadway dazzle.

title: Marriott Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
Maynard Oil Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 713,274 gain from the sale of property.

title: Most of Apple's Copyright Suit Is Dismissed
description: Apple Computer's long-running copyright infringement suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard was gutted today when Federal District Court Judge Vaughn Walker threw out its central elements in a surprise ruling.

title: International Business Machines Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 2,263,000,000 from transition effect of change in accounting principle, the SFAS 106, Employers' Accounting for Post-Retirement Benefits other than Pensions.Year-ago results are restated for the AICPA Statement of Position, Software Revenue Recognition.Sales for the latest quarter were $ 7,117,000,000, compared with $ 7,312,000,000 for the year-earlier period.Revenue represented worldwide revenues.

title: Corrections
description: Charts on March 11, March 13 and March 26 giving voter turnout and votes cast in Presidential primaries omitted a cautionary label for the figures. All three charts also misstated the turnout for New Hampshire; the second and third charts also misstated that of Massachusetts. All the figures in the charts were preliminary and in some cases were based on estimates of voter registration. In New Hampshire, 62 percent of registered voters cast ballots on Feb. 18; in Massachusetts, 34.7 percent of registered voters cast ballots on March 10.

title: New Oregon Issue's Top Yield Is 6.477%
description: A $52.7 million refunding bond issue by Oregon was tentatively priced yesterday with a maximum yield of about 6.477 percent for an issue due in 2018 through underwriters led by Dean Witter Reynolds Inc.

title: Showbiz Pizza Time Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: The company adopted Statement of Financial Standards No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes, at the beginning of 1992. All amounts have been restated to reflect this adoption.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article on the Company News page of Business Day yesterday about new orders for the Boeing Company misstated the company's Monday closing stock price in some editions. Boeing shares closed at $45.75, up 87.5 cents on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Yonkers Approves Housing Plan
description: The City Council tonight approved a landmark agreement to desegregate housing here, paving the way for an end to the legal and emotional turmoil that has divided the city.

title: Irsay Delivers His One-Two Hunch
description: General Manager JIM IRSAY says the Indianapolis Colts plan to use the first two picks in the National Football League draft on the Outland Trophy winner, STEVE EMTMAN, and the Heisman Trophy winner, DESMOND HOWARD. At least that's the plan for now, although the new coach, TED MARCHIBRODA, is keeping an open mind.

title: Universal Foods Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represented total revenues.

title: Times Co. Profits Rose in the First Quarter
description: The New York Times Company reported yesterday that its first-quarter net income more than doubled. It said one reason for the increase was advertising revenues in the newspaper and magazine groups that were higher than in the 1991 quarter, when they were held down by the Persian Gulf war.

title: Economic Scene; Fly Now, Pay Later
description: WANT to jet round trip to Hawaii for just $149? No problem. Just book 45 days in advance, stay over one Tuesday that is not a legal holiday anywhere in the Southern Hemisphere and complete travel in a month with fewer than 29 days. . . .

title: Peru and U.S.: What Course to Take?
description: While America's firm stand in support of the restoration of democracy in Peru may be laudable, is it practical?

title: CHRONICLE
description: Five years ago, Rabbi HARLAN J. WECHSLER of Manhattan was having lunch at a neighbor's in Southwest Harbor, Me., where he has a second home, when he heard that a woman was writing a book on the Jews of Maine.

title: Public & Private; Rabbit Punch
description: It is a difficult thing to rise up and decry those traditions and symbols that have become national customs. Although it is widely accepted that Mother's Day is a tool of crass commercial interests, a man attacks it (or forgets it) at his peril. Those lone voices that complain about the joylessness of Christmas are silenced by the rum-pum-pum-pum of Muzak carols in elevators.

title: C-Cor Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: People
description: * Kim Corrigan and Charlie Hasser were named to the new positions of senior vice presidents and management supervisors at Avrett, Free & Ginsberg Inc., New York. She had been vice president, management supervisor at Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss, New York. He had been vice president of marketing at American Racquet Co., Mobile, Ala. * John Uusitalo was named general manager at Floathe Johnson Associates Inc., Kirkland, Wash. He was previously an account director at FCB/Leber Katz Partners, New York.

title: First Interstate In Kohlberg Talks
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, the New York investment concern that helped the Fleet/Norstar Financial Group finance its purchase of the failed Bank of New England last year, may engage in similar transactions with the First Interstate Bancorp. First Interstate, the Los Angeles bank company, said it had discussions with Kohlberg, Kravis about the two companies joining to acquire savings institutions and banks.

title: Tenney Engineering Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on sale of property and equipment of $ 305,000.c-Included gains on sale of property and equipment of $ 175,000 in the quarter and $ 170,000 in the year; the year also included a gain of $ 150,000 on sale of securities.

title: Book Notes
description: Sifton and Knopf

title: Officer Filing For Pension In Teaneck
description: Police Officer Gary Spath of Teaneck plans to file for a disability pension on the ground that he is unable to continue work because of the fatal shooting of 16-year-old Phillip Pannell two years ago.

title: More Advice for Doctors: U.S. Guides on Treatments
description: Doctors have no shortage of advice when it comes to treating patients, either before or after the fact. And now a new voice is murmuring over the physician's shoulder, speaking cautiously and softly but nonetheless representing the opinions of experts backed by the Federal Government.

title: John Joseph Weber, 72, Is Dead; Did Research on Psychoanalysis
description: Dr. John Joseph Weber, emeritus professor of clinical psychiatry at the College of Physicians and Surgeons, Columbia University, died on Sunday near his home in Connecticut. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan and Deep River, Conn.

title: Roadway Services Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 23
Incomes of Young Families Dip 32% in 17 Years, Study Finds
description: Young families with children have significantly less money than their counterparts did a generation ago and suffer from child poverty rates that are twice as high, the Children's Defense Fund said in a study issued today.

title: Israelis and Islamic Fighters Clash in Southern Lebanon
description: Israeli troops and militant Muslim guerrillas fought a three-hour battle in southern Lebanon today. Two gunmen were killed and an Israeli soldier wounded, Lebanese security officials said.

title: P.& G. Splits Stock
description: The Procter & Gamble Company declared a 2-for-1 stock split and increased its quarterly dividend to 55 cents a share from 50 cents. The dividend is payable May 15 to shareholders of record on April 24, and the stock split is payable June 12 to holders of record on May 15. P.& G. shares closed at $104.50 each today, up $4.50 on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Mayor of Capital Finds Welcome Wearing Thin
description: Sharon Pratt Kelly swept into office as Mayor of Washington 15 months ago with 86 percent of the vote after promising to "clean house with a shovel, not a broom." The house, in this case, was the debt-ridden, patronage-swollen government left behind by her predecessor, Marion S. Barry Jr., who was convicted and imprisoned for cocaine possession.

title: Tracy-Locke's Chairman to Retire
description: Howard W. Davis, the chairman, president and chief executive of Tracy-Locke Inc. in Dallas, one of the country's largest agencies, unexpectedly announced his retirement yesterday.

title: Training Computers to Note Images
description: Now that computer researchers have refined the art of searching through megabytes of data for a single phrase, their new challenge is developing tools to sort through huge electronic libraries of pictures.

title: Food Notes
description: Easter Sweet

title: Banks? What Banks?
description: In 1989, there was a post-election February surprise: the new Bush Administration announced that it would seek $90 billion to close insolvent savings and loans. This is worth remembering, because we might see another post-election February surprise, this time involving banks.

title: Zaire Resumes Constitutional Talks
description: A new round of talks on Zaire's political future opened here today, centering on the creation of a transitional government until new elections are held.

title: Baseball
description: Two innings. Two miserable innings. Two forgettable innings.

title: Tennis; Capriati Camp Serves A Pink Slip to Slozil
description: She's just 16 years old, but she's the boss. And the repercussions from Jennifer Capriati's personalized agenda, the one that doesn't put tennis on top of her priority list, are taking their toll on a weekly basis.

title: The New York Times Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter's results included equity in operations of forest products group, which had a loss of $ 1,351,000, compared with income of $ 1,609,000 in year-ago period.

title: Kroger Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 21
description: b-After an after-tax loss from the early retirement of debt of $ 30,269,874c-Net income and after an after-tax loss from the early retirement of debt of $ 5,425,748.Shares shares outstanding included the effect of outstanding stock options.

title: Theater in Review
description: The Radio City Easter Show Radio City Music Hall 50th Street and Avenue of the Americas Through April 23 Production conceived by Patricia M. Morinelli and William Michael Maher; directed and choreographed by Scott Salmon; sets and costumes by Erte; lighting, Ken Billington and Jason Kantrowitz; costumes, Eduardo Sicangco and Jose Lengson; musical director, Don Pippin; production stage manager, Howard Kolins; soloist on "Glory of Easter" recording, Marilyn Horne. Presented by Radio City Music Hall Productions, J. Deet Jonker, executive producer; David J. Nash, producer. WITH: The Rockettes, the Radio City Music Hall Orchestra, Joel Blum and Antigravity.

title: CHIEF SAYS PANEL BACKS COURTS' USE OF A GENETIC TEST
description: The chairman of a National Academy of Sciences panel studying the forensic technique of DNA fingerprinting asserted yesterday that laboratories analyzing DNA should be held to higher standards. Contrary to a report in The New York Times, he said the panel was not calling for a moratorium on the technique while those standards were being put into effect.

title: It's Time for Rangers to Lace the Skates
description: If the Rangers needed reminding that this already had been a long, meandering season, then here it was: They were off for Toronto today, in mid-April, to resume their regular-season schedule and to play hockey in that provincial capital for the first time in more than 13 months.

title: Prices of Treasury Securities Fall
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in slow trading yesterday, as dealers were once again forced to cope without the benefit of the Treasury futures market.

description: Revenues represented total revenues.The net revenues totaled $ 658,729,000 in the latest first quarter, compared with $ 474,816,000 in year-ago period.

description: b-Net lossSales represented merchandise sales.The latest first quarter's results have not be audited and are subject to year-end adjustments.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: White House Memo; Bush Makes Habit of Announcements
description: After months of hearing Republican strategists say that President Bush had to demonstrate a mastery of Government programs, the White House has apparently taken the advice to heart -- after a fashion.

title: Owens-Illinois reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax credit of $ 19.9 million, or 17 cents a share.c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $ 300,000, or 1 cent a share.

title: A Vessel Where The Fuel Is Food
description: ASK Kirby Dupuis, captain of the Doc Neher, a 70-foot towboat out of Baton Rouge, La., what the hardest part of his job is, and he doesn't hesitate for a moment.

title: Ford Unveils Cleanest-Running Cars for California
description: California state smog officials and the Ford Motor Company unveiled two new automobile models today that they said were the cleanest-running cars ever approved for mass production in the world.

title: Setback for Apple Copyright
description: Apple Computer's case against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard was dealt a severe blow when a judge threw out core elements. Page D5.

title: Peru's Path Still Terror-Filled As Rebels Defy a Crackdown
description: In this dusty, sprawling shantytown built on coastal sand dunes 10 miles south of Lima, hope soared last week when President Alberto K. Fujimori shut down Peru's Congress and courts.

title: CUNY Tuition Plan: A Big Jump in Cost But a Free Semester
description: The City University of New York is planning a major tuition increase next fall, but the rise is accompanied by a promise that if freshmen make it to their senior year they may attend their last semester before graduation free.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Wednesday about psychiatric care of mentally ill homeless people identified a health-care worker imprecisely. The worker, Carl Siciliano, is case manager of the Neighborhood Coalition for Shelter Permanent Residence, not the acting director of its parent body, the Neighborhood Coalition. The executive director of the parent Neighborhood Coalition is Jonathan D. Meyer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: "The next time you snack on your favorite chocolate bar or bowl of peanuts, remember -- if enjoyed in moderation they can be good-tasting and might even inhibit cavities." -- PRINCETON DENTAL RESOURCE CENTER, a group financed by Mars, the candy company. [ A1:4. ]

title: TSR Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Net loss and the quarter included $ 30,000 benefit of partial reversals of deferred income taxes previously established at higher rates, which related to the change from the cash to accrual method of accounting for income taxes; the 9 months included $ 90,000 benefit of partial reversals of deferred income taxes relating to the change in the method of accounting for income taxes, and a gain of $ 558,000 from the early termination in June 1990 of the American Express Bank Ltd. facilities management contract, which was scheduled to end in August 1991.

title: Laborites to Wait Until July to Pick Leader
description: Britain's opposition Labor Party decided today to hold a special convention to pick a new leader on July 18, about a month later than suggested by its outgoing chief, Neil Kinnock, who is resigning after Labor's fourth straight election defeat.

title: Accounts
description: * The Plaza Hotel, New York, to Opt-X Advertising Inc., Clifton, N.J., for its advertising account previously at Great Scott Advertising Co., New York. Billings were not disclosed. * Sanofi-Winthrop Pharmaceuticals, New York, to Robert A. Becker Inc. , New York, for three accounts from the company's professional products division, with billings totaling $7.8 million. The Talwin NX and Talacen accounts were handled by Hudson Healthcare Communications Inc., New York, and the Danocrine account had been handled by Kallir Philips Ross Inc., New York.

title: Profits Off 82% at Genentech
description: Genentech Inc., the biotechnology concern, today reported a sharp drop in first-quarter earnings primarily because of increased research and development spending.

title: U.S. Pledges to Help Trade With Ex-Soviet Republics
description: The Government plans to do more to help American businesses trade with and invest in the former Soviet republics, but it has not yet coordinated how to pay for the effort, Commerce Secretary Barbara H. Franklin said today.

title: Griping, Without All That Typing
description: Does the nation really need a computer program making it easier for people to gripe about, condemn, or otherwise harass large corporations, politicians, Government agencies, trade groups and each other?

title: Hospital Stops Admissions To Infant Unit
description: A hospital in Livingston, N.J., has stopped admitting premature babies to its special-care nursery, after four babies who died in the first week of April were all found to have had intestinal-tract bacteria in their blood.

title: Genentech reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-12 SANCTIONS AGAINST LIBYA

title: Rogers Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Vista and Carolco
description: Carolco Pictures Inc. and the Vista Organization Ltd. reached a definitive merger agreement. Each Vista stockholder will receive 8 cents for each common share and either a 9.5 percent convertible bond or an additional 12 cents to 81 cents a share. Shareholders will vote later this spring. The merger of Vista, a film and television production operation, and Carolco is to be completed this summer.

title: Books of The Times; Healing a Mind and Spirit Badly Wounded in the Trenches
description: Regeneration By Pat Barker 252 pages. A William Abrahams Book/Dutton. $20.
