description: b-Included gain of $ 3.1 million, or 5 cents a share, on the amendment of the company's marketing agency relationship with American Telephone & Telegraph Co.

title: Utah Medical Products Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Report Says Marinovich Failed Drug Test
description: Los Angeles Raiders quarterback TODD MARINOVICH, who is nearing the end of a drug-diversion program, tested positive for a banned substance in an N.F.L. drug test, ESPN reported yesterday. The cable network said Marinovich refused to be interviewed but had denied the report through his agent, Tom Condon.

title: Topics of The Times; Highway Uglification
description: In early spring the foliage lining the New York metropolitan area's highways is at its most delicate. Trees and bushes look feathery and fragile as they prepare to sprout leaves. Grass loses its brown pallor, giving way to cool green. Forsythia are fresh and inviting.

title: U.N. Suspends Its Relief Effort in Sudan
description: The United Nations has suspended efforts to feed a million and a half starving people in the southern Sudan because of a new Government military offensive against rebels in the region.

title: There's Still Time to Save U.S. Shipbuilding; Submarine Tankers
description: To the Editor:

title: Accrediting Agency Wins Renewed Federal Approval
description: On the advice of a Federal advisory panel, Education Secretary Lamar Alexander today renewed Government approval of a college and university accrediting agency whose use of a cultural and racial diversity standard had been attacked as discriminatory.

title: Tax Crime, Prison Time
description: Why is it that around every April 15, some celebrity is in the toils of the law for tax evasion? Leona Helmsley, the erstwhile queen of the hotel world, was indicted in mid-April 1988. Convicted and unable to reduce her four-year sentence, she goes to prison on this tax deadline day.

title: Schools Cope With Influx of Immigrants
description: The huddled masses keep pouring into New York City's schools, infusing them with immigrant ambition and novel folkways but also overloading classrooms and straining the budget and the teaching staff.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League

title: Studying the Fine and Less Expensive Art of Dining at Home
description: Surrounded by steam kettles and double-stack boilers, a class of food aficionados gathered around a master chef at his cutting board recently as he filleted a salmon, bone by bone, and lectured on the art of selecting vegetables.

title: Beazer Holdings Sold by Hanson
description: Hanson P.L.C., the British conglomerate, said it had sold the Australian construction and property interests of its Beazer P.L.C. subsidiary for $24.8 million to B. & B. Asia Ltd., a Hong Kong company controlled by Bilfinger & Berger A.G., a German building company.

title: Provident American reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
But Suppose Yanks Pitch Well 161 Times
description: Ah, the vagaries of major league pitching.

title: Enron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included 1992 after-tax gains of $ 10.4 million from the sale of 268,000 shares of Mobil stock.c-Included 1991 after-tax gains of $ 6.2 million from favorable settlement of litigation and $ 500,000 from property sales.The company said all per share amounts reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid on Dec. 30, 1991.The company also said per share amounts reflect preferred dividend payments of $ 5.9 million in the latest quarter and $ 6.2 million in the year-ago quarter.

title: Parker Drilling reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: b-Included $ 1.05 million from continuing operations.

title: Do They Want My Wife To Die?
description: Naomi Weisstein lies on her back in a darkened Upper West Side apartment. Opaque curtains cover the windows; a mask and black lenses shield her eyes, for even a glimmer of light is painful. She has not been out of bed for eight years because she is too weak and suffers excruciating vertigo; she cries out as the bed seems to tip "toward New Jersey." Extreme sensitivity to sound prevents her from listening to the recorded books that once provided sustenance. Plagued by sweating fevers, then shuddering chills, she sleeps only fitfully. Too weak to talk, she communicates by hand signals and nearly inaudible whispers.

title: Watkins-Johnson reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
GTE Profits Up in Period
description: The GTE Corporation said today that its profit more than doubled in the first quarter, largely because its profit in the quarter last year was reduced by costs from its merger with the Contel Corporation.

title: French Angered at Ruling on Nazi Collaborator
description: French politicians, newspapers, human rights groups and a chorus of other voicesexpressed outrage today over a Paris court's decision to drop charges of crimes against humanity against a Frenchman accused of killing Jews in Nazi-occupied France in World War II.

title: Quaintance Eaton, 90, Writer on Opera, Dies
description: Quaintance Eaton, a writer of books and articles on opera, died on Sunday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 90 years old.

title: Police Seek Robbers Of Business Owners
description: A man who pretends to be a building superintendent to get into the apartments of small business owners to rob them is being sought by the police in northern Manhattan.

title: An Unusual Organizer For a Minority Business
description: Someone less confident than Thomas DeRogatis might have thought twice about starting Prestar Partners, a minority-owned investment boutique. After all, neither he nor his partner, John Coleman Jr., is a member of a minority group.

title: Philadelphia Electric In Bond Offering
description: The Philadelphia Electric Company yesterday priced through competitive bidding a total of $350 million of first- and refunding-mortgage bonds, with $200 million in 10-year bonds and $150 million in a 30-year issue. A group led by Lehman Brothers was awarded both offerings.

title: She Battles Leukemia With Laughter and Love
description: THIS is the season of hope. Flowers paint a symphony of color, birds perform the hourly miracle of keeping all those squawking little mouths fed, the religious holidays give us a sense of coherence.

title: Bridge
description: For the first time ever, a top-ranked European women's team competed in the American Contract Bridge League's Spring Nationals. In Pasadena three weeks ago, four Englishwomen who are due to play for Britain in August in the world championships in Salsomaggiore, Italy, performed very well in spite of some handicaps and some slight embarrassment.

title: New Autodesk Chief Was Executive at Sun
description: Autodesk Inc. yesterday named Carol Bartz, a former Sun Microsystems Inc. executive, to be its chairman, president and chief executive. Based in Sausalito, Calif., Autodesk is the producer of Autocad, the leading computer-aided design software program.

title: Theater in Review
description: SoHo Rep Presents SoHo Repertory Theater 46 Walker Street TriBeCa Through Sunday A political satire by Mac Wellman; directed by Jim Simpson; set and lighting by Kyle Chepulis; costumes by Caryn Neman; sound by Mike Nolan; production stage manager, Catherine A. Heusel. Artistic directors, Marlene Swartz and Julian Webber. WITH: Valerie Charles, Kristen Harris, Melissa Smith, Reed Birney, Steve Mellor, John Seitz, John Augustine and Jon Tytler.

title: Donnelly Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: The company said earnings for all periods are adjusted to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split payable April 1 to shareholders of record March 9.Sales represented net sales.

title: Nobody Migrates for Better Welfare Benefits
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Re-Insurance Co., Princeton, N.J., a unit of Aetna Casualty and Surety Co., named E. Michael Joye senior vice president and special counsel in corporate operations. * General Public Utilities Service, Parsippany, N.J., a unit of the General Public Utilities Corp., named Philip C. Mezey senior vice president-system services.

title: Goody Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Board of Trade Remains Closed
description: Futures and options trading at the Chicago Board of Trade remained suspended yesterday because of flooding on Monday that forced much of downtown Chicago to turn off electrical power. In addition, there was no trading in cotton futures or options on futures on the New York Cotton Exchange because those contracts are settled through the Board of Trade. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board Options Exchange reopened, but the Mercantile Exchange halted trading at noon in its currency, livestock and interest-rate contracts.

title: A Model Inmate, and Now a Suspect Again; New Jersey Officials Say Parolee Accused in 5 Slayings Showed No Signs of Trouble
description: Jerome Dennis, the East Orange man accused of killing five women since his release from prison last fall, was a seventh-grade dropout who grew up in one of the poorest neighborhoods in Newark and had run-ins with the law even before his arrest on rape charges in 1981.

title: On the Road to Tripoli: Expect a Detour
description: John Portelli, one of the directors of Virtu Ferries, is preparing for the windfall he expects from the United Nations sanctions against Libya.

title: Goodrich Posts $100,000 Profit
description: The B. F. Goodrich Company said today that it posted a small profit for the first quarter in contrast to a deficit a year earlier.

title: Stop the Butcher of the Balkans
description: Slobodan Milosevic, strongman of Serbia and wrecker of Yugoslavia, may not be as ruthless and reckless as Saddam Hussein. But his aggression against the newly independent republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina has become just as blatant -- and just as urgently requires a stern response. Unless the international community acts against him now, thousands may die.

title: Butler Manufacturing Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
SANCTIONS ON LIBYA BEGIN TO TAKE HOLD AS DEADLINE PASSES
description: Air transport links with Libya were cut, and United Nations sanctions took effect today against Libya for its refusal to hand over two of its citizens accused of blowing up a Pan Am airliner in 1988.

title: Sonic Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: Revenues represented total revenues.

title: Satellite Technology Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter's shares outstanding do not include the shares from the recently completed public offering, concluded April 1, 1992.

title: Corrections
description: The Practical Traveler column in the Travel section on Sunday, about fares for travelers who must make last-minute arrangements because of death or serious illness of family members, carried outdated rules for some airlines as a result of the sweeping overhaul of fare structures on Thursday. Updated information on such "bereavement fares" is planned for May in the Travel section.

title: It Wasn't Easy, but Mets Settle Down at Home
description: There was, in the end, enough offense for the Mets to permit them to smile through their embarrassment. There were, after nine alternately exhilarating and excruciating innings, enough runs to outlast the Phillies.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Candidate's Health; VOICE RECOVERED, CLINTON CAMPAIGNS
description: Gov. Bill Clinton's voice has been hoarse and strained for months, but it was not until he won the New York primary that he had the political luxury of taking the advice any good doctor would have been giving him for months: Shut up.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Weekend on Friday about "Damned in the U.S.A.," a British documentary about censorship in the arts, misstated the broadcast history of the documentary "Tongues Untied." The Public Broadcasting Service indeed provided "Tongues Untied" to its member stations, but many decided against broadcasting it.

title: CSS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
I.R.S. Tries Honey but Still Has Vinegar on Hand
description: The Internal Revenue Service, hoping that more taxes will be paid when fewer people have to beware its jaws and claws, is out to slay its reputation as a Jabberwock.

title: Schnittke's Opera In World Premiere
description: What may have been the most important event in Russian operatic history since the first staged performance of Prokofiev's "Story of a Real Man" in Moscow in 1960 took place Monday night. In Amsterdam.

title: St. John's Open-Minded on New Coach
description: The process of finding a successor to Lou Carnesecca as basketball coach at St. John's began yesterday with the announcement of a nine-member search committee that will recommend a replacement to the Rev. Donald Harrington, president of the university.

title: CPC International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are after employee stock ownership plan preferred dividends, and both the share earnings and shares outstanding are adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split effective April 2.

title: Market Place; Apples, Oranges And Bank Deals
description: IS the Valley National Corporation, the Arizona bank holding company that has been troubled by huge quantities of bad real estate loans, really worth twice book value?

title: Investigator Nominated To Head Suffolk Police
description: Acknowledging that he would have to do more with less, Robert J. Creighton, the chief investigator for the Suffolk County District Attorney's office, was nominated today as the county's next Police Commissioner.

title: Panel Backs Relaxed Rules for Horse-Drawn Carriages
description: Capping the first round of a bitter dispute between drivers of horse-drawn carriages and animal-rights advocates, a City Council committee voted yesterday to expand the hours and areas in which the carriages may operate in New York City, amending a 1989 law that restricts them to Central Park for most of the day.

title: Dow Closes At 3,306.13, A Record
description: Blue-chip stocks vaulted to new highs yesterday, as traders reacted to upbeat earnings reports from a handful of leading companies and sidestepped a futures market crisis caused by flooding in downtown Chicago.

title: INSIDE
description: Yonkers Council Approves Plan to Integrate Housing

title: New York Post Figures Faulted
description: The New York Post overstated its circulation by 60,901, or more than 12 percent, in a report last year to the Audit Bureau of Circulations, according to the organization, which audits newspaper and magazine sales.

title: Lotus Development reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
Southwestern Bell Acts on Account
description: The Southwestern Bell Corporation in St. Louis said yesterday that it would consolidate media buying at D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles in St. Louis, following a review that began with 11 other agencies and media-buying services. D.M.B.& B. also handles the telecommunications firm's advertising account.

title: Prosecutors Depict Vast Fraud Scheme By L.I. Car Dealer
description: A Long Island car dealer borrowed $1.75 billion from General Motors last year to finance tens of thousands of cars that did not exist, Federal prosecutors said yesterday. They charged the dealer with fraud in what one prosecutor called "the mother of all kiting schemes."

title: Amsco International reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
PARENT & CHILD
description: THESE days, when Stephen Elliott's phone rings, he isn't surprised to hear several young girls giggling, followed by a quick "click" as they hang up. The calls aren't for him; they're intended for his 10-year-old son.

title: State Street Boston Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gain of $ 32.6 million, or 88 cents a share, from the sale of credit card loan portfolio.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: Coca-Cola Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rest Your Head on My Building
description: PILLOWS do not have to be square, round or rectangular. They can look like a building.

title: Study Finds Great Benefits In Early Use of an AIDS Drug
description: Researchers have found that early treatment with the AIDS drug AZT can significantly prolong the lives of people infected with H.I.V., the virus that causes AIDS.

title: Ford to Take 50% Share in Mazda Plant
description: The Ford Motor Company agreed in principle today to buy a 50 percent interest in the Mazda Motor Corporation assembly plant in Flat Rock, Mich. The move would draw the two auto makers closer in their worldwide affiliation.

title: Petrol Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Protester at Reagan Speech Had Press Credentials
description: The anti-nuclear protester who jostled former President Ronald Reagan at a luncheon speech in Las Vegas on Monday had press credentials, a circumstance now leading the Secret Service to consider tightening its restrictions on journalists who cover Presidents, Vice Presidents and Presidential candidates.

title: Dow Rises 47.63 to Second Straight Record
description: Stocks rallied again yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average reaching a closing high for the second consecutive day, on a second day of upbeat earnings reports.

title: Cincinnati Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Orchestra; Simon Rattle and the Birmingham Explore Early 20th-Century Music
description: With three concerts at Carnegie Hall this week, the City of Birmingham Symphony Orchestra under Simon Rattle describes the free-for-all that was early 20th-century music. Under the rubric "The Revolution of Expression: 1911, 1912, 1913" these are events intended to go beyond the walls of the concert hall and use the surrounding city to explore the arts and the social climate of an era.

title: Williams Sent to Columbus
description: The Yankees sent outfielder Bernie Williams to their Class AAA Columbus farm team today while recalling pitcher Russ Springer in a move that appears to indicate they have curbed their efforts to trade outfielder Jesse Barfield. The club wants the 23-year-old Williams to play every day and he cannot do that in the majors with the veteran Barfield blocking him.

title: Lake Shore Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Albany May Toughen the Regulations for Bus Drivers as a Result of a Fatal Crash
description: The State Department of Motor Vehicles is considering tightening the regulations that govern bus drivers, already among the strictest in the nation, after a driver with a history of moving violations and accidents was blamed for a crash in upstate New York on Saturday that killed two middle-school students from Long Island.

title: GROWING
description: I ADMIRE the gumption of the common dandelion, getting nuked every spring with weedkillers like 2, 4-D that give dogs cancer if they roll around too much on the lawn.

title: Quantum Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Tyson Is Assigned To His Prison Abode
description: He's a grown man doing a grown man's time for a grown man's crime, but for the time being at least MIKE TYSON will be serving his six-year rape sentence at the Indiana Youth Center in suburban Indianapolis.

title: Cleanliness Is Next to Carburetors
description: EVERY spring brings an upsurge in gasoline sales, as warmer weather gives Americans the urge to hit the open road. While the season usually brings new sales pitches from the nation's gasoline companies, there seem to be more now than ever.

title: Millipore Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter's results were restated to reflect the acquisition of Extrel Corp. in the latest first quarter.

title: Treasuries Drop in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped in slow trading yesterday, as liquidity continued to be drained from the credit market in the aftermath of the underground flooding in Chicago that interrupted futures trading there.

title: New Campaigns
description: * A & W Brands Inc., White Plains, is extending its "Unexpected Spokespersons" campaign with additional television commercials by Della Femina, McNamee Inc., New York, that feature characters from other products' ads. One presents the Fruit of the Loom Gang, while another presents the actor David Leisure, who portrayed "Joe Isuzu" in Isuzu campaigns. * In an effort to promote hassle-free infant clothing, Health-tex is introducing a humorous print campaign that asserts its apparel can ease the pain of parenthood. One ad, created by the Martin Agency, Richmond, carries the headline "Babies tormented by their clothes. On the next Oprah."

title: Creditors Fail to Agree On Alexander's Plan
description: Trade creditors of Alexander's Inc. failed to agree to a proposed deferred payment plan yesterday, further jeopardizing the troubled budget department store chain's viability.

title: Endangered Rock
description: Rock is eating its young. Rock musicians are America's most wasted natural resource.

title: New York Logs 500,000 Jobs Lost Since 1989, a Record High
description: Job losses in New York State over the last three years were worse than they have been for half a century, since records began being kept in 1939, a leading economist said yesterday. But he also reported signs that the pain may be easing.

title: Yields Off Across the Board For Money Market Funds
description: Yields on money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report fell in the latest reporting week, with analysts attributing the decline to seasonal factors and to last week's trimming of the Federal funds rate by the Federal Reserve.

title: Scripps (E.W.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $ 12 million charge associated with the settlement of the litigation involving the Sacramento cable television system. The charge reduced net income by $ 6.3 million, or 8 cents a share.

title: Vance Appeals To Serbs to Halt Bosnia Fighting
description: Cyrus R. Vance, the United Nations Special envoy, called on Serbian leaders in Belgrade today to suspend military actions in this ethnically torn republic. Serbian forces pounded areas occupied by Muslim Slavs and Croats with artillery fire.

title: Third World Economies Shrink Again
description: For the first time since World War II, per-capita income in the third world has declined for two consecutive years, the World Bank said in a report released today.

title: North Korea Shows Video of Atom Site
description: Partly lifting the veil of strict secrecy from its mysterious nuclear projects, North Korea suddenly broadcast a videotape today showing what it described as a series of conventional nuclear power plants, on the same site that the United States maintains is the core of a huge weapons complex.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: Naked City The Marquee

title: WHERE TO FIND IT
description: THIS Sunday's Easter Parade on Fifth Avenue will be nothing like the grand one in the old movie with Judy Garland and Fred Astaire. Still, this is a big season for hats, according to Horace Weeks, who cleans and renovates hats for both women and men at his shop, Peter & Irving, in Manhattan.

title: Amid April 15 Frenzy, Filers Show Sympathy for a Tax Cheat
description: In a minority view of April 15, Thomas M. Bloch said yesterday: "It's a great day." But Mr. Bloch is president of H & R Block, the giant tax-preparation franchise operator, which he said handles about one in seven American tax returns, or about 14 million last year.

title: Morton International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Raids Delve for Evidence Of Illegal Waste Dumping
description: Federal and city investigators raided the Fresh Kills Landfill and a private shipyard on Staten Island yesterday, seizing office records and searching for buried waste containers, in what city officials said were separate inquiries into illegal dumping of garbage or other waste.

title: Parents Also Have to Learn About Guns; Waiting Period Fallacy
description: To the Editor:

title: CIT Group Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary loss of $ 1.4 million on early extinguishment of debt.The company is jointly owned by Chemical Banking Corp. and Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank.

title: All Mum on Marinovich
description: Through his agent, TODD MARINOVICH just says no. Because of policy, the National Football League just says nothing. And the Los Angeles Raiders aren't talking, either.

title: Immucor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Bausch & Lomb reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $ 58,311,000 reflecting the effect of the change in accounting principle associated with the adoption of SFAS 106.

title: GFC Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 613,000, or 3 cents a share, which is related to Verex Assurance Inc., GFC's discontinued mortgage insurance operation. The Verex loss of $ 285,000 in 1991 was charged to a discontinuance reserve established by Dial Corp.The company said year-ago share earnings and shares outstanding are not applicable as the company was a subsidiary of Dial Corp. until being spun-off on March 18, 1992.

title: Census Data Show Boom Before Bust
description: New information from the 1990 Census provides a haunting still life of New York in the glittering and affluent 80's, an ever more cosmopolitan center of sophisticated jobs, rising educational attainment and soaring incomes that had begun to make a dent on the intractable problems of the poor.

title: INSIDE
description: New York Job Picture Bleak, But With Light on Horizon

title: America's Fabrics, All in One Book
description: SPUTNIKS flying across galaxies, tropical hibiscuses and fronds, and Mexicans in front of adobe houses are some of the images in "Fabulous Fabrics of the 50's (And Other Terrific Textiles of the 20's, 30's and 40's)" by Gideon Bosker, Michele Mancini and John Gramstad (Chronicle Books, $16.95). The book, which is being published in May, traces the history of vintage American fabrics to their manufacturers and to their roots in popular culture.

title: In Ad, Florida Group Says State Child Agency Undermines Families
description: A Florida group has stirred up a storm with a publicity campaign attacking the state's main children's welfare agency and accusing it of "kidnapping" thousands of children as part of a plot to "undermine parental authority."

title: AT HOME WITH: John Epperson; A Day in the Life Of Lypsinka's Maid
description: JOHN EPPERSON has a new rug. He's funny about it, his press agent says. So, would you be good enough to humor him and remove your shoes at the door?

title: Winn-Dixie Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Greater New York Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring net gain of $ 11 million on the sale of securities.c-Net loss

title: Inside And Out At Expo '92
description: TO walk in the Saudi Arabian Pavilion at the Seville 1992 Universal Exposition, which opens on Monday, "is to be indoors and outdoors simultaneously," said James Wines, a principal in SITE, a Manhattan concern that designed the the pavilion. Fitch RS, a London design firm, created the interior.

title: Parents Also Have to Learn About Guns
description: To the Editor:

title: Vakhtang Chabukiani, 82, dies; Soviet Ballet Master and Dancer
description: Vakhtang Mikhailovich Chabukiani, a Soviet ballet master and choreographer and one of the great dancers of his generation, died on April 5 in Tbilisi, Georgia. He was 82 years old.

title: Pop and Jazz in Review
description: The Winans Family Beacon Theater

title: Hannaford Bros.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
AMR Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Caterpillar Workers' Shock: Jobs Aren't Ready for Them
description: Although Caterpillar Inc. agreed Tuesday night to take back the workers who have been on strike for five months, it did not say when it would do so. So Jerry Dolan and thousands of other employees who showed up at their plants early today, hoping to put the bitterness behind them, met one more rude surprise.

title: Advanta Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Casualty List Grows, G.O.P. Shows Doubts About House Bank Scandal
description: Only a month ago, Republicans proclaimed the House bank scandal as a great opportunity to retake control of Congress. But now the war cry is beginning to sound more like a whimper.

title: Pace Medical reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Hubbell Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's share earnings were adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend paid Jan. 30, 1992.

title: U.S. WARNS SERBIA IT FACES REPRISALS
description: The United States warned the Serbian-led Government of Yugoslavia today that unless it stopped its assault on the republic of Bosnia and Herzegovina and withdrew its forces in the next 14 days, Washington would press for Belgrade's suspension from a major international organization.

title: Henry Hurwitz, 73; Research Physicist Developed Reactors
description: Henry Hurwitz Jr., a research physicist who worked on plans for the hydrogen bomb and later helped develop nuclear power plants, died on Tuesday at his home in Schenectady, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Dutch Purchase
description: The Dutch sugar, foods and biochemicals group CSM N.V. said it expected to reach an agreement to take over the Dutch vegetable bottler Hak B.V. Hak has sales offices in Germany and Belgium and employs about 355. CSM in February completed the purchase of Eryza B.V., a rice processor, and said the deal was part of a strategy of acquisitions of high-profile brand names.

title: Chief's Son Moves Up At Hospital Company
description: Community Psychiatric Centers of Laguna Hills, Calif., yesterday announced the retirement of its chief executive, James W. Conte, and the succession of his son, the 38-year-old Richard L. Conte. The company, which operates 50 private psychiatric hospitals in the United States, England and Puerto Rico, said the new chief executive planned to emphasize lower-cost treatment programs that do not require hospital stays.

title: Finding the Center in a Rightward Drift; 'You Gotta Believe'
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press on Friday about a minister who resigned as president of the Association of Free Lutheran Congregations misstated his condition. The minister, the Rev. Richard Snipstead, is infected by the virus that causes AIDS; he has not yet developed symptoms of the disease.

title: Bank of New York Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Comerica Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Standex International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Yankees, Mets Tie in Ratings
description: In their first head-to-head confrontation on local over-the-air television this season, the Mets on WWOR-TV and the Yankees on WPIX-TV drew even Tuesday night with Nielsen ratings of 5.6.

title: Hallador Petroleum Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $ 4.2 million impairment provision due to lower oil and gas prices.

title: Nicor Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Consolidated Rail reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Music; Opera Without Singing, But With Scary Sounds
description: John Moran, a 26-year-old composer from Nebraska, jumped into the center ring of the avant-garde opera world three years ago with "Jack Benny," a quirky fantasy in which soloists mimed to an electronic sound track made from fragments of the "Jack Benny Show." His next work, "The Manson Family," peered into the peculiar relationship between the murderer Charles Manson and the members of his cult.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Democrats; Clinton Directs His Restored Voice Straight at Bush
description: After nursing strained vocal cords for a week, Gov. Bill Clinton of Arkansas returned to the campaign trail today, trying to claim the high ground in the contest for the Democratic Presidential nomination. He also sharpened his criticism of President Bush, whom he accused of a "grandstand play" on labor issues.

title: Franklin Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
CHRONICLE
description: In August, Lin Lin, a 34-year-old Chinese artist, was shot to death at Eighth Avenue and 45th Street during an argument with four youths over a portrait he was sketching. Yesterday, his family and friends, along with Chancellor W. ANN REYNOLDS of the City University of New York and 250 others, gathered four blocks away at the university's Graduate Center to open an exhibition of his work.

title: Legality of CUNY Plan On Tuitions Is Questioned
description: In a sign that the City University of New York's proposed two-tier tuition plan may face tough political opposition, the chairman of the Assembly's Higher Education Committee yesterday questioned whether the plan was legal.

title: Overdrafts and Overkill; Capitol Punishment for the House Bank?
description: The overblown House bank scandal has already driven valuable public servants from Congress, with scores more likely to leave. In one poll, an astonishing two-thirds of the respondents say they are inclined to vote against any member who bounced as few as 10 checks, and if there were many such checks, to favor prosecution.

title: Sprint Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $ 36.4 million, or 17 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-After a charge of $ 12.5 million from an accounting change for post-retirement employee benefits.

title: Bulls Top the N.B.A. in Court
description: The Chicago Bulls can do no wrong. They have 65 on-court victories, and now an in-court triumph against an unlikely foe: the National Basketball Association.

title: Republic New York Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tennessee County Offering Bonds
description: A $89.1 million tax-exempt bond issue by Shelby County in Tennessee is being offered to the public at prices to yield from 3.15 percent for an issue due 1993 to 6.35 percent in 2008.

title: Ex-Aide to Dinkins Facing Tax Charges
description: Arnold I. Biegen, the former finance chairman of Mayor David N. Dinkins's re-election committee, was indicted yesterday on Federal charges that he failed to pay taxes on $886,000 that he has admitted stealing from an elderly widow whose estate he was managing.

title: Review/Theater; Shaw's Cultured Class At the End of Its Era
description: The people who gather in "Heartbreak House" are intended to represent "cultured, leisured Europe" languishing before the outbreak of World War I. Complacently removed from anything remotely resembling political or social upheaval, they inhabit a stylish wasteland. They drink tea and exchange epigrammatic insights as the conflagration begins.

title: New York Principals Reach Pact
description: After more than a year of working without a contract, New York City's 3,500 school principals and other supervisors have reached a new labor agreement with the Board of Education that provides a 5.5 percent salary increase, essentially matching features of a pact negotiated by the much larger teachers' union.

title: Rain Thwarts Effort to Plug Chicago Tunnel Leak
description: A heavy rain fell on the city today and lightning flashed across the sky, further frustrating efforts to stop the Chicago River from rushing into an abandoned underground freight tunnel system.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Ambac Inc., New York, said its Health Care Investment Analysts Inc. unit had acquired Healthcare Knowledge Resources Inc., a unit of Thomas S. Monaghan Inc. Terms were not disclosed. * Associates Corp. of North America, Irving, Tex., a financial services company, reached agreement to buy the assets of Signal Financial Corp., from Corestates Financial Corp., Philadelphia. No terms were disclosed.

title: McGraw-Hill Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Coleman's Latest Salvo: Out of My Face, Coach
description: Derrick Coleman may be in better health, but his relationship with Coach Bill Fitch shows no sign of improvement.

title: Chris-Craft Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for 2 percent stock dividend paid April 3.

title: Ex-S.E.C. Official in Unusual Dissent
description: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, quietly celebrated last month when the thorn in his side on the panel, Edward H. Fleischman, resigned. Now it appears the celebration may have been premature.

title: Cooker Restaurant Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Major Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $ 1,547,000, or 22 cents a share, related to the previously announced major center office building transaction.

title: Owens-Corning Fiberglas Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a special charge of $ 227 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting change for the adoption of Financial Accounting Standards No. 106, Employers' Accounting for Post-Retirement Benefits Other Than Pensions.The year-ago first quarter's results have been restated to reflect the accounting change.

title: James Brennand, Bassist, 69
description: James Brennand, a former principal bassist with the New York City Opera Orchestra and a member of the New York City Ballet Orchestra, died on Saturday at Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, N.Y. He was 69 years old and lived in Shady, N.Y.

title: Helmsley Surrenders At Prison
description: Leona Helmsley, the self-styled queen of the Helmsley hotel empire, became prisoner No. 15113-054 today shortly after she flew overnight from New York in her private jet and surrendered at the Federal Medical Center here to begin her four-year sentence for income tax fraud.

title: Audiovox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
Committee Urges Delay in Cloning Lincoln's Genes
description: An attempt to clone the genes of Abraham Lincoln to see if he had Marfan's syndrome should be delayed until DNA test techniques improve and more is known about the genetic cause of the disease, a panel of experts said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Team One Advertising, El Segundo, Calif., said it had decided not to participate in the review for the Sega of America Inc. account, with billings estimated at $65 million. Seven other agencies, including the incumbent shops, Bozell Inc., Los Angeles, and Della Femina, McNamee Inc., Los Angeles, were also invited to participate. A decision is expected by July.

title: Steinbrenner Works Out Deal With Kleinman
description: The Yankee partners are scheduled to meet in New York today amid reports that George Steinbrenner and Leonard Kleinman have reached a settlement of their dispute over Kleinman's lawsuit against Commissioner Fay Vincent and over the $1 million Kleinman contends the Yankees owe him.

title: General Dynamics Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $ 5 million, or 12 cents a share, and after an extraordinary credit of $ 358 million, or $ 8.49 a share, on a net gain from the sale of Cessna Aircraft Co.c-Included income from discontinued operations of $ 7 million, or 17 cents a share.

title: Finding the Center in a Rightward Drift
description: To the Editor:

title: People
description: * Philip A. Forman was named to the new position of executive vice president and director of marketing and strategic planning at Campbell-Mithun-Esty, New York. He was previously president of WPP Group's U.S. Communications unit, based in New York. * Ron Hartwig, 48 years old, general manager of Hill & Knowlton's Los Angeles office and regional general manager for the western region, was named to the additional position of president and chief operating officer at Hill & Knowlton U.S.A. He will continue to be based in Los Angeles. Mr. Hartwig succeeds Craig L. Fuller in New York, who resigned earlier this year to become head of corporate affairs at the Philip Morris Companies.

title: Gannett Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Integra Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Man In the News: Willie Lawrence Williams; An Astute Manager
description: A few months after the beating of Rodney King by Los Angeles police officers last spring, Philadelphia's police commissioner asked a local civic group to evaluate the police department's ability to prevent such an occurrence from happening here. In particular, the commissioner, Willie L. Williams, asked for suggestions for improving police training and discipline, the handling of complaints and ways to identify officers who might use violence or excessive force.

title: Johnson Controls reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: All share earnings are after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Bard (C.R.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Studio! Life Style! Empire?
description: ORIBE, the star hair stylist to the star models Linda Evangelista, Naomi Campbell, Christy Turlington et al, lingered for a moment outside a converted garage on Washington Street in the West Village. Wearing tight purple jeans and a leather jacket, he turned a well-heeled cowboy boot toward a huge glass doorway. Running a hand through a head of matinee-idol-thick black hair, he buzzed and then entered a cavernous concrete white-washed space.

title: Shawmut National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included securities gains of $ 68.4 million, and a gain of $ 9.7 million from the sale of home equity loan pass through certificates. The latest results also included core earnings of $ 65.6 million.c-Net loss and included a $ 71.5 million gain from the corporation's sale of its credit card and merchant card businesses.

title: CBS Reports 79% Increase In Its Operating Earnings
description: CBS Inc. said yesterday that its operating income jumped nearly 79 percent in the first quarter, mainly as a result of reduced costs, especially in the network news division, which spent millions of dollars covering the Persian Gulf war last year.

title: First Fidelity Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included $ 3.8 million in net securities gains.c-Included a gain of $ 31 million from the sale of a subsidiary as well as $ 15.2 million in net securities gains.

title: Review/Television; Dr. Kildare? Well, No. But a Human Face.
description: It's not as if television entertainment has turned its back completely on doctors and hospitals. There's Dr. Huxtable in "The Cosby Show" on NBC and there's the wisecracking gang on "Nurses," also on NBC. Over on ABC, Doogie Howser, M.D. does see patients between bouts of teen-age angst. But where are the serious dramas about medicine, the kind that became television staples, dating back to the days of "Dr. Kildare" and "Ben Casey"? Is the form still trying to recover from the cheeky irreverence of "St. Elsewhere"? Perhaps.

title: Market Place; Hanson Viewed As Undervalued
description: AFTER years of trying, Hanson P.L.C. has finally nudged the level of American ownership of its stock over 20 percent. However, that is far short of the goal the industrial and natural resources conglomerate outlined to American analysts and portfolio managers during the company's recent investment roadshows.

title: Ruling on Apple May Ease Development of Software
description: With most of Apple Computer's arguments in the company's four-year-old copyright infringement suit against Microsoft and Hewlett-Packard tossed out by a Federal judge on Tuesday, many industry analysts said today that a freer operating environment could ensue for software developers.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Republicans; Quayle's Damage-Control Squad Rebuts Accuser on a Talk Show
description: Listeners had no way of knowing that White House damage controllers were at work early this week when a man identifying himself only as Dave called a San Antonio radio talk show to berate the guest.

title: Drug Arrest of Postal Worker Shows That Trouble Can Touch Senate Too
description: A six-month undercover investigation at the Senate post office last year by the United States Capitol Police and the Federal Bureau of Investigation has resulted in drug charges against a Senate postal employee who sold crack to a narcotics officer at the Dirksen Senate office building.

title: Columbia Journal; Doolittle Raiders Recall 30 Seconds in History
description: Fifty years ago Jimmy Doolittle, then a lieutenant colonel in the Army Air Forces, flew to a small air base south of here seeking volunteers for a World War II mission that he described only as top secret and extremely hazardous.

title: Former Football Star Gets Job at Drug Maker
description: Nicholas A. Buoniconti, whose career has run from professional football to charities to business, yesterday was named vice chairman and chief operating officer of Columbia Laboratories Inc., a pharmaceuticals company.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Saturday about the dedication of a newly restored Upper Manhattan park originally designed by Frederick Law Olmsted Jr. misidentified the school attended by the students shown. It is the Incarnation School, not the Immaculata School.

title: Article 819592 -- No Title
description: The International Monetary Fund said today that the former Soviet Union would need $44 billion in foreign aid this year to help insure that the transition to a market economy does not break down.

title: Corrections
description: An article by The Associated Press in Business Day yesterday about brokerage earnings misstated the increase in compensation and benefits paid by Merrill Lynch & Company in the first quarter. It was 15.4 percent.

title: Bear Stearns Says Profits Are Up 58.2%
description: The Bear Stearns Companies, riding the wave of record earnings that Wall Street firms are reporting, said yesterday that profits in its fiscal third quarter rose 58.2 percent, to $91.3 million, its best quarterly result ever.

title: Review/Piano; Seeking to Make a Point While Making Music
description: There were times, on Tuesday night at the 92d Street Y, when the framing of the concert distracted from the attention due the Portuguese pianist Pedro Burmester, a 28-year-old "distinguished loser" of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. This was the last of a three-concert series dubbed Goldfingers. Imaginatively conceived by Joseph Horowitz, the series attempted to suggest that when it comes to competitions, a loss could be as great a credential as a laurel. In fact, immediately after the close of Mr. Burmester's performance of Bach's "Goldberg" Variations, the pianist joined a panel on the stage for a discussion titled "Piano Competitions: Are They a Necessary Evil?"

title: Sports of The Times; Coleman's Sulking Dims Nets' Glow
description: THE Nets should be smiling, aglow with pride in escaping from their treadmill to oblivion.

title: Dr. Gregory Jameson, 77, Known For Work With Heart Catheters
description: Dr. A. Gregory Jameson, emeritus professor of clinical medicine at the College of Physicians and Surgeons at Columbia University, and former director of cardiology at Roosevelt Hospital, died on March 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 77 years old.

title: Parents Also Have to Learn About Guns; Rifle Group Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Cards' Smith Is Out
description: St. Louis Cardinals pitcher BRYN SMITH is expected to miss at least two months after underdoing arthroscopic surgery on his right elbow. Cardinals physician Dr. STAN LONDON said yesterday that the surgery, performed Tuesday in Los Angeles, involved the removal of fragments and general cleaning of the elbow.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The per share earnings reflected a 3-for-1 common stock split. On a pre-split basis, per share earnings amounted to $ 2.34 for the latest first quarter, compared with $ 2.12 for year-ago period.

title: Norwest Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Afghan Rebels Say They Hold Major Air Base
description: Two rebel groups contended today that they had captured a major Government air base 30 miles north of Kabul, the capital, although it was impossible to confirm the reports.

title: A Coke and a Plaque
description: DONALD KEOUGH, president of the Coca-Cola Company was selected yesterday to receive the Gold Medal Award of the National Football Foundation and College Football Hall of Fame. Keough, the unanimous choice of the foundation's board of directors, will be honored at the foundation dinner and Hall of Fame induction ceremony Dec. 8 in New York.

title: Several Big Banks Post Higher Quarterly Profits
description: Several large banks around the country yesterday reported large gains in profits during the first quarter as problems with bad loans declined and they benefited from a wider spread between the interest rates they pay on deposits and the interest rates they collect on loans.

title: An Art Collection Gathered Cheaply
description: ART by van Gogh sells for tens of millions of dollars. Paint-by-number art can sell for 50 cents a picture, and that's what Michael O'Donoghue, a New York screenwriter, collects. More than 200 pieces from his collection can be seen in "1952-1992: 40 Years of Paint-by-Number Paintings" at the Bridgewater/Lustberg Gallery, 529 Broadway (Spring Street), from April 20 to 25.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: PORCH railings are frequent casualties of winter weather. Because railings are important to safety, any damage should be repaired promptly. But even if railings appear sound, they should be inspected each spring, a good time to perform routine maintenance.

title: Old Mills and Factories All Over the Northeast Get a New Life
description: To the Editor:

title: Presidential Realty reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After investment gains of $ 41,000, or 2 cents a share, in the quarter and $ 222,000, or 7 cents a share, in the year.c-Net incomed-After an investment loss of $ 14,000 in the quarter and an investment gain of $ 901,000, or 27 cents a share, in the year, and both periods included a $ 259,000 writedown of loans receivable.

title: U.S. Backs Delta On Pan Am Route
description: The Transportation Department gave final approval to Delta Air Lines' proposed purchase of a Detroit-to-London route from the Pan Am Corporation, the defunct carrier, subject to possible court action. Northwest Airlines has opposed the route transfer, and last week Pan Am filed a notice that it would terminate its contract to give Delta the route.

title: Valley National Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net securities gains of $ 5.3 million in the latest first quarter and $ 6.8 million in year-ago period.Valley National said that earnings for latest quarter included the impact from adoption of Statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes, which resulted in the recognition of $ 40.2 million, after taxes, of previously unrecorded tax benefits.

title: Spain's Objective: Peaceful Games
description: Now just three months away, the Barcelona Olympics are well on course to become the largest Games ever staged, with more countries and athletes than ever helping Spain commemorate a year also notable for the 500th anniversity of Columbus's voyage to the new world and the birth of the European Community.

title: First Bank System Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bailout Agency Falls Short
description: The Federal agency that is disposing of failed savings and loans institutions announced today that it would fall $15 billion short of its target for asset sales by the end of September.

title: In Tally of '91 Income, President Lost to Both the I.R.S. and His Dog
description: President Bush made public his 1991 Federal tax returns today. The numbers show that he took a drubbing not only from the Internal Revenue Service but from the family dog as well.

title: Review/Dance; Famous Literary Bunny for Children and Adults
description: This is the time in the spring holiday season when greeting-card racks and gift-shop windows are filled with images of bunnies. Therefore it is only appropriate that O.D.C./San Francisco is honoring a famous literary bunny at the Joyce Theater.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt * California Pollution Control Finance Authority is offering $35 million in tax-exempt pollution-control revenue bonds due 2009 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs. The bond has a 6.625 percent coupon and is priced at 99.375 to yield about 6.686 percent. However, for some investors this debt issue may be subject to the alternative minimum tax.

title: 3 Shot, Including Retired Officer, When Queens Robbery Is Foiled
description: A retired police officer and his son were wounded yesterday afternoon when their routine visit to a doctor's office met up with a robbery in progress.

title: Bridge
description: Ask any knowledgeable follower of the game to name the player with the biggest collection of master points and he would probably come up with the name of Paul Soloway of Mill Creek, Wash., who last year brought his total to more than 35,000. Soloway and his closest rivals are all professionals, mostly from California and Texas, who follow the tournament circuit year in, year out.

title: ISOLATION OF LIBYA GROWS AS ITS LINKS TO WORLD ARE CUT
description: Air traffic between Libya and the rest of the world appeared at a standstill today as both Arab and non-Arab countries began enforcing the second major punitive embargo the Security Council has imposed on a United Nations member since the end of the cold war.

title: Peru's Chief: Every Bit the Emperor
description: Alberto K. Fujimori, Peru's pragmatic and business-suited President, has lived up to his flashy street nickname, the Emperor.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results have been restated for the effects of the Oct. 1, 1991, merger with FNW Bancorp, which was accounted as a pooling of interests.The per share amounts for 1991 have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split distributed on Jan. 6, 1992, to shareholders of record Dec. 27, 1991.

title: TRANSACTIONS
description: Baseball American League AL -- Named John Ricco assistant public relations director.

title: Martin W. Donner, 71, A Leader in Radiology
description: Dr. Martin W. Donner, a leader in radiology and in swallowing disorders, died on Monday at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore. He was 71 years old and lived in Ruxton, Md.

title: Profit Growth Slows at Merck and Upjohn
description: Reflecting the pressures on drug prices and flagging sales for older products, two large pharmaceutical companies reported yesterday that their earnings growth slowed during the first quarter.

title: Maple Leafs Get a Final Hurrah
description: "Oil me," the Rangers creaked tonight.

title: Standard Register reports earnings for Qtr to March 29
Parents Also Have to Learn About Guns; Another Curriculum
description: To the Editor:

title: Meridian Bancorp Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss of $ 3.5 million from discontinued operations.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Courier Looks Strong Jim Courier looked every bit the top-ranked player in the world as he breezed past Martin Damm of Czechoslovakia, 6-2, 6-1, yesterday in the second round of the Salem Open in Hong Kong. Courier, celebrating his return to the head of the ranking, needed only 64 minutes to dispose of Damm and move into the quarterfinals, where he will meet a South African, Gary Muller, tomorrow. (AP) 14-Year-Old Is Winner: Iva Majoli of Croatia, a 14-year-old rookie pro ranked 537th in the world, upset fifth-seeded Lori McNeil, 6-3, 6-3, yesterday in the Virginia Slims tennis tournament in Houston. Majoli was given a wild-card entry into the tournament, her first appearance on the Virginia Slims tour. Majoli broke McNeil, the world's 24th-ranked player, in the sixth game to take charge of the match. Leading by 5-3 in the second set, Majoli also broke McNeil, who was playing in front of her hometown fans, in the final game. (AP) SOCCER Barcelona Back in Final Barcelona and Sampdoria of Genoa advanced to the European Champions Cup final last night and will play for the championship on May 20 at Wembley Stadium outside London. Sampdoria, which won its first Italian League title last May, tied Panathinaikos of Athens, 1-1, while Barcelona beat Benfica of Lisbon, 2-1. It is the third European Champions Cup final for Barcelona. Werder Bremen of Germany and AS Monaco advanced to the Cup Winners Cup final in Lisbon, while Ajax Amsterdam and Turin advanced to the home-and-home final of the U.E.F.A. Cup. (AP)

title: Ethyl Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included First Colony Life Insurance Co. after-tax realized gains on investments of $ 11 million, or 9 cents a share, in latest first quarter and $ 3.1 million, or 3 cents a share, in year-ago period.

title: Oce-van der Grinten nv reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 29
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and have been converted from Dutch guilders/florins (NLG) 1.8427 equaled $ 1.00.

title: THE 1992 CAMPAIGN: Political Memo; Shooting From the Lip, Retired 'Boy Wonder' Picks His Targets With Ease
description: Four years after fleeing Washington out of contempt for politics, Patrick H. Caddell, once the self-described "boy wonder of American politics," now jokes that he has "strapped my guns back on" like the fictional character Shane.

title: Work Force Entrants Fill Service Jobs
description: The Census Bureau reported today that 76 percent of the people who entered the work force from 1987 to 1989 took jobs in the service-producing industry.

title: Parking Rules
description: Because of Good Friday and the first day of Passover, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow and Saturday. Other regulations remain in effect.

title: Review/Music; Elise Ross Sings Bartok, Ives and Others
description: Elise Ross finds the recital stage simply one more arena for theater. No stationary positions in front of the piano, no trusting of her message to sheer sound. Throughout this program of Ives, Rachmaninoff, Bartok, Ravel and Weill at Town Hall on Sunday afternoon, Ms. Ross prowled the stage much like the caged cat in the first of her Charles Ives songs. It can be a disastrous strategy -- a dangerous descent into overkill -- but she does it better than most, depending on a mixture of vulnerability and forwardness to sell her songs and win her audience.

title: Babies Too Tiny, Risks Too Big
description: Anyone aspiring to be President, including the incumbent, would be well advised to read a new report from the National Commission to Prevent Infant Mortality. It's a grim tale.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the appointment of Ronald S. Johnson as New York City coordinator for AIDS policy misstated his educational background. He did graduate work at Harvard but has no master's degree from there.

title: Bag of Fetal Remains Found in Oklahoma
description: Two fishermen found the remains of 48 fetuses that had been abandoned in a field near Shawnee, Okla., the authorities said today.

title: American's Bookings Rise 46%
description: American Airlines said yesterday that the new, lower fares it introduced last Thursday had generated a 46 percent increase in bookings from normal levels for this time of year.

title: Reebok International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Rohm & Haas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter's results included a gain of 27 cents a share from the sale of land and securities, and a charge of 26 cents a share for accruals for waste disposal site cleanup costs.

title: LINKED TO MAFIA, UNION CHIEF QUITS
description: The head of the most powerful union in the New York region's construction industry resigned yesterday only hours before he was to face charges that he had been a pawn of the Gambino crime family and had helped John Gotti extract payoffs from contractors.

title: Editorial Notebook; Forbidden Delights
description: People do not eat chocolate. They sneak it. When somebody floats a box of bonbons under their noses they mutter, "Well, maybe just one." When they munch a candy bar they do so with the furtiveness of a wino pulling at a bagged bottle of Thunderbird.

title: Vroom! Torborg's Lineup Changes Put Mets in Gear
description: The latest radical reconstruction of the lineup for the Mets didn't require the expenditure of millions of dollars, only some brain power. Manager Jeff Torborg went to work with his pencil and his instincts, stitching together a lineup of substitutes, backups and hunches.

title: Mercantile Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: "Those who think you can remove the problem by violence, by more killing, are dead wrong." -- CYRUS R. VANCE, United Nations envoy, in Yugoslavia. [ A1:5. ]

title: Bridgeport U. Clears Path For Bailout
description: Deeply in debt and fast running out of students, the University of Bridgeport tonight agreed to pursue a bail-out plan that would give control of the private university to the Professors World Peace Academy, an affiliate of the Unification Church.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Currents column of The Home Section on April 9 about a dollhouse that looks like a New York loft building misidentified Kevin Walz, one of its designers. He is a principal of Walz Design, not an architect.

title: Taiwan Official Resigns In Debate on McDonnell
description: The chairman of the Taiwan Aerospace Corporation has resigned in the midst of a debate within the Taiwan Government over whether to proceed with a deal to acquire 40 percent of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's commercial aircraft business, industry executives said today.

title: Two Military Contractors Post Big Gains in Quarter
description: The General Dynamics Corporation and the Northrop Corporation, two of the nation's largest military contractors, reported sharp increases in first-quarter earnings yesterday.

title: Iran Is Said to Expel Arabs From Gulf Island
description: Iran has stirred concern among its neighbors in the Persian Gulf by expelling Arab residents of an island in the middle of the gulf that they jointly administer with the United Arab Emirates, officials in gulf nations said.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Home Section on April 9 with an article about black architects misidentified Robert L. Easter. He is to become president of the National Organization of Minority Architects in the fall. William J. Stanley 3d is the current president.

title: Pacific Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are after preferred dividend requirements.

description: b-Included a $ 5 million provision for the shutdown of Hussmann Australia, which was offset by tax benefits of an equivalent amount.c-After income of $ 17.2 million, or 16 cents a share, from discontinued operations.

description: Sales represented net sales.

Pilana Journal; Village Life in India Is Invaded by Big City Tastes
description: Already the fields of wheat enveloping this jumble of low brick-and-mud houses are well past waist high, undulating waves of green-gold that lap into the distance, a gentle barrier fencing Pilana off from other villages and from distant towns and cities.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRENT SCOWCROFT, national security adviser to President Bush, has been named the winner of the first Eisenhower Leadership Prize, to be awarded by Gettysburg College and its affiliate, the Eisenhower World Affairs Institute.

title: Some Serious Fun For Mercedes-Benz
description: The initial advertising created for Mercedes-Benz of North America Inc. by its new agencies introduces an ingredient previously missing from the car company's campaigns: fun.

title: Baxter International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
What Iran's Vote Doesn't Change
description: President Hashemi Rafsanjani, reputedly a pragmatist, seems to have prevailed in Iran's parliamentary elections. Official results give his party a commanding lead. But before the vote, a Council of Guardians disqualified dozens of hostile candidates as spiritually incorrect. And though the Government claimed a massive turnout, foreign reporters saw few lines at polling booths.

title: Continental Air Gets Extension
description: A Federal judge gave Continental Airlines nine more weeks to file a plan detailing how creditors will be paid under its bankruptcy reorganization. Zack Clement, the airline's lawyer, said the extension was warranted because of the complexity of the case and industry itself. Federal Bankruptcy Court Judge Helen T. Balick said the airline should detail its plans for a hearing on May 12. The hearing was set for June 22.

title: At 'Guys and Dolls,' Seeking Fun and Breaking a Record
description: When the head porter at the Martin Beck Theater showed up for work at 8 A.M. yesterday, the line had already formed for "Guys and Dolls." Then it grew, and grew. Even Michael Jukovsky was impressed. Mr. Jukovsky, well known to theater personnel up and down Broadway as New York's most persistent patron of musicals, holds the distinction of having bought the first ticket for the first preview of "Guys and Dolls."

title: Board of Trade Back at Work
description: Futures and options trading resumed at the Chicago Board of Trade yesterday on a shortened schedule that will continue today. Trading in all contracts opened at noon and closed at 2 P.M., central time, and the tables on page D20 reflect the shortened schedule. Activity resumed after a two day suspension caused by flooding that forced much of downtown Chicago to turn off electrical power. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange resumed normal trading in all contracts.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acme Electric Corp., East Aurora, N.Y., appointed Dan Corwin chief financial officer and vice president for administration. * Chase Manhattan Bank N.A., New York, named John P. Mellor, human resources executive for regional banking, to the additional post of senior vice president.

title: Martin Marietta Buys Quarries
description: The Martin Marietta Corporation, the nations's third-largest producer of crushed stone for the construction industry, said it had bought two stone quarries in Virginia. No price was disclosed, but one analyst estimated it at about $25 million.

title: Grainger (W.W.) Inc. (N) reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Maytag Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Albany Reaches Tentative Labor Pact
description: New York State reached a tentative contract agreement with its largest public employees union today, ending a contentious period in which disgruntled state workers have labored without a contract for more than a year.

title: Review/Dance; Not-So-Typical Views Of Sexuality in Motion
description: Sometimes he hits it and sometimes he doesn't. The second program by the Mark Morris Dance Group is nowhere near as substantial, nowhere near as good as the one that opened the company's current season at the Manhattan Center, 311 West 34th Street.

title: Incumbents Outpace Rivals in Raising Campaign Funds
description: Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato reported today that he added almost $1.1 million to his bulging political war chest in the first quarter of the year and for the first time had raised more money in a three-month period than any of the four Democrats seeking their party's nomination to oppose him.

title: Animals As Artistic Inspirations
description: "CUTE is the operative word here," said Dorothy Twining Globus, the curator of exhibitions at the Cooper-Hewitt Museum. She was talking about "Animals in Design," which runs through July 20 at the museum, 2 East 91st Street in Manhattan.

title: Snap-on Tools Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $ 38,949,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.The company adopted SFAS No. 106, Employers' Accounting for Post-Retirement Benefits Other than Pensions, effective January 1991. The 1991 statement of earnings has been restated to reflect the cumulative effect of this accounting change.

title: Investigation Begun Into New York City Sludge Removal Program
description: The Manhattan District Attorney's Office has subpoenaed records of New York City's Department of Environmental Protection for an investigation into its sludge-removal program, department officials said yesterday.

title: Tokyo Stocks Steady
description: Japanese stocks showed little change today after recovering from some earlier losses. The Nikkei index of 225 issues moved above the 18,000-point level and then retreated. Brokers said bargain-hunting helped to firm up prices. At the close, the Nikkei was up 11.75 points, to 17,959.76. It gained 508.43 points on Wednesday. About 380 million shares were traded.

title: Home Video
description: The Hits Are Coming

title: Abroad at Home; Straight and Narrow
description: One of Dwight Eisenhower's most important contributions as President was his choice of Federal judges in the South. His nominees played a crucial part in leading the region away from segregation and lawlessness.

title: Alltel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The earnings have been restated to reflect the acquisition of Computer Power Inc., on a pooling-of-interests basis.The quarter's results reflected net after-tax costs of $ 5 million related to the acquisition of Computer Power.

title: Devils Need Inspiration, But Get Rangers Instead
description: Two nights after playing one of their most inspired games of the season, the Devils tonight closed out their regular season with one of their most uninspired efforts in a 7-0 loss to the Islanders at Nassau Coliseum. Next: the Rangers in the first round of the National Hockey League playoffs.

title: Tips for Tark the Shark and Other Musings
description: Welcome to San Antonio, Jerry Tarkanian. Welcome to the Spurs. Welcome to the big leagues. After all these years of fighting with the preppie bureaucrats, all we can say is: What took you so long?

title: Russian Cabinet Wins Shaky Support of Assembly
description: Russia's Cabinet withdrew its resignation today after the Congress of Peoples' Deputies passed a muted declaration of support for the course of radical economic reform.

description: b-Net income and included tax benefit of $ 740,574.

title: New Study Bolsters Skin Cancer's Link To Halogen Lamps
description: Scientists said today that they have more evidence that halogen lights may increase the risk of skin cancer, a risk that apparently can be eliminated by using simple glass or plastic covers over the bulbs.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Removing the name Union of Soviet Socialist Republics from an entire country is one thing, but erasing it from a beauty pageant is quite another. So YULIYA YETINA, a 17-year-old student at the University of St. Petersburg, arrived in New York this week wearing the crown of Miss U.S.S.R., which she had won in March.

title: Panhandle Eastern Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lessons in Protection -- A special report.; Trade Curbs: Do They Do the Job?
description: In the midst of the recession and election campaign, protectionist pressures have boiled to the surface, but economists say that import restrictions have had glaringly mixed results for the industries they were supposed to help.

title: Dun & Bradstreet Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago first quarter was restated to reflect adoption of certain new accounting standards.

title: Caterpillar's Trump Card; Threat of Permanently Replacing Strikers Gave Company Advantage Against Union
description: The abrupt end of a five-month strike against Caterpillar Inc. showed that management can bring even a union so mighty and rich as the United Automobile Workers to its knees by asserting that experienced machinists, tool makers and technicians add no more value to the products they make than an untrained job hunter who comes in off the street.

title: U.S. Trust Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Head of Police in Philadelphia Chosen for Chief in Los Angeles
description: A little over a year after the videotaped beating of a black motorist by white police officers plunged this city into racial discord, the Los Angeles Police Commission has chosen a successor to Chief Daryl F. Gates. He would be the city's first black chief of police.

title: Defiant Chinese Dissident Tells of His Ordeal
description: What is remarkable about Han Dongfang is not that the prison authorities jammed a needle through his hand or that they infected him with tuberculosis, but that he talks about his experience and risks it all over again.

title: Tennstedt Cancels Concerts
description: The conductor Klaus Tennstedt has canceled his three remaining concerts with the New York Philharmonic because of illness, the orchestra has announced. Kurt Masur, the ensemble's music director, will conduct the scheduled program: the Sibelius Violin Concerto (Nigel Kennedy, soloist) and the Brahms First Symphony. Performances are tonight at 8, tomorrow at 11 A.M. and Tuesday at 7:30. Information: (212) 721-6500.

title: Rubbermaid Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $ 17,281,000 gain from the cumulative effect of changes in accounting principles, including adoption of FAS No. 109, Accounting for Income Taxes.

title: Marshall Moran, Nepal Priest, 85
description: The Rev. Marshall Moran, an American-born priest regarded as the pioneer of modern education in Nepal, has died at the age of 85, his school announced today.

description: Three teen-agers pleaded guilty today to murder in the ritualistic strangulation of a friend, and agreed under a plea bargain to testify against two other suspects in the slaying.

title: Industrial Output Gains Second Straight Month
description: Aided by a weather-induced surge in demand for electric and gas, industrial output rose two-tenths of 1 percent in March, producing the first back-to-back advance since last summer, the Federal Reserve reported today.

description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, the federally chartered corporation known as Fannie Mae, which invests in home mortgages, priced a two-part offering totaling $1.1 billion yesterday through various securities dealers.

title: Essay; The Rising Gorge
description: Outrage is In. The fashion color for spring is red in the face. The national gorge on the rise.

title: Lincoln Fails After Review Of Hospitals
description: In the most glaring sign of continuing troubles at two New York City hospitals, the national hospital accreditation organization has voted to strip Lincoln Medical and Mental Health Center in the Bronx of its accreditation and grant Kings County Hospital Center in Brooklyn only conditional accreditation.

title: Once Again, Blue Jays Leave Yankees in Dark at the Dome
description: Sometimes a teams gets only one or two chances to score in a game, a crucial opening or two for a big inning against a pitcher who is toying with them out after frustrating out. If those rare chances are missed, the night can be dark. Even inside a domed stadium.

Streets of New York
description: As with any new sports promotion in New York, the horns have started blowing early for the Indy-car race scheduled for June 1993 around the World Trade Center. And when it comes to excessive horn-blaring, who knows better than a New York cabdriver?

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that 1992 first-quarter results included one-time, after-tax gains of about $ 45 million, or 11 cents a share, attributable to a refund of tax and interest arising from the favorable settlement during the quarter of an income tax matter related to pre-divestiture tax periods, and a $ 15 million, or 4 cents a share, Federal Communications Commission over-earnings adjustment.

title: On One Side of Gun Control, She Puts Connecticut on the Other
description: THE State of Connecticut, through its public investment in the Colt's Manufacturing Company, has become a major, if perhaps unwitting, force in the effort to overturn or undermine restrictions on assault weapons across the nation, a leading gun-control advocate contended yesterday.

title: Winnie Mandela Resigns a Post
description: Winnie Mandela resigned under pressure today from her influential post as head of social welfare in the African National Congress. The move came two days after the announcement of her formal separation from her husband, Nelson Mandela, the congress president.

title: Italian Furniture Goes All Cuddly
description: THIS year at the Salone del Mobile Italiano (a k a the Italian Furniture Fair, where the shape of a chair can be as cataclysmic as the length of a skirt), there was no denying that modern furniture design had done a double somersault and landed on sweet little feet.

title: Global Marine Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $ 3.3 million, or 3 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and included $ 11 million gain on sale of drilling rig.c-Net loss

title: Bear Stearns Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 27
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividend declared April 15.

title: Gains at A.T.& T., Sprint and Telesis
description: A.T.& T. and the Sprint Corporation, two leading long-distance telephone companies, reported strong first-quarter earnings yesterday, in large measure because of cost-cutting moves like layoffs and plant closings. But the recession continued to take its toll with lackluster revenue growth in the quarter.

title: United Way Group Severs Tie
description: The United Way of Greater Milwaukee has severed all ties with United Way of America, saying an entirely new national organization must be created in the wake of allegations of lavish spending and financial manipulation against former top officials. The Milwaukee chapter, which raised $26 million in 1991, is the largest to break with United Way of America, the national organization said. Of 2,100 affiliates around the nation, only two others -- in Kalamazoo, Mich., and Warren County, Ohio -- have voted to cut ties.

title: Students Teaching Teachers; Immigrants Reverse Language-Skill Roles in Bronx School
description: With the nervous expressions of students afraid of being called on, eight teachers at Theodore Roosevelt High School in the Bronx sat in a semicircle the other afternoon, while the same number of teen-agers sat beside them looking smugly self-confident.

title: Manufacturers National reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEWS SUMMARY
